Kathy, his Executive Secretary, followed through with my car rental arrangements with their own Hertz office at the hotel, efficiently run by Dallas, along with having my materials for my business trip organized and loaded into my rental car. They also arranged for my pick-up by Rainui and drop off by Sahng at Honolulu Airport, who were both cheerful, helpful, and very efficient with their communications so we could easily coordinate our meeting details. Bart, who oversaw the front desk, made sure that I was accompanied to my suite quickly when I arrived, so I did not have to wait at all at the front desk to check in. DeeDee, the concierge, made sure that I got whatever I needed, including her offer to print my airline boarding pass and send it to my room without me even asking her to do it. The parking attendants and bell staff were always available whenever I needed assistance with my car or luggage, and consistently with a big smile.Because I travel for business, I stay in a lot of hotels. The Kahala pampers its guests, and makes everyone feel special. The staff anticipates your needs, and makes sure you have everything taken care of so you can enjoy your stay. They are very gracious, respectful, positive, and caring. They have a wonderful work ethic, which, I believe, is set by their General Manager. You experience it throughout the hotel.I also want to recommend The Plumeria Beach House, the hotel's oceanside restaurant. The setting is beautiful, overlooking the beach, and the menu is very extensive, so there is something for everyone. The food is delicious, and the servers are friendly and helpful. I had a wonderful lunch buffet there which had a huge selection, and everything I ate was delicious, especially the bread pudding and sauce which I had for dessert.The bottom line is that after my two stays, The Kahala has consistently reflected high standards, great accommodations, a beautiful location just outside of Waikiki, and a staff with superior service. It's no wonder that travelers come to vacation there from all over the world. Staying at The Kahala is an experience that you will always remember. I look forward to my return! Vivian

Seduced by the promise of resident dolphins in their own lagoon,a private beach and a seaside grill, I booked the Kahala,dolphin lagoon view room on a pay 3 nights get 4 at $750 US a night , slightly less for the other nights, and including breakfast.I thought I would be enjoying 5 star luxury which would start at check in. Not so.The booking was made well in advance with early arrival and second floor room request advised. The first night fee was taken as a deposit. My two subsequent emails asking for a receipt of payment did not get a response. I telephoned long distance international and was relieved when the call was taken by Cameron, the concierge.He was able to book a hotel limo transfer for me and reassured me that the hotel was indeed open and trading and my reservation was in place.Cameron was as good as his word and the limo transfer spot on.Check in was a disaster. No Aloha spirit at this front desk. A surly, unsmiling welcome waited and all in one breath I was told "Aloha' ,the rates per each night, a lei was flung around my neck, a towel presented and finally "we are putting a US$2000 hold over your credit card which if cancelled could take up to 3 days to lift , and oh yes, we regret at this time your room is not available and we can't tell you when it will be but we can say it will not be on the second floor."I had no problem that the room was not ready as regular check time was 3pm.I had to ask where I could get a coffee and some food.The hospitality lounge was up one floor, no signage but I was able to find a housekeeping staffer to direct me. There is a coffee machine but not even a cookie and two hours sitting looking at a blank wall is not fun.All that was needed at check in was for someone to be assigned to walk me nowhere i could sit comfortably and have a meal and a coffee.It was 3pm when I got into my room. I would be moved to my requested second floor the next day. That occurred at 4p.mThe Kahala is a sprawling hotel with eateries a fair distance from the lobby. Directional signage is almost non existent, steps are many and elevators few and far between.The room service menu is limited , US$42 for a steak plus 18 and a half % gratuities and an $8 delivery charge for your order. No wonder so many eat offsite.The main beachfront restaurant is used for breakfast as well.The view is as beautiful as I had imagined, the dark and dingy outdated decor is not.Room 1211, the second floor Dolphin Room was extremely spacious,had a great view over the dolphin pool and had once had a stylish and smart decor . In Room 1123, my first assigned ground floor room, the wall repaint when done had left paint splashed over the alarm clock and some of the furniture but failed to address the peeling paint issues elsewhere.The hotel is popular with Japanese visitors, children and everyone who loves seeing dolphins up close.The famous dolphins are very entertaining and very smart . Smart too are the pretty lemon coloured uniforms of the housekeeping staff but sadly that is about all that is smart about this now faded former great hotel.What a disappointment.

Enjoyed the hotel very much from its friendly staff to its great location. The restaurants and spa can’t be beat. The beach is the best on the island and staff make you feel very comfortable. Great place to chill and close enough to the action in Waikiki. Had a nice package that made the pricing competitive.

Stayed for four nights in a ocean view terrace room.Staff was amazing and excellent- you can feel it the whole time you are there. Really a top notch place.Room was spacious and comfortable.Great views.Food at restaurants was good-plumeria, arancino, and the veranda (with jazz).We had breakfast included and 50$ per day resort credit.Beach is nice as well as pool. Pool might be crowded if it is busy.The location is great and this hotel is very HawaiianLoved it.

We had wonderful family dinner indoors but facing the beachside, it was a buffet, the seafood was exec Ella the and of course fresh, it also happen to be the night where they lit up the Christmas tree and there was carollers there and free drinks for the guest it was so much fun too.

My wife and I wanted a weekend getaway to celebrate my 60th birthday. We procrastinated and this resort was kind of an impromptu selection hours before the flight on Friday evening. It is a five star resort and lives up to its billing. We had to pay top Dollars but it was my 60th afterall! Though situated away from the maddening touristy crowds of the main waikiki beach, it is easy to get into the thick of things by using the free shuttle of a cheap ride on Lyft. (@10$) I have to give a shout out to our shuttle driver who gave us the best guided tour through the one hour drive from the hotel to town (usual drive is only @20 min but if you take multi stop shuttle it takes 1 hr and worth it if you have time) We greatly enjoyed it. Remember it is the backyard where president Obama grew up.Ambience of the resort: Elegant simplicity without being ostentatiously ornamented like many resorts.Staff: Professional;fast yet attentive overall and what you would expect from the staff of a luxury hotel Rooms are large and the bathrooms are excellent with wonderful housekeeping twice a day.The view of the ocean was amazing from our ocean view room There are other scenery as well all around especially that of the misty mountains and the famous diamond head. The beach itself is beautiful. The rains that preceded our arrival ,prevented us from getting in to the ocean. Food We ate at all the three restaurants. We usually skip the report food and seek out local fanfare but the breakfast buffet at Plumeria and the sunday seafood brunch at Hoku's are fabulous and nightly lazy time on the Veranda for drinks is relaxing.Overall it was a memorable trip for a landmark occasion. The $800/night tab for the room was well worth it. We will certainly stay here on our return to Ohau. I hope we would get a less expensive rate :)

I left my iPhone charger in the room but when we checked out they didn’t said that we left the charger, n when I called the receptionists looking for my charger they said she needs to asked the attendant to asked, how dishonest the staff for a charger, please don’t stay in this place because staff I know what call to call them, first time I encounter this kind, for all the hotels I stayed.

Stayed here for several days recently on holiday with my girlfriend to celebrate a significant birthday of hers, before going to Maui for a friends wedding. Let me start out by saying that it is my strong opinion that this is the best luxury hotel on Oahu. Upon check in, they were kind enough to upgrade us to a Ocean facing room with a balcony as it was her birthday, which we were very grateful for, and we were able to have great breakfasts on the the balcony, which was an experience on its own. I do admit, the hotel overall can seem a bit dated, however the service that you get, together with the atmosphere, location, and available amenities, make it irrelevant. As it was Spring Break season, the hotel was full of families and young children, which can be a mood breaker at times, especially when the pool and beach are overrun and overcrowded, however it wasn't much of an issue for us as we had planned activities outside for most days. The location is also great because you are away from the very touristy buzz of Waikiki, but close enough to all the spots that its easy to get to. They also have a shuttle service that will take you to several spots in town which was very useful. Overall, I wouldn't think twice about where to stay on Oahu. Kahala is the only option.

We celebrated our daughter’s wedding reception here last week and she couldn’t have selected a better spot!Venue, food and service were amazing. No one left dissatisfied or disappointed. Thank you to all that assisted in making this an exceptionally memorable experience.

We stayed in an ocean front lanai room, with a beautiful view of the pool, beach and ocean. It was very spacious, with a large lanai. The bathroom had two sides, each with a closet and drawers and a vanity, so each person had plenty of space. There was a Japanese style toilet with a control panel on the wall. On one bedside table, they provided a plug with multiple connectors for various types of phones/electronics; would have been even better if they were on both sides.I loved the classic feel of the place; it is an older resort, renovated, fresh and clean but built in a way that evoked memories of years gone by - for example, there are external staircases at either end of the wide hallways where you can step out and feel the Hawaiian breezes. Service is excellent, the pool area is not overcrowded and the beach is nicer than Waikiki, secluded and calm. There are some good restaurants onsite, a shopping mall nearby, and Waikiki is a short drive away. We previously stayed out at Ko Olina, which was more remote; I preferred the location of the Kahala, more convenient to activities in Waikiki or downtown Honolulu, yet removed from the crowds.

Even though we did not get "beach" weather, we thoroughly enjoyed our stay at the Kahala Hotel & Resort. On site restaurants are not only convenient but awesome food.We ate at the newly renovated Hoku two separate times. The service was great and the food fresh and creative. A good wine list also! Plumeria Beach cafe great buffet breakfast. We ate there everyday!All the staff at the hotel were efficient, friendly and helpful. We enjoyed watching the dolphins, fish and turtles with their trainers. Do you know you can teach a fish to reach up out of the water to get food on command? Very interesting.We took advantage of the onsite photographer to have photos taken on the beach. Very professional and we were thrilled with them. A great remembrance of our trip.Our room was on the 10th (highest) floor with a great view of the ocean from our lanai. Very nice rooms, elegantly appointed; although the lighting for putting on make up could have been better. Rooms were cleaned early and nightly turn down service was a treat. We will definitely stay there on future trips. It's away from the madness of Wakiki but within a 20 minute drive if you want to go there.All in all, a great place to stay!

We stayed at the Kahala resort in Oahu and came across a free photography session offered by the hotel. We were on a babymoon so thought this would be a great opportunity to capture some memories! We met Loryn who set up a quick photoshoot whenever it was convenient for us. The shoot was only half hour long but that was enough; she was able to capture some great images! The pictures were ready for my choosing the next day. There was no pressure at all whether I wanted to purchase any (but ofcourse I did since they were so great!). Loryn was so sweet during the shoot and posed us for all the photos so all we had to do was show up, enjoy the scenery and smile :) Overall it was a fun experience! - Priyanka

Wow, 4th time here & I think it can’t get much better but it does. Stayed in a more secluded area of the hotel which I really enjoyed because it offered a completely different view which was a nice surprise. Same friendly your-wish-is-my-command service. Still not used to that type of service & attitude. It could be the Aloha spirit which basically is nice, kind, decent folks. What really made this trip special was in addition to my husband there; I had 2 crazy funny gal pals. It was so much fun to party with your peeps in Paradise. We pretty much laughed, ate & drank in that order. Memorable restaurants were Gaze, Side Street & Hy’s steakhouse. Be warned you’ll pay top $$ for Hy’s but it was worth it. On top of that saw one of my fav performers, Jackson Browne at the Waikiki shell outdoor concert hall. Nice small venue but acoustics seemed not great on left side of stage. Maybe speaker problems. This vacation was a highlight in my life.  Mahalo Flora & Team Kahala❤️Aloha

Yes it is away from the shopping of Waikiki, yes it is not cheap, yes it is very quiet, and yes, we love it!Atmosphere is serene, views are amazing, and the tropical fish and dolphins and sea turtles on property are beautiful. Great place for a wedding and a great place for an anniversary! Pack a few books and get away

My husband and I wrapped up our 9-day babymoon vacation with a 2-night stay at The Kahala. I booked the room four months ago and booked a special package by booking early and paying in advance. I would highly recommend doing this because doing so awarded us with $150 worth of resort credits, which you can use for onsite parking and dining. This is by far the nicest hotel we have ever stayed at. From the moment you check in and receive a mint towel and fresh lei, you are treated like royalty. The staff are incredibly friendly and helpful. The property is intimate and lovely and does not feel like a resort at all, but rather a boutique hotel. The pool is nice and clean, always had plenty of lounge chairs available on the weekend and even though there were children, they were all well-behaved. The beach is lovely, not over-crowded and the water calm. We dined at both Hoku’s and Arancino’s - both are 5-star restaurants. Really exceptional service and food, coming from someone that lives in a big city and knows good food! Highly recommend Hoku’s for brunch. Arancino’s pre-fixe has fantastic options. We booked a photography session with the onsite Pacific Dream Photography last minute and they accommodated our request for a sunrise shoot of our baby bump (maternity photos). The session was complimentary and the photos turned out beautifully. We purchased a package. Loryn and Macy were so great to work with - responsive to texts/emails and very professional and talented. Highly recommend if you want to have special photos taken during your stay. I cannot say enough good things about our stay. If/when we return to O’ahu, we will absolutely stay at The Kahala again.

The resort is from another world a.k.a HAWAIIWe almost drowned but its ok. The dolphins were amazing and the locals are very nice. One of them let us stand on his surfboard to take a photo... The sea is a spectacular color... They had great facilities nearby and our favorite was the cheesecake factory. :)

Had a fantastic stay here- can't say enough great things about the Kahala. We had two rooms- one for two adults and one for three older teenagers. Our rooms were Ocean View Lanai, so they directly overlooked the arrival circle and parking area, but looked out onto the beachfront and had fantastic views of Diamond Head from the lanai. The rooms are large (the room for the teens had a rollaway and two double beds and still had enough room to get around) and the bathrooms are large and well appointed.The restaurants on site are a little pricey but worth it. We had the breakfast buffet at Plumeria Beach House that was included with our rooms and enjoyed going down daily. We also ate dinner several nights at Plumeria including their seafood buffet on Friday evening- all meals were fantastic. We ate one night at Arancino, the Italian restaurant onsite, and had an amazing meal there. Unfortunately, their signature restaurant Hoku was closed during our stay.The beach is protected enough to make swimming very safe. It's not a great lagoon for snorkeling (water too cloudy) or body boarding (waves break too far out). We did rent stand-up paddleboards, which the teens were brave enough to take out past the reef to where the breakers were. Chairs both at the beach and poolside were available even without reserving in advance.The teens participated in the Dolphin Quest encounter and loved it, but you can enjoy seeing the dolphins without participating as they are easily viewed in their lagoon. Overall we had a fabulous time. It's pricey, but comparable to other luxury resorts and worth every penny.

This resort is just a $2.75 bus ride from Waikiki. We could not afford to stay here but we could afford lunch at the seaside grill! Bonus is the free access to 6 Dolphins and sea turtles and koi fish. The dolphin trainers will answer all your questions and if you can afford it you can jump in the tank with these beautiful creatures. The resort is beautiful and the beach pristine. If you don't have $500 a night to stay here - go for lunch!

We stay at the Kahala for 4 days just this past spring break and love it! We also booked a complimentary photo shoot with Pacific Dream Photography at the Kahala. It rained on our original scheduled appointment, but Pacific Dream easily rescheduled us for the next day. We loved the relaxed vibe and energy from our photography Loryn. Our photos were absolutely beautiful and something my husband and I will cherished forever as our teen girls are getting older.

After an absence of 2 years I returned to the Kahala for a wonderful 4 nights. Although under renovation at the time the hotel continues to be a shining light for Honolulu hotels. Ocean View rooms are superb although on prior visits I stayed in mountain view rooms-the rooms are identical except for the views. Let your wallet decide.The hotel beach and overall service separate it from the crowded, intense Waikiki scene. This is the hotel to stay at in Honolulu. Frequent shuttle service to Waikiki makes access to restaurants and destinations in that area easy-be sure to reserve your shuttle.

The Kahala Hotel & Resort is a wonderful hotel in Hawaii. It has charming 1960's architecture and friendly staff who provide great service. This is not a typical Waikiki hotel that many might associate with Honolulu, packed with thousands of tourists who cram onto the beach there, and getting in and out is a nightmare due to the tour buses and traffic jam on the street. The Kahala is in a secluded area of Honolulu, just outside of a quiet residential area, yet it is not prohibitively far from major activities, beaches, and other destinations on the island. It has its own private beach, which gives guests an intimate feel of quiet and privacy. The waves (at least when we were there) were extremely small (virtually nonexistent), meaning it's good for small children or a leisurely swim, but not for those who may be interested in surfing or boogie-boarding. The hotel has a heated swimming pool, a kiddie Jacuzzi, and a salt-water Jacuzzi. The Kahala also has a fish / turtle / dolphin lagoon, where guests can book a swim with the dolphins (if you are comfortable with the ethics of that, it's the place for you, if not, it's not; I won't make judgements). When you check in, you are greeted by friendly staff who give you a fresh lei along with your room keys. The rooms are good and have all the necessary amenities, including showers, baths, ample closet space, and Japanese bidets. The toiletries provided are of good quality. One thing I noticed that was odd was that the television in our room was located off to the side, not above the desk or the bed, could have caused issues (thankfully, I had no intention of watching TV, so it had zero effect on me; also not sure if this was the case in other rooms). The food in the Plumeria Beach House restaurant was spectacular, from the breakfast buffet (which also had a wide variety of choices), to the dinner menu, to the alcoholic beverages and cocktails. The service there was also exceptional, on par with that of the rest of the hotel. The staff apparently provide or arrange good tours of the island, although we did not go on any. Definitely worth a stay if you're looking for hotels on Oahu.

Like all “grande dames” the Kahala oozes class (see photos). Even if it does not have all the mod cons, marble-everything etc... the hotel has been marvellously AND sympathetically maintained but there is no denying that it IS old. As such, it cannot possibly even be compared to the modern luxury brand properties / resorts (atrocities !), nor should it. Our room was quiet and clean and the bed comfortable. The only gripe I would have is that the towels were - and felt - old / used and could really be replaced more often than they clearly are. As we got a healthy discount on the rack rate I am prepared to overlook this aspect of things and give the Kahala maximum marks. I would probably give it only a four if paying full price.

I am torn. The Kahala in my opinion is the best place to stay on O'ahu, away from the craziness of Waikiki. "Upscale" I suppose but it is a bit tired, the pool is so small and I missed the sound of the waves crashing on the beach. The dolphins (which are a part of Dolphin Quest) are an addicting added bonus and since our balcony overlooked their lagoon we found ourselves sitting out watching them anytime we were in our room. Arancino is amazing and Chelsie is the BEST beach restaurant Server out there (but she was the only Server out there which was a problem). The Kahala takes the "Relax" vibe a bit too far but it is easy to dismiss because everyone is so nice. A few more servers, a bit of updating, and follow-through on every level would help to elevate The Kahala to the hotel it is known to be. There isn't much they can do about the waves breaking 100 feet out from the beach.

We stayed 6 nights in April and had a wonderful time. We had our photos taken with Pacific Dream Photography and our photographer Macy knew all the bests spots for photos: beach, trees, water, sunrise, etc... All I wanted was one good family picture and we got dozens! The other photographer, Loryn, walked us through all the photos to help us pick out the best ones. We got rained out the first day and they were able to reschedule easily, but the Kahala resort is so nice, we could have done indoor photos too. Both photographers were great with kids and I highly recommend them. We also had a wonderful time on the Holokino Sailing Adventure Tour. Again, great with kids and we saw 3 turtles swimming buy. One was huge! My husband is a sailor and he was impressed with our guide Austin's ship handling. It was a windy day and I was worried someone would get sea sick, but it was a smooth ride. Austin taught us how people navigated, the cool places to hike/visit and we all had a great time!The kids also went to the Keikei club and enjoyed it, we booked them in at the last minute and the concierge called my cell phone to make sure that I knew the kids could get in. The resort was very busy, but the beach had lots of space and we rented a cabana while the kids swam and played on the beach. The pool is warm! Valet parking was also quick and had bottles of water and towels for our day trips. Overall a great family vacation.

Stayed here 4 nights in March. Very comfortable beds , extremely quiet and clean rooms, fabulous breakfast buffet, and a wonderful beachfront. Pool/beach service fabulous. Always plenty of chairs as their pool attendants keep unused ones open and set you up. Would undoubtedly come back.

Everything about Kahala is 5 star. From the moment you walk into the stunning foyer & are greeted by reception, you know you are in for a treat. Every staff member is all about hospitality & customer service. We enjoyed a week of luxury & relaxation. Many Mahalos!

We just returned from a 2-week stay on Oahu. We spent 8 days in the hustle and bustle of Waikiki and spent the remaining 5 days at The Kahala. It was our first time at The Kahana and we enjoyed our stay tremendously. All the staff members (people at the front desk, waiters, housekeeping, valet staff) are extremely friendly and very professional. Our room was quite roomy, well appointed and had a covered lanai with comfy chairs. The ocean view from our 5th floor room was a little disappointing as we overlooked the roof of the lobby to the left and the top floor of the parking garage to the right before seeing the ocean. The view from a higher floor room is probably better. The bathroom had a His and Hers sink as well as His and Hers closets and drawers. Also a Toto washlet, a bathtub and separate walk-in shower, however, the handheld shower head doesn’t really belong in a luxury hotel of this category. When traveling through Japan last year we noticed a lot of the hotel showers have temperature controlled showers with both, a rain shower and a handheld shower head. Something to consider..... Turndown service was great, it also included fresh ice in the ice bucket as there are no ice- and vending machines on the floor. A good supply of bottled water is provided daily as is coffee and tea.The breakfast buffet was included with our Costco package and boy, they have one of the best breakfast buffets we’ve ever had! A large variety of breads, juices, fruits, smoked salmon, prosciutto, 5 warm breakfast items, Japanese breakfast items and an omelet station. Breakfast is in the Plumeria restaurant which also has a beautiful lanai overlooking the ocean. If you happen to be there on a Friday or Saturday, don’t miss the Seafood Buffet! A cornucopia of all kinds of seafood, sushi, sashimi, mini lobster rolls and for those craving some meat, they also served a delicious prime roast. Food and service at the Plumeria restaurant were outstanding!We had dinner once at the Seaside Grill where they serve salads, hamburgers and the like. Restaurant Hoku and the Veranda were closed for renovation during our stay. On the day of our departure our flight back to the mainland left in the evening and after checking out we spent some time in the hospitality room. Nice they have such a room, however, the hospitality room is not large enough to accommodate the amount of people using it. There is only one large bathroom with shower, toilet and sink. When we were there the 2 “dark rooms” were filled with guests (one very large family occupying both rooms) who had just arrived and were waiting for their rooms to be ready. When we were at the hospitality room there must have been about 20 guests, the bathroom was always occupied. I had to go to a bathroom on the Lower Level to change, another guest had to go downstairs to change as well. Adding at least a half bathroom would be helpful.There is a warm, welcoming atmosphere at the Kahala, it is a luxury family style hotel catering to guests of all ages.

While the food and amenities are great the public beach can be visited by any animal in human disquise. Throwing rubber balls to each other across the beach where families with young kids are playing. When complaining to the hotel they said they can't do anything once is a public beach.

5 star resorts really doesn't get much worse than this. The rooms are antiquated. Food is terrible. The poor dolphins have been making money for them for decades. You really feel like you travel back in time when quality has a different definition.

My family and I spent several days at the Kehala. It is a beautiful property and the staff is so well-trained, warm and friendly incredibly helpful. If feels like a classic mid century modern hotel. Terrific beach, great food, gym, and In a quiet residential area that is perfect for jogging or hiking Diamond Head. Paradise!
user_name:
Groverprach
New York City, New York

review_body: I came to Kahala to get away. My room faced out to the ocean, so my first thought was how beautiful it was until I noticed the pool down below. Within the small tank were several dolphins swimming in circles looking bored and disillusioned. I did not want this to happen yet the view ruined my hopes of relaxing. I could not stop looking at how dirty the tiny pool was in comparison to the vastness of their neighbor, the ocean. I hope the Kahala resort loses the dolphins in captivity; this aspect of their resort is a game changer when it could be a much better place.

I love the hotel! It's been many years since I last last there but it is still just as wonderful. The staff was so gracious and made me feel at home. The standard room we had was spacious and nicely appointed and very clean. Though I am sorry one of my favorite restaurants at the hotel, Hoku, was undergoing renovations I thoroughly enjoyed the Italian restaurant and the breakfast buffet in the Plumeria room was perfect. We took advantage of the hotel shuttle service into Waikiki - super easy

We stayed here as part of our honeymoon. Its tucked away from crowded Honolulu hotel zone yet not too far away. We were able to enjoy quiet/private beach then took an advantage of free shuttle to Waikiki in the afternoon for some shopping and dining. Our room (oceanfront) had a great view of ocean and hotel grounds. This is a historic hotel with rich, antique feels to it. Hotel grounds were well kept and breakfast buffet by the ocean was well worth the money. A Pool was rather small, crowded, and noisy with kids running around all the time. They have few cabanas and beach loungers with cover for rent as a secondary option. I felt that the rental price for cabanas and lounge chairs was little over-priced.Although this was a good hotel, we were disappointed by lack of good quality customer service. We stayed at two different resorts during our honeymoon- Kahala and Four Seasons Ohau. When making both reservations, my husband had indicated that it was for our honeymoon. Kahala was not aware of this at all until we had let them know during our check in; whereas Four season had our room prepped with champagne/chocolates and a hand written card from general manager. A front desk agent then offered a bottle of champagne which didn't happen until my husband called in to check on it on the second day.. In overall we had a good stay but nothing too WOW about this resort. For the amenities and services, we would have been better off staying only in Four Seasons.

After carefully looking into a number of great locations, in the US and Europe, to celebrate our 50th Anniversary, we selected The Kahala Hotel & Resort. I will tell you that without a doubt, this was the best decision we could have ever made. The beauty and elegance of the hotel, the breathtaking views from our hotel room, and the attentive staff at the hotel guaranteed that we would have a most pleasurable and enjoyable experience.The Kahala Hotel & Resort is trully unforgettable.

Below is my review of different aspects of the resort:1)Room: simply gorgeous. Beautifully decorated, large with a sitting area and a desk area. Bed is extremely comfortable and wonderful to sleep in. Loved the bathroom as well, also quite large, with a large tub and separate large shower area. Two sinks, one on each end, as a his and hers which was also great. Pay the extra money for the ocean view and also for a balcony, it's worth it 2) all inclusive breakfast: very good, large selection with lots of hot options, cereal options, fruit options, bread options, and yogurts. There is a guy who makes inlets and waffles to order. Make sure you try and get it included into your room package as otherwise it's 92 bucks a day for two people. We usually went around 7am and never waited for a seat; servers however were sometimes slow with bringing coffee and were consistently slow about bringing us the check(you had to sign the check even when it's included in your room package)3) Beach: soft sand, very calm and warm waters. Good place for young children. Hammocks available on the beach. There's a sandbar so you can go out far and still stand. There's also a reef to snorkel but didn't see too many fish. Can walk on the right side on the beach for a while which is nice. They have cabanas and also lounge chairs with sun covers on the back of them attached which both cost money, 65 per day for chairs with covers and over 100 for the cabanas per day. I expected the cabanas to cost money but I didn't expect the lounge chairs with covers to cost money as it didn't cost money for the same type of chair when we stayed at a resort on the big island. This made me grumpy as I get easily sunburned. Luckily, there's a large tree on the middle of the property which I was able to drag the lounge chairs which did not have covers and thus were free under each day. This tree provided great shade, but routinely dropped small flowers on us (and I had to pick out of my hair) and also we had birds poop on our lounge chairs twice. Resort provides chair towels and beach towels at no cost which is nice and of good quality 4) Pool: warm water, reasonable size, only goes about 4.5 deep. One small kiddie pool. One hot tub. Always crowded and noisy with lots of children, they needed more pool space with the size of the hotel. Chairs at the side of the pool at times can be hard to come by 5) Dolphins: I'm conflicted about this. I liked watching the dolphins and think this is very unique to have on a resort. They also offered dolphin experiences to those willing to pay. Dolphins seemed well taken care of. However, I'm conflicted because I'm starting to become against keeping such beautiful and intelligent animals in captivity 6) Lunch: we ate at the beach side open air cafe which had a large menu. I consistently ate off the kids menu which they let me do because I'm picky and like those portion sizes better. Lunch was around 32 bucks daily for two people not including tip7) location: it is true that it is out of the main city where most hotels are. It is true that it's close to attractions in the city, Pearl Harbor is about 30 minutes, dole is 40 minutes, Waimea bay is 25 minutes. Close to lots of restaurants and even a mall. However, it's very much suburbs and it takes away from the resort tropical island feel. It's a very different setting from Maui or the big island where you feel removed from it all. This bothered my husband and I more then expected, we really wanted the tropical island away from it all vacation- if this is want you want, I would recommend trying the turtle beach resort instead 8) Random: service was good. Beautiful entrance into the hotel. They offer free photo session but we didn't do it because of the weather the week we stayed. Parking is expensive but equivalent to any other resort on the island. Construction closed down half the gym while we're were there which irritated my husband- small gym only one piece of equipment per type such as treadmill and rapidly became crowded even with only five people in the room. No nightly activities/entertainment offered that we were aware of.

My husband and 4 year old son spent time at the Kahala from 11th through the 17- I can say that this was one of the most spectacular vacations we’ve had, thanks to the hotel. From the views , to the decor to the incredible staff ( my son was in love with Ying at front desk who gifted him a stuffed dolphin) our experience was incredibleCheck in was wonderful- the close proximity to the city was great- we felt detached from the craziness of Waikiki without being isolated. For 4 days we toured the island, and for 2 days spent it on the beach and pool. We rented a cabana for $165 which was well worth it- we put the 2 chairs with a small deck chair and we all slept outdoors with the cool sea breezeThe food was incredible- fresh and the buffet was delicious. What I appreciated was the mock tail list ( I’m 4 months preggers) so the fact I could have delicious drinks made me feel like I was on holiday modeI usually want to leave after a few days away from home - this time I really had problems getting on the plane- my son actually cried on the way to the airport since he didn’t want to head out. There is something magical about Hawaii and especially about the KahalaMahalo to the wonderful team and staffNow- planning next Years vacation already!!

The Kahala Hotel is a gorgeous luxury hotel hidden away from much of the busy crowds found in Waikiki or other popular tourist locations on Oahu. The decor is undeniably Pacific, but purposefully understated... think luminous natural woods and gently colorful beach glass, and you get a sense of the style of the lobby. The staff are amazing, attentive and helpful without being overbearing. The restaurant serves a stellar weekend brunch, and in general the food is delicious. We have visited several times and loved it each time. The beach is sandy and calm, which makes it wonderful for sunbathing and swimming with children. The grounds are gorgeously landscaped and one of the highlights is the lagoon and waterfall that have a variety of sea life living in them.

So one reason I picked this hotel is that it is away from the hustle and bustle of Waikïkï. So keep in mind it is harder to stay here if you want to be in Waikïkï a lot. If you would rather stay on property or you are renting a car anyway, then this place is good.The staff is super friendly. Check in was smooth. My favorite thing was the concierge will communicate with you by text message if you want! This worked well for me since that is my easiest mode of communication!The hotel room was lovely. My only complaint was that due to a window above our bed, it was hard to Black out the whole room for a mid-day nap. The bath products provided were nice and not super perfumed which is good. The rooms had a safe and a fridge which was stocked w bottled water.If you are a runner, it is easy enough to run nearby. The front desk will give you water and a running map if needed.Although the rooms have a Keurig, there is also complimentary coffee on the ground floor in the mornings.We did the breakfast inclusive option and the buffet at Plumeria House was amazing! So many things to choose from like omelets to waffles w coconut syrup to miso soup as well as salad and dumplings. The fruit bar was also wonderful. Different juices every day.Lastly, I’ve done dolphin swimming a few times so we didn’t do it here but you could still watch the dolphins which was nice and fun! Oh and the beach was super calm without big waves. Saw some people doing SUP yoga and looked not too bad since almost no waves. Probably a good beach for kids that way.

John Milton's 11th. book of poetry would have been his best had he the opportunity to spend a week or two at the Kahala. This hotel and it's staff are what make this resort absolutely first class. You are surrounded by beauty every where you look and the restaurants, salon and spa prevent you from ever wanting to leave. Aloha!

Hi! I am a luxury travel agent and have worked with 5-star hotels all over Hawaii. I just wanted to write in how excellent the concierge team has been on several recent client itineraries....they really go above and beyond!

ザ・カハラホテル＆リゾートにできた日本の老舗美容室。東京銀座で、100年以上の歴史をもつHatsuko EndoA venerable beauty salon in Japan has opened at The Kahala Hotel ＆ Resort. 「Hatsuko Endo」The beauty salon with a history of over 100 years at Tokyo, Ginza.日本に戻るフライト前に行ってきました。

The Kahala is tucked away from the overwhelming crowds at other hotels in Honolulu as well as in many of the major hotels on the other islands. The hotel boasts old style charm, the lobby is beautifully furnished, all the staff are professional and gracious, and the rooms have a feeling of warmth and comfort. It's lovely to sit on one's balcony and enjoy morning coffee while overlooking the ocean and beach as well as the dolphins playing in the pool (assuming you get a room with an ocean view), or in the evenings watching the sunset with a glass of wine. The beach is beautiful and uncrowded; often you get to enjoy a fabulous wedding of a beautiful Japanese couple with their family. The buffet breakfasts are sumptuous with awesome fresh fruit and tropical juices. The concierge staff are all gracious, professional, and accessible -- one of the lovely concierge's helped us with our plans daily and was often willing to refresh our leis -- Susan was wonderful!!!! The hotel registration staff was also pleasant and accommodating. I'm so happy we took the concierge's advice to hire a private sedan for airport transportation! A shuttle bus takes you into Waikiki for shopping and dining throughout the day (so very appreciated!!!!). I chose the Kahala as a special vacation destination to take my sister there for her first trip to Hawaii. She was overwhelmed with the entire experience, and I'm so happy I chose The Kahala to share Hawaii with her. This was my 3rd visit and I'll always go back when staying in Oahu!

We stayed at the Kahala for a medical conference. The resort is beautiful without being over the top. The staff was excellent, courteous and attentive. The rooms were large and comfortable. There is a lot of history at this resort but it does not overwhelm you with its luxury or size. It is expensive. There is a small pool and the beach is just a few yards away. The ocean water is nice and calm due to the reef offshore, perfect for paddle boarding or swimming. There are several restaurants but no easy grab and go option for breakfast or lunch. We enjoyed our stay but wished there were easier options for breakfast other than the main restaurant. I would stay here again.
user_name:
H Daniel Z
Portland, Oregon, United States

review_body: We travelled here for our honeymoon for a couple of nights in Honolulu before our cruise around the South Pacific. The checkin staff were a little curt and even though they knew it was our honeymoon, we didn't get any sort of acknowledgement. Pretty poor really. The room we paid for cost a small fortune and didn't even include breakfast (we found this out when we got there). It didn't even occur to us that breakfast wouldn't be included for a £650 a night hotel. Our fault for not double checking though. In the hotel's defence, they did give us free breakfast for the two mornings we were there, so in the end I guess it was a nice thing to do.The room was stunning - again it was the room we paid for, but we were really disappointed not to get an upgrade, especially as the hotel was not sold out. The first morning we were there, my lovely hubby jumped downstairs to reserve a cabana on the beach. He was charged $100 by a member of staff from The Khahala. When we came back to our room and told me what happened I lost the plot! Number one, we didn't realise that they charge you money to sit on the flaming beach if you want an umbrella in Honolulu, but $100 for the cabana?! Eh no! Turns out that it was half that price to reserve one and the member of staff had pocketed the money. I'm sure you can imagine we were furious with the hotel and arguing with members of management on the first day of our honeymoon was not the start we were looking for. We got our money back but seriously saddened that this happened to us. From that moment on we had a pretty sour taste in our mouths about the hotel. While there we made the best of it, but I would not recommend staying there.Another thing: The dolphin pool is shockingly small. As a massive animal lover this should be shut down. You'll see how small it is when you get there. The pool for humans is the smallest hotel pool I've ever seen (hmm is that so you go and sit at the beach to get conned out of $100?). Not impressive.The hotel is tired in areas and needs a bit of a facelift. I would not return to this hotel.

We had the pleasure of staying at the Kahala Resort for two nights, with one of those nights being our wedding night. We actually got married at the beach right outside of the resort. We were having a hectic and stressful day, but the moment we checked in, Gina made everything amazing for us. She really took great care of us and we are so appreciative of her! Kahala is lucky to have her. Everything about our stay was magical. Really felt like paradise between the incredible beach, beautiful amenities inside and out and amazing staff. I can’t wait to stay here again (hoping for a future anniversary trip!)

Kahala Hotel is unique for at least two reasons. It is in Honolulu, but away from Waikiki. Unless you are looking for a city Hawaii vacation, the Kahala is the only great hotel near enough to Honolulu to enjoy the great food and shopping Waikiki has to offer, but far enough away to avoid the hustle and bustle. There's good news and bad news in this. The bad news is a taxi or Uber ride into downtown Waikiki will set you back $35 each way. The hotel offers a shuttle into Waikiki, but inexplicably, this bus is in pretty bad shape. Tip - Stay in the front at all costs. The rear axle may fall off at any moment.The other unique thing about Kahala is its Dolphin Lagoon. The hotel has 6 of the friendliest, most entertaining dolphins anywhere. Book a Dolphin Lagoon room and you will be endlessly entertained by these beautiful animals. Here's another tip - make sure you're not booked into 1206 or 1207. If you are, you will be looking partly at Dolphins, but mostly at the back side of the hotel's tower. When I requested a room change, I was only offered an ocean front room for $100 more per night.There were other issues which prevent me from otherwise endorsing this Hotel. There is construction going on outside the Plumeria Restaurant, which is the indoor/outdoor restaurant where a beautiful and included breakfast buffet is served daily. Why this construction is not scheduled after the buffet hours is inexplicable. During our stay, each morning we were greeted with a view of construction workers and not the Pacific Ocean, along with the attendant noise.Equally hard to explain is that the hotel offers comfortable lounge chairs and umbrellas pool side, but a few steps away on the beach, the lounge chairs are free, but the same umbrella costs $30/per hour. The beach itself is beautiful and faces west towards the sunset. If you want a beautiful view (and I mean really beautiful), but not a sun tan, this view is unavailable without significant additional cost.

Stayed here for two nights with my family (first of three hotels on a 10-day Hawaii trip). We had an Ocean Front Lanai and three teenage sons had a Scenic View room. This is a beautiful, classic property that is completely opposite of the Waikiki experience (which is only 10-15 minutes away if you want night life/shopping etc.). The rooms were larger than we expected and well-appointed. We were on the 10th floor (after originally being given a room on the second floor, which the front desk smartly fixed) in the Koko Head wing and had an amazing view, as well good size bathrooms/plenty of closet space/separate vanities/tub/shower. The balcony was quite large. The boys' room was on the other side but had a large (man-made) waterfall view that was cool.The pool area is on the small side, but the beach is quite large and water is calm/not rocky (the teenagers particularly enjoyed swimming out to the floating dock). We didn't hang out there for a meaningful amount of time so can't comment on pool/beach service, but the tiki bar wasn't overwhelmingly busy. There is a Dolphin Quest facility on the property, right next to the pool area, which we didn't experience but was great to watch them feeding or a show. There are also sea turtles and many other fish species swimming in the other ponds. The main restaurant Hokus was closed for renovation but we all really enjoyed Arancino also on property (good wine list). Plumeria was fine for breakfast, but got busy after 7:30 or 8:00a.The gym was standard fare, nothing to write home about but fine. There's a nice run along the main road (beautiful neighborhood) up to Diamond Head and the old lighthouse though. Never made it to the spa.

We went to the Kahala based on word of mouth but were very disappointed. From the first day we checked in we were disappointed. The reservation/front desk staff were unhelpful - not willing to guarantee us a connecting room when we were travelling with our 2 young children. There was a 20 min wait for breakfast on the weekend and the place was like a zoo with building works happening right in front of the breakfast venue not what you would expect from an upmarket hotel. We thought the resort facilities would be great so close to Waikiki but golf is not available on site as it is a private club, tennis was not simple to book either being part of the club. The place is tired and is nowhere near the top hotels on Waikiki as far as service, location or amenities go. If you are looking for resort facilities you would not drive past Ko Olina to get to the Kahala, it may be worth a day trip for dolphin quest but that's about it.

We stayed for 4 nights at the Kahala resort on a family vacation and really enjoyed it! The hotel facilities have an old-world charm to them and the service was impeccable. The hotel is located at the end of an upscale, high end neighborhood, about 15 min drive outside of Waikiki. It's not really walking distance to anything, so you'd need transportation (rental car or Uber) if you want to get around. It is situated in a quiet, protected beach, with lots of beachfront access, easy swimming, and good stand-up paddle space. There is a tower with ocean front and garden view rooms, a smaller building with a view of an internal lagoon, and a few rooms right in front of the ocean.The lagoon inside the hotel is home to 6 male dolphins in an operation managed by Dolphin Quest Oahu. I have mixed feelings about having these animals in captivity. But, as a tourist, it was great entertainment to watch their daily shows, feedings, and trainings. Other quick points about the hotel:Pros:- Great service from check in to check out (I love it that they still offer 3PM check and noon check out!)- Nice restaurant for breakfast buffet right in front of the beach- Pool attendants were always available and willing to help. Chairs were not too hard to find in the middle of the day- Quick valet service- Daily housekeeping and turn down service- Spacious room with great view- We had some problems with check in that were quickly addressed. We later received a handwritten apology note from the front desk manager - well done!Cons:- Family rooms have 2 double beds (rather than queen beds)- Small pool- The hotel was built in 1964 and, while updated in many ways, there are still some items that feel original, like the painted wood cabinets in the bathroomAll said, this was a lovely way to end a Hawaiian vacation and we highly recommend the property.

Went for friday nite and Saturday morning brunch. Wow. Amazing choices for both meals. Also went to the veranda bar for Saturday dinner. All i can say is it was an all around fabulous experience. Staff treat you like family, everyone that i met that works there went above and beyond. The experience was not free..but worth every penny. Hopefully will make it back!

My wife and I enjoyed a Sunday brunch on Feb 18, 2018. With drinks and a tip the total bill was $175.00. I would have GLADLY paid more! Service, food and the scenic view are unmatched anywhere else we ate on this trip. My only regret is we do not have a restaurant of this caliber in Fredericksburg, VA! Guaranteed we will eat here the next year when we come back to Hawaii. Aloha!

We choose The Kahala because Waikiki looks like our idea of hell...but we wanted a resort experience in HNL, convenient to the Pearl Harbor sites. The Kahala is exceptional in every way. The staff is warm, inviting and 100% professional. When the desk clerk heard we were celebrating our 30th anniversary, she immediately upgraded our room to the top floor, ocean view and sent a bottle of champagne. Anything that needed was immediately provided. I don't believe we heard 'no' once. We had all of our meals at the resort...all were very good, some were exceptional. The breakfast buffet is great...it includes everything and if you book appropriately, you can get breakfast included so you don't feel bad about the price vs what you may want to eat. The room was lovely, spacious and very well appointed. I visited the spa - which was first rate. We did a little shopping and found the staff helpful and the prices not unreasonable for hotel shop0s. The hotel itself is quite lovely. Some reviews have mentioned that it appears 'faded' from it's original glory. We did not feel that at all...in fact, she has a beautiful patina that we felt was critical to our enjoyment of the resort. The beach is beautiful and, on our visit, not at all crowded. The resort is large enough and varied enough to provide full service without making you feel that you are in a busy bustle. We will not hesitate to book here on another trip to Honolulu. My only caution is that I would not book here unless we were planning to spend our time in HNL. The HNL traffic is not good and although the Kahala is very well located, it's impossible to reach any of the historic sites, whale-watching, Waikiki or downtown area attractions without spending 30-45 minutes in traffic. We will stay outside of HNL if we are not planning to be IN HNL. Love the Kahala, it's energy, it's spirit and it's people. Thank you for a beautiful stay.
user_name:
Donna Lynn H
East Haddam, Connecticut

review_body: This was our second time to the Kahala and we enjoyed it immensely. We had a ground level dolphin lanai room again which was nicely appointed like our last stay. We utilized room service service several times for breakfast and evening dessert and the food was always the appropriate temperature and delivered promptly. The grounds are well kept and service is top notch everywhere you go. We splurged on the romance package at the spa this time and it was worth every penny being pampered for nearly 4 hours. We were definitely able to relax like we were hoping to do. If you are looking for a quiet hotel stay then this hotel should surely do it since it is away from Honolulu near a residential neighborhood.

We had a beautiful scenic room with balcony and had fun watching the golfers below. The room was very warm and spacious. Wonderful staff and dolphins and turtles a bonus! Highly recommend this wonderful resort and staff.Mike & Randa

The entire stay was like living in a dream. From beginning to end it was just magical from the gorgeous and spacious room with ocean view over the delicious food in the restaurant and the dolphin marina. Most importantly is the staff who have been going above and beyond to make you feel special. I met one of their incredibly inspiring leaders named Tim Lee. He was the most caring and kindest person I have met in my travels. A true and passionate hotelier! The team around him loves him and I fully understand the reason. I hope he will be there for a long time and I cannot wait to return soon.

We have stayed here twice--once with kids and once just my wife and I. We love the islands of Hawaii, including Oahu, but prefer to stay away from crowded Waikiki. The Kahala sits by itself in a more residential neighborhood about twenty minutes from Waikiki. We booked via Costco Travel and got a good deal on a suite with an ocean vie. Reception was typical of nice resorts in Hawaii--"relax, have a smoothie, here is a flower lei." It works well. The rooms are large and comfortable. The ocean view suites look straight out on the shades of blue from the beach to the reef and the horizon. The beach is private and easy for kids--gentle slope with a protected reef. I was able to swim open water inside the reef. I love breakfast and the buffet here is one of my favorites in the world--lots of fresh fruit, great bread, Japanese and Chinese items and made to order omlettes. The service is attentive and high class. If you want to see the sights of Oahu but pass on the bustle of Waikiki, this is an excellent alternative.

Simply put, my wife and I felt we made the right choice in staying at the Kahala for a weeklong babymoon recently. We tend to like quieter settings and to alternate between sightseeing days and lazy beach lounging days.Some specific impressions:We felt warmly welcomed and cared for by all the staff, from Noel who checked us in and found us a room away from the elevator to Kei (? spelling) who helped us load our car as we checked out. The couple times we called for assistance, the response was rapid and handled expertly and cheerfully (even when we didn't realize that the A/C was not broken, but designed not to operate when the door to the balcony was open :) ).We enjoyed breakfast at the Plumeria House each day, and also had a dinner at least once at Plumeria House, Hoku's and Arancino. We enjoyed the creative menu at Arancino the best.We enjoyed the easy beach access tremendously. The beach was clean and the waters were calm. The service to assist with cabana rentals/towels etc. was friendly and helpful. There is a small group of fish that hang out under the raft off of the beach; we also saw a large sea robin in the water.All in all, we felt our trip was a fantastic experience and that The Kahala provided excellent value for a couple looking for a luxurious, relaxing babymoon.

From your greeting upon entering the hotel to departure, this was a quality experience. Staff is friendly and goes out of their way to please. Our room was an ocean view lanai also over one of the dolphin pools. The views were spectacular. The grounds contain not only dolphin areas, but areas with sea turtles and exotic fish. It has a relaxing atmosphere and is a great property. While it is about 15 minutes from Waikiki, there are shuttles there and we took Uber and Lyft for excursions. I would definitely return here; no question.

This property knows the meaning of luxury. From the lobby to the rooms to the beach they maintain a very high standard. We felt like pampered guests and were very well taken care of. The beach is wonderful, quiet and sedate. There's a floating dock to swim out to for fun. The beach chairs fill up quickly so get down there early to reserve a couple of them. The beautiful pool tends to fill up with kids but it's really nice to jump in after being in the ocean; rinse of first please!Riu Morimoto deserves a shout out for going above and beyond for handling any issues that arose during our stay.The only downside was Hoku's; we felt it didn't match the high standard of the rest of the resort.The breakfast buffet at Plumeria Beach House is highly recommended to start the day. There's a wide selection of items that everybody enjoyed. (I love those sticky buns too much!)We were a party of eleven people spread over 6 rooms.

カメラマンの方がとても気さくで、楽しく撮影して頂けました。 ホテル近くのベストスポットで家族三人でパシャリ。一歳の子供とのはじめての家族写真だったので、最高の思い出になりました。写真の光の入り方も気に入っています。ぜひカバラリゾートに来た時は利用してみてください。The photographer was more friendly and pleasantly photographed. The shooting spot was the best spot near the hotel. It was our first family photo with one year son so it was our best memories. I also like how to enter the light of the photograph.Please come and visit there when you come to Kahala Resort.

The Kahala was our final destination and it was a wonderful finale to an awesome family holiday. The staff are excellent - welcoming, friendly and respectful. Our ocean front room was fantastic and we enjoyed relaxing on the balcony watching the sunrise/sunsets over the ocean. The highlight are the Dolphins, turtles, stingrays and many colourful fish - which are all on the grounds of the resort. We really loved swimming with the Dolphins. The ocean is so beautiful - we relaxed on the private beach - kids loved swimming to the pontoon and canoe and also enjoyed paddle boarding. If you want peace, relaxation and minimal crowds - this is the place for you. Its a short drive to Waikiki and shopping so we get the best of both worlds here. Thankyou Kahala for making our family holiday more awesome ... We will be back !!!

I’m not too sure that I can add to all of the other great reviews of this property. I’ve tried to think of anything negative to say, but I can’t come up with anything. Is it expensive - yes. But you get what you pay for in this case.From the moment we arrived, we were greeted warmly and treated exceptionally well by everyone at the resort. The bellmen, front desk staff, and housekeepers were all outstanding and seemed to willing to do whatever was necessary to make our stay enjoyable. The building and property, even though its about 50 years old, are in very good condition. The lobby is very nicely decorated, open and inviting. The beach and pool areas are immaculate. The pool itself is small and was sometimes crowded. The dolphin pond was large, and it was amazing to be so close to these wonderful animals. Although I am conflicted about the dolphins being in captivity, they are extremely well cared for, fed, and trained.Our room was on the 3rd floor and had a view of the golf course and the peaks beyond. It was very large, with a great lanai outside. The bed was comfortable, it was very clean and had a couch and chair in addition to a desk/chair combo. The bathroom itself was big, although the walk-in shower was rather small. There was also a tub, 2 sinks, 2 closets plus a refrigerator/coffee area. The bathroom was separated from the main area by double doors. The toilet had its own door inside the bathroom, and it had a heated seat and a remote control which performs a myriad of functions that I never figured out.We ate at 3 of the restaurants at the property. We had dinner at Plumeria Beach House twice. The food was excellent, and the service was even better. The waiters were very friendly, talkative and informative about the resort and Hawaii. There was also live music one night that we saw, and it was very enjoyable (I believe there is live music every night but we only saw it once). We also had breakfast here one morning and it was very good. The buffet looked fabulous, but was around $40/person.We had drinks and lunch one day at the Seaside Grill. This is much more causal, with seating right next to the beach. Unfortunately it is not open for dinner which I found disappointing. The food was good, and it was very comfortable. We also had dinner once at Arancino, which is an Italian restaurant at the resort. The food was very good here as well.Several things to be aware of here - you pay extra for almost everything except some of the activities (Paddleboard Yoga, for example, didn’t cost extra). But Rental of a paddleboard for an hour is $30. Rent mask/fins/snorkel - you pay.There is a shuttle that runs from the resort to several areas around Waikiki. Because the timing was never right for us, we never used it. We always took Uber to go anywhere. I was initially concerned that there might be limited availability of Ubers because of the location, but we never waited more than 5 minutes for a ride. It would cost around $13-$15 to get to the middle of Waikiki. Overall the Kahala definitely lived up to its reputation as a 5-star resort. I wouldn’t hesitate to stay here again, and probably will.

We used to stay at this hotel for weekend getaways. It was nice to return after all these years. Definitely brought back a lot of memories. Love the dolphins and the ocean front views. The location is awesome; feels like you are out of the city, but in actuality you aren't too far from civilization. The Plumeria Beach House is a nice setting for dinner right on the beach front, and the food was tasty. Always enjoy going to their Hoku's Restaurant as well.

After 2 weeks in Hawaii - staying at the stunning Mauna Kea resort in the Big Island and the brand new Hyatt Residences in Maui, we ended our trip with 4 nights at the Kahala. Having read all the reviews, I was greatly looking forward to it and expecting something special. We were however very disappointed. Firstly on checkin mid-morning, our room wasnt ready and there was clearly no interest from the front desk person in getting us a room any earlier than than 3 pm “guaranteed” time. But wait, we could offer you an upgrade to a better room if you want access earlier - only another 300 / 400 a night - how about that sir? Oh, on top of the 750+ we’re already paying you mean? No problem trying to upsell me, but then trying to make us look cheap by refusing the new fantastic offer was pretty insulting at these rates. A promise to call us when the room was ready was made, but no call ever came. We eventually went into Waikiki, instead of hanging out for hours in the “hospitality suite”, and returned in the evening, requested our room key and pointed out no one had bothered to contact us to tell us the room was available. Sorry sir. Then throw in the “voluntary” contribution toward regenerating trees or something that they added on by default, the big sell to join LHW which would give us free wifi for our stay (seriously?) and, fair to say, first impressions of the hotel were pretty bad. The room itself was big and comfortable. Relief. Weird setup though with the bar and coffee maker in the bathroom and the hanging closets/drawers in the bathroom too. Room cleaners service was outstanding - very friendly and always left the room Immaculate. Next morning was a 30min wait for breakfast. Oh, you didn’t make a breakfast reservation sir ? We were on to it the next morning though - made a reservation and then watched all the other first day guests wait like we had. Breakfast buffet was pretty good though once we got in. The Italian restaurant onsite (Arancino) was very good, if a bit pricey. The limited shuttle times meant that we gave Uber a pretty serious workout heading backwards and forwards from Waikiki with the kids. As other reviewers have commented, the pool is very small and overrun with kids. Really not up to standard. Biggest gripe though would be the age and condition of the hotel in general - it’s really very old. Needs a total refurb from rooms to facilities. Old furniture, old carpets, old bathrooms, old facilities although is no doubt well maintained for its age. Room sizes and bathroom sizes are great too. Beautiful setting no doubt, lovely feel to it, airy lobby and relaxed vibe, nice staff (except at check in), lovely beach and location etc but....just very old and lack8ng what you would expect at this price. Yes I know all the rich and famous have stayed there but if you look at the wall of photos in the lobby, there are very few from recent years. Says a lot I think. It’s glory days would have been 20 years ago or more. If you want 5 stars (and we did), sorry to say that this ain’t it. Not even close.

We spent eight wonderful days at the Kahala. Beautiful, spacious ocean view room with a huge bathroom—two separate vanities, two closets, a tub and a separate shower, and lots of drawers and shelves. All the staff were gracious and friendly including the front desk personnel, restaurant wait staff and beach and pool attendants. Housekeeping is excellent. This is a quiet resort with an old Hawaii, old Hollywood vibe. The hotel beach is beautiful as well. Make sure to ask for a rate with breakfast included—it’s well worth it! Highly recommended.

My favorite hotel in the world. Been coming here since 1980 and through all the ownerships and different brands, the Kahala has consistently been excellent. Beautiful rooms, great private beach, great food and beverage, and close to Kahala mall.

Sooooo. We came THIS close to booking 10 days here but opted to stay at the Moana Surfrider (lovely, with accommodating staff) and check it out for our next visit. Stopped by this morning to enjoy brunch and explore the grounds—and were told it would be a 45-minute wait for a table. This, on a Wednesday morning when half the tables were empty, and after we explained why we were there. We are not all that demanding but we were utterly stupefied that prospective guests are treated with something bordering on disdain. We will happily cross it off our list and give other resorts our business.

My wife and I stayed at the Kahala for 7 days/6 nights in late January. It was a delight from check-in until our bittersweet check-out. We had a room on the 8th floor which overlooked the golf course below and had good views of Koko Head and the beaches as well. The room was spacious, clean, and had everything you could need. The resort itself has several fine restaurants. Arancino was our favorite, but the Plumeria House was amazing as well. And you have to do the breakfast buffet there. However, we spent most of our time on the beach. It was wonderful. Food and drink were close by at the Seaside Bar and Grill and the beach had excellent lounge chairs and towels. The beach there is very, very calm. You could easily bring very small children there and feel safe with them playing at the shore with you. When we did leave the resort, the shuttle was excellent to the Kahala Mall where there are some decent stores and restaurants that you can grab a meal at. The shuttle also takes you into Waikiki if you like. The service was polite, very accomodating, but very much "as needed" and therefore you weren't overwhelmed by service employees bothering you. All in all, it was a fantastic experience. We hope to return soon.

We celebrated our 40th anniversary in Hawaii along with our children and grandchildren. Our stay at the Kahala was the most luxurious. We all felt like we were treated as royalty. Everyone was accommodating, and helpful every interaction. The views were breathtaking. The grounds were pristine and private. We enjoyed our stay and had wished we had planned a longer stay at this hotel.

We stayed at the Kahala for 8 wonderful nights for our honeymoon. I had done extensive research before planning our trip, hoping to find the perfect place to stay. We found exactly what we were looking for in the Kahala. It is not located among the crowds of Waikiki, but is close enough that you can easily visit on the hotel-provided complimentary shuttle (Our driver Gary was wonderful!). We also looked into staying in the Ko Olina area, but it was more expensive and way too far away from everything for us. We were able to spend a great deal of time relaxing at the resort, plus have adventures in Waikiki. We also rented a car for 2 days so that we could adequately explore the other parts of the island. It was really the perfect balance. We stayed in a Dolphin Lanai room, and I highly recommend this. We used our lanai daily, and were pleasantly surprised to find we not only had a view of the dolphins but also of the ocean. The room was very clean, thanks to our wonderful housekeeping staff member, Lino. I have seen some complaints on here of rooms being out of date and run down. The furniture does have some wear, but everything is spotless and the bed was so comfy! The room and the bathroom were both spacious. Our package included breakfast at the Plumeria Beach House each morning, and this was a great way to start each day. We ate such a wholesome breakfast each day, that we often found we could share a meal for dinner and still be stuffed! This helped cut down on food costs. The beach at the Kahala is beautiful, and you will never have to struggle to find a chair to relax in. After reading other hotel reviews where you have to get up at 7am to find a beach chair before they are all gone, I realized what a luxury it was to not have to worry about this! There are two things I thought of that would have helped enhance our visit. One would be to add some type of ottoman to the lanai furniture, as we would have loved to stretch out more. The other would be to offer some type of happy hour or daily drink special, as all drinks onsite were pretty pricey. These were definitely not things that were “make or break”, but just things we thought of. We will definitely return!

...in a beach vacation. I've travelled the Hawaiian islands for many years and have stayed at many hotels and resorts. Though all of me stays have been great, Each time I was wishing for something that was lacking. Maybe the beach was too rough, or there weren't enough pool lounges, or I had to pay for beach lounges, or it was a little too crowded, or I wasn't happy with the restaurants. Sometimes the hotel was too impersonal, or worse, the hotel was too personal. There was always something that made it not quite perfect.But the Kahala was perfect...at least for me. We stayed 4 days in the dolphin lanai and 4 days n an iceanview lanai in the tower. Both rooms were wonderful and roomy, can't really say which I prefer. There was more light in the tower room, but it was fun to watch the dolphins from the lanai in the other room. The breakfast buffet at the Plumeria is the perfect way to start the day, plenty of fresh fruit, omelets made to order, fantastic Kona coffee, sausages, potatoes, and much more. beach is beautiful and uncrowded, the chaise are free and are cushioned and comfortable. There are plenty of pool lounges too, also cushioned and plenty of umbrellas. The staff is always responsive and accommodates any requests. We also tried Arancino restaurant, it was ok, but perhaps overrated. We used room service a few times and it was just fine. We also took the free shuttle to Waikiki and the Kahala mall for some meals. Another time, we went to Uncle B's in Kapahula and had a delicious, fresh fish meal.If you're looking for a stress-free, relaxing vacation, try the Kahala - you won't be disappointed! I will definitely return. But the Kahala resort provided

We were there at a business conference, which worked nicely for it. Nice rooms; comfortable bed; we had an ocean view with a balcony, and the balcony is a nice plus. Nice bathroom; not large, but nice tub and separate walk-in shower; one sink, refrigerator. You see the back side of Diamond Head, a different profile, and with the mountains in the background, there was pretty much a daily rainbow. Nice swimming beach with calm water, not as clear as Waikiki. Nice pool with ample seating; not the usual rush to get chairs in the AM. Friendly and accomodating staff and housekeeping. Nice Italian restaurant on premises for lunch and dinner: Arancino (see my review); nice outdoor dining at the Sea Grill for light bites on a beach day. And of course the Dolphin pool/show, which is quite different. It's directly next to Waialae Country Club, though no privileges to play golf there. If you're looking for resort laid back, then you'll probably prefer Kahala over Waikiki. The drawback is it takes a lot more time to get an Uber or Lyft, though both are available, and obviously the cost goes up if you're going into Honolulu proper for dinner, sightseeing, etc. So it's really a function of whether you want quiet resort, or the action of Waikiki. One thing we thought could use improvement is a better stocked store for snacks, drinks, espresso, etc, e.g. a Take and Go....nice refrigerator in the room, but you'll have to hit the ABC store to stock it; Keurig in the room, but not espresso, which means room service. There is free coffee during the earlier morning hours down on the LL level. We like the freedom of having some simple breakfast options without doing the room service pricey stuff.

I just spent 5 nights at the Kahala with a group of 6 women. We were worried it would be a little too quiet but it was absolutely perfect in every way.....staff, rooms, beach, food, pool, location was excellent! Waikiki is only 15 min by cab to venture out for shopping and fun. Our rooms were on the mountain side which was very nice and we enjoyed sitting on our lanai watching the 'Sony Open' golf tournament. The only area that I think needs improving is their live entertainment. We all agreed the style of music was a bit dry and too sleepy, lounge like. Perhaps, 1 or 2 days a week they could have music that is slightly more upbeat. Or, an outside area with sports or music with a fun vibe for happy hour. I can't wait to return to the Kahala. I couldn't think of anywhere better to stay on Oahu!

We stayed at this hotel for a conference. The hotel was phenomenal. Service was outstanding, and the staff very friendly and accommodating. We had a room on the top floor with a view overlooking the golf course and mountain. I was on a long conference call and happened to look out my room to see an incredible rainbow right outside! One of the most gorgeous features (and there are many) is the orchid wall - a staircase connects the lobby to the lower lobby, and the wall has been planted with an incredible collection of exotic orchids. Just stunning.The lobby area is really quite breathtaking. The restaurants were all top-notch. The hotel also features neat little lagoons stocked with colourful reef fish, a sting ray, two sea turtles, and, of course, dolphins. The beach and ocean cove are lovely and very kid friendly - even with gusting winds, the waves were calm and kid-safe. The water off the beach is very very shallow - we went snorkelling out to the wave break and the water wasn't much higher than 2 or 3 feet. The snorkelling off the beach is just "meh" for more avid snorkellers, but it would be a good, safe intro for kids or less confident swimmers.The drinks and pool/beach-side restaurant are particularly excellent - drinks were never far away while out relaxing in the sun, and the fish tacos are 10/10.The business centre was also very helpful - I was able to print some documents and have them scanned seamlessly and with assistance from very friendly staff. Staff also made arrangements to courier the materials via FedEx. It was an easy place to get work done (even when I'd rather be at the beach).The room was great - we were late arrivals and the hotel was jammed for the conference, so we had two double beds, but there was a double his/her vanity on either side of the bathroom, a giant shower and soaking tub, and plenty of storage. Guests are greeted with beautiful orchid Leis on arrival, which add a wonderful sense of occasion. I travel extensively for work, and this hotel experience was truly top-notch.
