The room/bathroom was lovely and larger than typical hotel rooms and it was great having a lanai to sit & drink our coffee even though our room faced away from the ocean. I told my husband that I wished we had spent our whole vacation here instead of hopping over to Maui. This is true relaxation!

My travel agent recommended this hotel. Perect choice for a first timer. Secluded yet super close to the Waikiki action. Golf course feels like it's "on property". Gloria, in concierge, is attentive and tailored our personality with the the right tours and tour guide. Hotel has wonderful good choices and ammenities. Spa is rather expensive, however good alternatives in Waikiki. Will definitely stay here again, especially since a regular room is super sized at 512 square feet.

From the moment we arrived we had the best and friendliest service. Everything was clean, beautiful, and comfortable. Every person was kind and accommodating to every need in a fast and organized way!

Diamond Head has not moved in 42 years nor has the structure of the hotel been gutted. When making reservations, I tried to book the same view we had on our honeymoon 42 years ago. The room and view had been beautiful then. Cost was not a consideration. Amex travel could not get a straight answer from hotel, nor could I. I was informed that the hotel had been completely reconfigured and so could not pinpoint view. NOTE: HOTEL IS SAME, REFURNISHED BUT IN NEED OF FURTHER REFURBISHING. I booked Mountainview and was told it was overlooking Diamondhead. Upon checking in, once again asked about view. Was told could see from balcony. Bottom line, we had to go to end of hall to take pictures of sun setting over Diamondhead. Front desk could have cared less if we were less than happy then or when they refused us a late checkout. There are too many hotels/ resorts today that think customer satisfaction and service are important to recommend anyone stay at the Kahala.

Amazing room overlooking the golf course and the ocean. Very private room. Bed was so comfortable with luxurious pillows. Exceptional staff, who were always friendly and went out of their way to accommodate everything you need. Food was 5 star. The beach was maintained to a high standard. Pool was sparkling clean. A great way to spend time watching the dolphins and turtles swim passed.Would stay here any chance I could.

We were looking for a hotel away from the crowds of the beach and found the perfect fit. The Kahala was excellent. The staff was very friendly and helpful. When we were going out in the morning, they made sure we had directions for where we were going and asked if we needed water bottles. Far enough away from the crowds, but close enough to be convenient. There is a shopping mall about 5 minutes away and there was a Whole Foods where you could get take food for picnics or a quick breakfast before exploring for the day. The restaurants on site were excellent . The morning buffet had lots of variety of hot and cold with plenty of fruit etc. The evening lounge served a reduced dinner menu if you wanted something lighter and had live entertainment. Would definitely return

We had a wonderful stay at the Kahala. The staff was very friendly; our room was tastefully decorated. The bathroom was very large with a bathtub, separate shower stall, and two separate vanities, the usual amenities including robes and slippers. Early morning coffee is available and free from 5:30am-8:00am in the lower lobby. The hospitality center also offers free coffee and bottled water throughout the day.There is also a keurig coffee maker in the room. Parking is available at $32 per day. In my opinion, it should be free.We had breakfast included in our package. The buffet was wonderful, expensive, but tasty. We did not rent the cabanas ($135 per day). When they weren't in use, we used them. The resort is expensive, but great!

We've been going to Kahala for the last 20 some years with n without our children. We've tried many other hotelsIn Honolulu and always came to a conclusion that this is the besthotel in Honolulu. Their beach is private and unlike all the hustle n bustle of Waikiki beach, one can relax and truly enjoy the ocean.It is about 20 min. taxi ride from Waikiki n alamona shopping mallbut they have shuttle servicesall day long. So what we usually do is spend the in the ocean andtake the shuttle out to Waikiki orAlamoana for the shops and theReataurants are usually open til very late. The rooms are very spacious and attractive.Their breakfast buffet is great and poolside snacks are good too. Anyway, if you want to really relax and enjoy your vacation in a luxurious yet comfortable setting, this is it.I recomment it highly.

My wife and I stayed at the Kahala Resor for the first time last week and it exceeded expectations in every aspect. The staff was attentive, but not invasive. The room was spotless and very comfortable. We spent a lot of time on the beach and visiting the dolphins. The breakfast each morning was delicious and a great way to start the day with the palm trees and ocean as the backdrop. We were so impressed, we were planning our next visit on the plane ride home.

The hotel itself is a mixed bag....The good: Rooms are spacious and comfortable. Restaurants excellent. Beach beautiful. Adequate chaises. Service excellent everywhere - and staff totally obliging.The bad: Carpeting is beginning to look worn and stained. Chair covers for beach chaises are raveled, some stained, need replacing. You cannot go in ocean beyond about waist level without hitting a wall of rocks -- not conducive to swimming. Inadequate shade at beach. Need palapas or umbrellas. You have to pay extra for chaise lounges with a shade hood -- I resent that at the prices we paid for this resort. Also, the free chaises were pretty worn, pads stained. Pool ordinary and not very big. It also bothered me that they have sea turtles and dolphins in captivity in small ponds on the premises.While we had a lovely time, I don't think we will return.

My husband and I traveled to Hawaii with another couple to celebrate our wedding anniversary. When we arrived, we were greeted with beautiful leis, and then, when we checked in, they upgraded us and our friends for our anniversary. When we arrived in our room there was a complimentary bottle of champagne as well. We couldn't say enough about the staff or the resort. We were pampered to the max. We also loved the resort grounds. The views were breathtaking, it was quiet and relaxing, and we loved the lagoon that wrapped around the pool area. The beach was always well-maintained with super soft sand and the ocean was amazing with crystal clear water.

I had the pleasure of staying at Kahala for 6 nights this past September. We really enjoyed our time at Kahala while vacationing on the South Shore of Oahu. So glad that we decided to spend the extra money and stay here. We enjoyed the scenic lanai room during our stay. Although we didn't have a view of the ocean, the picturesque mountain view and beautiful golf course were a treat to take in. We purchased the daily breakfast buffet with our room. I must say that the breakfast buffet was a great way to start the day. The offerings each day were great - everything from an omlette station to miso soup and everything in between. I especially loved the fresh fruit. I'd read mixed reviews about long wait times for the breakfast buffet but we did not experience long wait times, maybe because we visited in September when it's not so crowded.The hotel offers a shuttle to Waikiki (2 different stops) as well as a stop at the Kahala Mall where there is a Whole Foods among many other stores. The shuttle service was perfect - we were able to enjoy the hustle and bustle of the Waikiki area and all that it has to offer for tourists and then return to the calmer Kahala area for real R&R.I would definitely recommend Kahala to anyone planning a visit to Oahu and wants to enjoy the touristy side of Waikiki by just having a short drive from the serene Kahala area. I would stay here again.

we had a great experience staying at the kahala resort. the room was spacious which was great for our 2.5 yr old. they provided a nice crib and the breakfast buffet was delicious. the highlight of our stay was our complimentary photo session with pacific dream photography. we weren't sure what to expect and when we saw our photos we were very pleased. julia presented it to us in a slideshow format and was very patient as we selected our favorites. there was no pressure to purchase and we would definitely recommend this experience to any who stays at the hotel. great memory to have forever.

We spent the weekend at the Kahala for a family wedding. Was impressed with the stately, but comfy lobby area. The staff from the valets to desk clerks to beach attendants were all smiling, helpful and pleasant. There were so many unique touches to the décor: orchids, the hula girls in the elevators, hanging quilts, simple, cool bed linens. The views from any part of the hotel were breath-taking. The food (wedding reception and Sunday brunch) was some of the best food ever! Do not diet here!The Toto toilet was also quite the conversation piece. Clean, calm, relaxing, beautiful island vistas with great staff. I enjoyed the spa, as well as, paddleboarding on a calm ocean. Well worth the splurge to stay here.

I had quite an adventure there getting back spasms but they helped me every step of the day, brought me ice, fixed up my bedroom and simpy made me feel comfortable the entire time I was there.. I can not say enought about this incredible hotel.
user_name:
Daniel K
Phoenix, Arizona, United States

review_body: My husband and I had a wonderful trip to The Kahala, we stayed in a room that walked right out to the dolphin lagoon and it was amazing. Day and night the dolphins were right outside of our room. We were welcomed with a very pretty flower necklace and a cold towel to refresh ourselves from our travels. The front desk staff were very friendly and helpful. They certainly made us feel welcome and special. We enjoyed the welcome gift of chocolate covered nuts upon getting to our room and turn down service at night. The entire hotel just smelled really nice as well. We had the breakfast buffet and it was good, the options could have been larger for the amount of money spent on the buffet, but it is right by the water and you have a beautiful view while eating breakfast. This place was a little pricey for what we normally spend but defiantly felt that it was worth the money. The only drawback for me was the fact that there was too many kids. This is a very nice hotel, my husband and I were very surprised at the amount of small children there were running around.

I'm the type of person that always looks at the "poor reviews" before making a decision just to see if there is something I may not be able to live with. I almost did not book the Kahala based on someone saying their room was moldy smelling. I am so glad I ignored it and decided to book anyway. The hotel is beautiful, our room was bright, clean and smelled wonderful! No mold or musty smell what so ever. I wish we didn't bother with a couple of nights in Waikiki and spent the entire time at the Kahala. There is so much to do, bike, tennis, snorkel, etc. We enjoyed it all. Everyone was friendly and welcoming. The location is perfect. Sitting and watching the sunset and surfers was just so relaxing. I would highly recommend this hotel.
user_location: North Kingstown, Rhode Island, United States
user_name:
Melissa P
North Kingstown, Rhode Island, United States

review_body: We loved this place as compared to anything on Waikiki Beach. It is lovely, very peaceful. The beach is quiet. We were there in mid October. Our school aged kids were some of the very few there. We had a Garden View room which overlooked the golf course and mountains. The view from the windows and lanai was beautiful. I would not spring for full ocean view.This is really a sold 4 star hotel. We were not charged 5 star prices, so overall a good value.They were filming Hawaii-50 there two days during our stay. That got in the way a bit, but was fine and kind of fun to watch.PROS: -Nice rooms (not 5 star but solid 4 star)-Quiet beach-Great location, easy to get to anything if you have a car-Heated toilet seat ;)-Very reasonably priced, especially in October We paid about 350/night. Well worth it.CONS: -Two full beds. Hate not having two queens with two children. A full bed is not big enough for two adults.-I personally hate the dolphin enclosure. Why?-Service was just "fine", definitely not exceptional. We had no "wow" moments.-Pool is small-Beach and pool chairs are poor quality-Charging for an umbrella at the beach...seriously-Poor pool and beach service-Little shade at the beach-Half the days turndown never happenedWe stayed here 6 nights and at Turtle Bay Resort for 3. My wife and I preferred the Kahala while our 10 and 12 year olds preferred Turtle Bay, but only slightly.I will have to return to Oahu for business and Kahala will be my first choice. Again, solid 4 star hotel.

Nice resort with great view from the oceanside rooms. On the negative side: narrow non attractive pool area. Old chairs at the beach, no umbrellas for sun protection. Rental of more comfortable cabanas overpriced.

Absolutely outstanding visit! The hotel is one of the finest in the area. The service is 5-star from check-in to check-out. On-site restaurants are world class, service and fare. The grounds are amazing, beachfront pool, dolphin lagoon, tropical fish ponds.

My wife and I stayed here during a conference at the convention center, rather than stay in the hotels closer along Waikiki. In mid October there are only adults and adults with small children, probably because of school. The hotel was not crowded and it was easy to get beach/pool side lounges at most any time of the day.It is expensive and, as is usual in the high end hotels these days, they charge extra for a cabana on the beach ($115/day) and for shaded lounge chairs on the beach ($40/4h). Drinks and meals are pricey, but that is to be expected as this is not a budget resort. The beach is small but nice. A reef encroaches the swimming area which makes for a long expanse of shallows but a relatively smaller area with sandy bottom. Paddle boarding is a good way to get out on the water, if the wind isn't too high.I was surprised that they have dolphins as well as sea turtles and rays captive in large natural looking pools on the property. If you are into it, you can "swim with the dolphins" in these shallow pools. They are well trained, which some might consider a little sad.The breakfast restaurant overlooks the water and has a very nice buffet for $22/$34 depending on if you want grilled meat or omelettes or more of a continental approach. There is a seating area for afternoon tea (reservations suggested on weekends) and evening drinks. Entertainment is lounge-y and for an older crowd.The rooms are spacious and well appointed. We had a lanai with partial ocean view as did another couple we were with. Our room looked out over the ocean and parking lot, theirs really looked out more over the hillside. Both lanais were noisy with a generator near one and a very loud waterfall near the other. The noise didn't carry over into the room. Unless you are going very high end with full ocean views on a higher floor, I would not recommend spending extra on a lanai. It sounds romantic, but you get better, more peaceful views from seating all over the property.Staff were helpful and friendly as would be expected when paying upwards of $400+ for a room. No one really stood out. The valet service was excellent and quick. My wife participated in the yoga classes on 2 days and enjoyed them.We hiked the nearby Koko crater rail trail. With a rental car, the trip to the convention center was simple and only takes about 15 minutes.

We had an amazing time at the Kahala celebrating our engagement. Our ocean view room was spectacular and very well kept by housekeeping, the beach is beautiful and the amenities are lovely. We were particularly impressed by Pacific Dreams Photography, a complimentary professional photography service that the hotel offers. Before arriving in Hawaii I did some research hoping to find a photographer that might capture this special time in our lives but without any first had recommendations it was hard to make a decision on a company. To find that the Kahala offered this service allowed us to have our photos taken without the financial commitment up front and purchase the photos that we loved individually afterwards. The photographer, Julia, was very talented and we were incredibly impressed with her photos. Lauryn helped us with the selection process and was awesome, as well!Everyone at Dolphin Quest was very informative whenever we had questions and my Dolphin Dip was unforgettable. I do feel 1 or 2 photos should be included with the package rather than charging extra for them.Sean from the Seaside Grill was incredibly attentive and helpful and made our experience unforgettable. We also really enjoyed Anthony "Tony" from the Italian restaurant. We tried all of the restaurants on our stay and were happy with them overall. We did find that it was tacky to "charge for shade" as one of the towel assistants put it. Most of the tents and shaded chairs were empty during the slow season and when you pay $600+ for a room and high prices for drinks and food, it would be nice if they offered beach umbrellas or some option for shade rather than everyone having to huddle under the one tree on the beach where the sand wasn't as nice and it was hard to get service. I also found the shuttle reverse beeping to be disruptive and the beach groomer was quite loud while we were trying to enjoy the sunrise in the morning. Overall we were very happy with the hotel and would recommend it to friends as a high end option in beautiful Honolulu.

My wife and I just returned from a beautiful week at Kahala. We already want to go back. We splurged on an ocean front room and were not disappointed. The rooms are spectacular, the service is five star, and the lobby still takes your breath away when you first arrive. Kahala has managed, somehow, to balance its 1960s Hawaiian look with all of the modern touches that you expect in a luxury hotel. The last thing that the Kahala needs is "updating." If you leave the Kahala thinking it does you probably should have stayed at Trump or the Hilton.The resort has, I think, resolved its service issues at Veranda and at the pool/beach, which I mentioned in my review a few years ago and prevented me from giving the place 5 stars. The staff at Veranda was very attentive and friendly. I think they are still understaffed out at the pool, as there were a couple times where we had trouble getting their attention, but for the most part service there was perfectly fine.Staff at both places told us that the resort is about to substantially change their respective menus. I took every opportunity to tell them to bring back their nachos, which we loved on past trips and was one of the few things on the menu really accessible to kids. I fear that the hotel will try to "upscale" the menu and eliminate things like the still excellent cheeseburger. The last thing the pool menu needs is another raw fish option.One thing that really bothered us: every time the shuttle backed up in front of the hotel--more times each day than you can count--we could hear the beep beep beep of it going in reverse. Management should really figure out a way to have the shuttle exit the driveway without going in reverse because it really can ruin your solitude in your ocean front room, not to mentioned the atmosphere of the Veranda. But that is my only real criticism. I've already started saving for our next trip.

Overall we really enjoyed our stay here. The rooms and decor were lovely and in good taste; and the staff was mainly very friendly, accommodating and helpful. People have commented in other reviews that the hotel is "aging" and needs to be updated, but that is not the case in my opinion. Just because something isn't modern doesn't mean its not classic or well kept (which this hotel is).The valet, concierge, bell service, shuttle driver, and housekeeping were all helpful and polite. The spa (although pricey) was one of the best experience's I have had at a spa and the staff was extremely nice.The downsides to this hotel were limited and very specific in my opinion:  - The service at the Seaside Grill is horrible. Errors abounded and it was clear that the staff couldn't have cared less (you can see my review at Yelp under Sarah R). - You have to pay for umbrellas. Cabanas I can understand completely, but to make guest who are paying $500+ a night at a high end resort pay for the luxury of not being sunburned seemed a little cheap on the part of the hotel in my opinion. I expect that basic things like shade will be provided without being nickeld-and-dimed, that is why I am staying here and not the Hilton.Overall I would likely stay here again, although I really would want to see those two issues fixed before I could say I am sure. That would also make this a 5 star rating for me instead of 4.

We were warmly greeted by genuinely friendly staff carrying leis who welcomed us into an exceptionally well-maintained and very beautiful property. Our room was very spacious, with lovely furnishings and linens, two separate sink areas in a luxurious bathroom and stunning golf course views. From the ocean-side restaurants, the wonderful food, the relaxed atmosphere, excellent all-around service, state-of-the-art gym, yoga and fascia classes and lessons on the beach and lovely pool and beach areas -- we couldn't have been happier. The Kahala is a wonderful experience and highly recommended!

This is what other hotels strive to be. It's outside of Waikiki which we liked. There is a shuttle to take you in for shopping etc. The staff is so gracious, and skilled. Our room was 1205, overlooking the dolphin lagoon. Very spacious, great bathroom (paint needed touching up), large TV that swung out for viewing. This is my favorite hotel to date.

Stayed only for 2 nights. Decided we wanted to end our 18-day holiday with some beach time and comfort. The Kahala did not disappoint. It far exceeded our expectations. From the moment we checked-in until we left the hotel, the hotel staff were consistently very helpful, courteous and welcoming (special mention to James at the reception who tried to accommodate our needs as we have been on the road for two weeks). Overall, very attentive staff. The rooms were luxurious and spacious. I love the double vanities and two separate wardrobe closets!!! The pool and beach did not feel overcrowded and noisy as there were enough provisions for the guests. We thoroughly enjoyed the restaurants (Hoku's and Arancino) at the hotel. Great food and excellent service. Probably the best in the island! Breakfast was pleasantly relaxing with a beautiful view of the beach. Unlike other big resorts we've stayed at, were you had to endure the long queues, uncontrolled children, and just too much activity going on. The best thing we loved about this hotel is its quiet residential location. Far away from the crowded beaches of Waikiki. The only disappointment we've had is not to be able to stay here a lot longer. The good part, we've found our hotel in Oahu! Will most definitely stay at The Kahala again!

Really good hotel and resort, friendly staff and good service, kids friendly, there are sea turtles and dolphins in the resort which are open for all guests. However, I don't like the Kahala Beach as much as Waikiki Beach, it is too quite, this hotel may not be your first choice if you enjoy city life.

We had an amazing stay here last month. The rooms are spacious, modern and well equipped. The staff are attentive and polite. Our children loved watching the dolphins, turtles and sting rays. The gym was very well appointed with modern equipment. We enjoyed being away from the hustle and bustle of Waikiki and would love to come back again

One of the finest hotels on Oahu, it is NOT in Waikiki and has maintained its top shelf facility and service for decades. Though it is close to most major tourist spots on the Island, it has it's own private location, quiet beach, and that warm and welcoming feeling of Aloha. It is our first choice by far, when visiting Honolulu. Oh, and yes - they still have their own dolphins, you can even swim with them if you like.
user_name:
travelingman921
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed here as the last part of our holiday after spending some time in New York and a few days on the Big Island. On arrival the staff were fantastic, greeting us in Hawaii style and helping us with everything we needed. On checking in they provided us with an upgrade to a Suite with views directly on to the Dolphin Enclosure. The room was one of the largest I've ever stayed in with a lounge area and a large bathroom with his and hers sinks either end. They had a twice daily maid service which would always keep everything topped up and a turn down service in the evening which was a nice touch. The room was a good walk from the Lobby, but a short walk to the beach and swimming pool. Although the restaurants were fairly expensive, it's what you would expect from a 5 star resort like this. We wasn't here long enough to try all of the restaurants but the ones we did try were worth it. All of the staff from the front desk, to maids, to waiters and bar staff were all fantastic. Always looking to help and very kind. Although it was outside of Waikiki, the hotel offers a free shuttle bus into town which runs about once an hour which I thought was excellent. It could be quite expensive if getting taxi's because it was about $30-40 each way depending on which part of Waikiki we we're travelling too. We tried to use the shuttle bus whenever possible, but the latest return is about 9:45pm and therefore if returning back late a taxi is needed. I would definitely recommend this hotel to those who don't want to stay in the city, but want to be close enough to be able to go into the city when you want. Definitely a 5 star resort.

We booked the Kahala for our Honeymoon and was not disappointed. From our arrival where we were greeted with leis to our checkout, we had an amazing experience. The view from our 10th floor room was exceptional and the hotel sent us a nice surprise to congratulate our honeymoon. The wife loved the bathroom and how it had a side for her. We enjoyed the uncrowded private beach (compared to Waikki) and the shuttle service the hotel provides (to Ala Moana, Galleria by Waikiki and the Kahala Mall). Also very cool to see the Sea Turtles and Dolphins in the lagoon! The staff was very courteous and helpful, esp the shuttle drivers. They went out of their way to accommodate the guests and dropped us off at an unplanned stop along the route to the Ala Moana. We did try the SeaSide Grill and the Plumeria Beach House which were okay, but pricey. Fantastic stay overall!

My family stayed at the first week of June. The facilities were impeccable, the suite had plenty of room for the kids to just hang out. The grounds were amazing and the view from the seventh floor overlooking the Pacific Ocean was magical. The breakfasts served on the outdoor patio was everything I imagined a trip to Hawai'i to be and more. Swimming with the dolphins was another memorable life event. Most of all, we felt like we were royalty in the service that the staff provided. It was the best place to vacation with my family, my father-in-law, my brother-in-law's family and our friends. I hope I get to return again some day. I can't imagine that Heaven is much nicer.

We spent a week at the Kahala in Sept. and we can't say enough about the wonderful service and time we spent there. The resort has an old style grandeur about it that yourarely see as most places are transitioning to a modern style which can seem pretty stark at times. From the moment you arrive, you can tell this is not this kind of hotel.The lobby is beautiful and tasteful. The rooms have beautiful romantic furniture and bathrooms.The valets, front desk, waiters and maids were all very courteous and gave the 5 star service expected at a hotel like this. It was very refreshing to have the maid call us by name when she came to do the turn down service at night. And the food in the restaurants was delicious (along with room service food also).It is a very stunning and peaceful resort I cannot wait to be able to return here for another visit!

Once again, we went to the Kahala for our anniversary (please read my October 2014 review). While much is the same, something was noticeably different with the staff. Their new uniforms, their almost "Stepford Wives" interaction with guests, less personal. Yes, they were polite, but their was an insincerity about them. Nor did they appear to be happy (I know this all sounds weird, but it is true). They seem to have cut many corners, which leads to believe that, once again, they are under new management (this was confirmed by employees). They close a poolside bar we used to frequent two nights a week (who does that and why?), they had considerably less poolside staff working, and then to garner additional revenue, they installed (while we were laying out poolside) 3-4 private cabanas that blocked your ocean view! The interesting thing is that no one used them the entire time we were there. It is like they were squeezing every available fee revenue possible, and let the guests enjoyment be damned. Had I not been going to the Kahala for over 25 years, I may not have noticed these things, but I definitely did. There was a lack of joy or morale in the employees that was noticeable. Part of the Kahala experience and success has always been their staff. Guess we'll have to wait awhile before returning.

We went for our honeymoon and loved that this was a quiet, secluded hotel, but was still a short cab ride or shuttle away from Waikiki. The staff was very nice, including the concierge when we had to change a few travel plans. The room/view descriptions were not exactly accurate, though we were pleasantly surprised to find our view was facing a golf course, with the ocean in the distance, and the sounds of a waterfall below us. We always had great service at the restaurants. I wish the poolside grill would stay open a little later. We often found ourselves by late afternoon wanting a snack before we went out for dinner and would realize the grill had just closed or was about the close leaving the nicer restaurants as our only option. We ended up going to a grocery store at a local mall to buy some snacks to keep in our room for this reason. We did a few tours that would not pickup at this location because it was not right on Waikiki, but a short cab ride solved that problem. (The tour bus driver typically drove us back for a small tip).

I love the hotel and our large room. The staff is attentive and I enjoy the evening sprucing up of the room in addition to the morning cleaning. Only drawback I can find is parking lot could use a little sprucing up but still well lit. Overall, a wonderful experience

I had a wedding at the Kahala. We had friends and family members stay for an average of three nights. Although the wedding itself was amazing (good location; and great food and beverage service), the service and experience at the hotel was horrible. Here is what happened to us-1. We got a smoking room, when we explicitly told them that we were nonsmokers and did not want a smoking room or smoking floor. When I complained, they moved us. They thought they were doing us a favor, and decided to move us two hours before the wedding ceremony. 2. They got our luggage mixed up, and delivered someone else's luggage twice. They told us that they were confused by the fact that so many people had the same first name initial, and last name. 3. My friend's laundry went missing. She had gotten it sent out to be cleaned, but some of her clothes never made it back. 4. We tried to get a fork and knife from room service. When we called, there was no response and we were placed on hold for five minutes. Then we were told that it was OUR fault since we were calling at a busy time of the day. My friend, who works in the travel industry, had to tell them that they should then staff accordingly.5. The bellman attempted to throw our luggage into the trunk--he missed and the luggage hit the rental car, leaving a scratch. He said, "Wow..That was heavier than I thought." My partner had to load up our own luggage as we were leaving.6. The worst part has been the billing and accounting/reservations desk. There was a charge on my credit card I didn't understand. When I called the resort to ask where the charge came from, they passed the blame onto each other--the reservation blaming the accounting, etc. it's been 48 hours, and no one has explained to me where the charge came from and to whom it pertains. I also had to remind them about the 500 room deposit, and ask for it. I wonder: what would have happened if I didn't double, triple check all of my bills and invoices from the wedding?7. The staff at the front desk were rude, and treated us pretty much like garbage. I have stayed at other Leading Hotels of the World, including the Shilla and the Faisano in Brazil. The Kahala does not deserve to be part of LHW. In fact, the night before we checked into the Kahala, we stayed in a small hotel in Waikiki that was a third of the price. The service we received there was far superior to that from the Kahala.

The best part about the Kahala is its location in a quiet residential neighborhood a few miles away from the bustle and bling of Waikiki Beach in Honolulu. It has its own beautiful beaches and a magnificent view up the east coast of the island. The public areas are also very pretty, with a wall of live orchids along the curving staircase that leads from the reception area to the lower level on the way to the outdoor dolphin pools where sea turtles and manta rays also reside. Service at the beach bar and poolside café was very friendly and the food was perfectly fine. Despite these strengths, the hotel is quite dated. It opened in the early 60s and looks it. Carpeting in many parts of the hotel needs a good cleaning. The hallway outside our beachfront room was cavernous and echoed loudly with any sound, which meant that passing conversations at normal volume were magnified enough to awaken us. Not restful. The property needs a thorough overhaul to bring it to the level of a five-star hotel. I hope someone invests in this effort, because it really is a wonderful peaceful spot.

My husband and I stayed here for one night. This is basically a four star hotel. If you think of it as that, it is a lovely hotel. It's located right outside Waikiki, so it's nice and quiet. The rooms are very spacious, with a big comfortable bed, a bathtub and shower, and a lovely Japanese toilet. There is no complimentary water and the minibar is not stocked. The grounds are unimpressive, but well kept. There's quite a few wonderful water features, even with dolphins, manta rays and sea turtles in them. The pool is quite small, and it closes quite ealry at 5.30 pm, but the (private) beach with reef is absolutely lovely. The breakfast buffet was also quite small, with no fresh orange juice and an extra charge for espresso. We payed about 600 dollars for the night - breakfast was not included. There is free wifi throughout the complex, even on the beach. The one thing that absolutely impressed me was their hospitality suite. We had a late flight and couldn't get a late checkout, but were offered the hospitality suite for the day. It is a communal area, with comfortable chairs and couches, a tv, drinks, a business unit, a shower, a few beds outside and things like an iron. The hospitality suite made our day amazingly pleasant. That and the Maui mule cocktails on the Veranda.

Currently staying at the Kahala and apart from a few minor issues it's wonderful!If you want modern, cool and homogenous - this hotel will not be for you! Sure, the decor is a little dated but that's what makes it so special. It's a little over the top in its grandeur but we loved it for it's kind of 60's LA feel.Breakfast, although expansive and delicious, has become a little tiresome after 9 days - perhaps a few minor changes each day would be an improvement. Don't like paying for the umbrellas and cabanas but when I complained the very gracious Manager gave us a cabana gratis for the rest of our stay.Our room, with balcony and ocean view was fabulous and very quiet. Despite having read past reviews regarding stains and lack of upkeep, we have found no evidence of this.The beach is away from the madding crowd of Waikiki, clean, calm and very swimmable!The whole experience, although a little pricey has been thoroughly enjoyable.PS. The staff are (to a man) wonderful!

a hotel with classnot into the waiki area but also have beaches around go try it, i have some preferences for the sheraton the moana and the modern honoluludifferent styles different budgetsit has good ranking

The lobby and rooms of this hotel were absolutely beautiful. They have dolphins on property which is nice for kids to see but I thought that the pool area was a little bit small. That aside, walking into the lobby you just seem to feel yourself relax. After taking the time to travel to Hawaii that was a nice experience. If you decide to upgrade your room to have a view of the ocean I would recommend trying to get a high floor (but not the 10th unless you smoke as that is their "smoker" floor) and keep in mind that the ocean is going to be beyond the parking lot or the roof of the lobby. Higher floor helps get a bit more above that.If you are wanting to be in Waikiki where all the action is than I would caution that this resort is by Diamond Head so you aren't on Waikiki Beach but if it's peacefulness and relaxation that you're looking for this was a great option.

Our stay here was pleasant, just a few minor details as per a previous review that niggled us a little. The pool IS quite small and can get crowded. Pool side service....well pretty much forget it. I did twice get up and get our own drink and asked do you have pool side service or not. I did see one guy wave his hands around for quite sometime before he finally got up as well. I did mention it to the bar staff at the restaurant and they said I'm not the first to complain in the last few days! Water should at least be taken around regularly, especially in that muggy hot weather. We asked for a mountain view, well really it's a golf club view, but the room itself was nice/clean and very quiet. Great shuttle service to/from shopping centres. Reception staff/concierge/porters very friendly and helpful. The dolphins are special, I found myself standing and staring at them quite frequently. The trainers do an amazing job.

We were upgraded for free to dolphin view room for being Expedia credit card holder. We got 4 leis for as family of 4. We were given goodie bags with free 2 beach towels and stuffed toy blue Dolphins. The bathroom is big with 2 sinks, 2 walk-in closets, mini fridge, free bottled waters, coffee maker and tea. They have 2 bathrobes, slippers and dark chocolates with turndown service. We also got $50 credit to spa or hoku's restaurant. Parking valet or self park was flat rate $32. Since hoku's was closed on Mondays we ate dinner at Italian restaurant closed by the main entrance. We also hang put ny the pool and ordered cook tail drinks. The gym was good size for quick morning workout. There's complimentary coffee and tea until 8:30 am by the 1st floor stairs near the conference rooms. We had beach view for breakfast at plumeria beach house. The staff were very pleasant, and hospitality room was full of drinks in the fridge, computer, copying machine and printers, coffee tables and lounge chairs. It is nice getaway from San Francisco,CA for me. I will defined elk come back. I like seeing the Dolphins by the hotel room balcony and sting rays bear the swimming pool. It is near kanaka mall and HNL airport only 18 minutes away driving.

This Hotel has a LOT of History. So many Presidents and political figures have visited over the years in addition to several Celebrities. The Kahala is FAMOUS for that.Unfortunately, It wasn't what we had expected. The property is very pretty but not very big, so if you like that, this is the place for you. They have a Dolphin Encounter on site. It is very cool to see the Dolphins and other sea animals on the property. We did not swim with Dolphins, as we had done previously. The pool and pool area are VERY small.I was actually surprised when I saw it. The beach is the place to be. Very pretty, but not a lot to do for kids. You should know that ALL the beaches on the Island are PUBLIC. Don't be surprised if you see some locals using the facilities and some dogs on the beach. The Hotel lobby, bar and resturants are nice... open air. The resturant by the pool/beach area needs a bigger/better selection of items. After a couple days of eating there you are definately wanting something different. Whole Foods and the mall are very close by.. Several people got food from there. Our room was nice. The furniture a bit dated but I think part of the charm of the hotel. Housekeeping was not the best... Complained several times due to trash not being emptied and coffee not being replenished. We had an issue with our TV... That wouldn't turn off, a few times... They eventually replaced the TV. Complained as well. I think customer service overall needs some work, especially at the front desk, However, the concierge was great. My Biggest THANK YOU goes to the Front Service Manager Masaharu Holeso (Masa) who was AMAZING! He went out of his way on several occasions during his stay to make sure we were comfortable and well taken care of. This was our 1st time in Honolulu. I would say if your looking for a quiet hotel with city life this is the place for you. To me... this didn't feel like typical Hawaii...

My wife and I have been to Hawaii several times over the years, and our stay at the Kahala Resort & Spa last week was our best experience to date.Upon check-in we were given an upgrade (without asking) to a partial ocean-view room. The room was fantastic with a large balcony with a couple chairs and a table. It overlooked the waterfall (manmade) that also serves to oxygenate the large dolphin lagoon (5 male, trained dolphins). Our room had an extremely comfortable king-size bed. I loved the large (I'm guessing 50-inch) Sony LCD television that, attached to a wall-mount, swivels out a good distance for viewing from any part of the room.The bathroom had two sinks, at opposite ends, with their own respective mirror, vanities, closets and ample drawers. There was a large bath tub (fantastic) and a separate shower. We also had a coffee-maker and cups, beer/wine glasses, bottle-openers, etc. The evening turn-down service was nice. She also tidied up the room... and placed two Hawaiian dark chocolates on our pillows along with two bottles of Hawaiian artisan water. And the maid also made sure our ice-bucket was always full. My wife and I loved watching the dolphins throughout the week. They played and sometimes stopped and peeked at us as we watched from one of the many viewing spots. For a large fee you can book a private session where you (and as many people are in your group) can don life vests and sit on a ledge with your legs in the waters... and the trainer will introduce you to a couple dolphins and you can touch them, get photos, etc. Then they will jump out of the water and do some tricks. We didn't do it ourselves but enjoyed watching those who did. The swimming pool is large and always clean. There is also a jacuzzi. The pool house staff always has fresh towels on hand (free) and they will also set up beach chairs anywhere you choose along the resort's large, private beach. For an extra fee (the chairs are also free) you can get an umbrella. The resort's free shuttle was very convenient and saved us a ton of money otherwise used for a taxi. It runs (there is only one and the driver is super nice) daily and drops (and picks you up) you at either the Ala Moana Shopping Center, Waikiki beach or the Kahala Shopping Center. The main thing we loved about the Kahala Resort & Spa was the peace and quiet (compared to staying at Waikiki); especially at night. It is a very peaceful and quiet (and relaxing) place to stay and we will be back next

Stayed here for a week of our US honeymoon. Location secluded which is what we wanted. There was a shuttle in to Waikiki which was good. Our room was on the ground floor facing the golf course (1108). The room itself was nice but noise was an issue. There was a kids club room just around the corner, and every morning excited children would be running by to go to club. Possibly this room is better for a family.The hotel pool was small and very crowded at times. This was also full of children and hence very noisy. We have nothing against children but would have preferred a seperate adults only pool. The hotel beech was beautiful and the only niggle here was the lack of umbrellas, in a 5 star hotel I don't expect to pay for the use of a sun shade. We chose to do the dolphin experience and really enjoyed it, expensive but worth it. I had a facial at the spa and this was also good. The service in the poolside restaurant was very slow especially at lunch times. Food was ok though. We experienced hoku and the Italian restaurants and the food and service at both were great. The veranda restaurant was not as good for service, the staff there seemed disinterested and we were often left waiting a while. if you want a meal there be warned, portions are small. My husband ordered risotto as his main, it was laughably small. Special mention to Gloria on the concierge desk, she was very helpful and had a great sense of humour. Overall we felt the location and setting were great, but little things left our experience being less than 5 star. With improved attention to detail this place could be awesome.

This hotel was terrific. The building itself is amazing, as are the grounds and the beach. Just a short drive from Honolulu and all it has to offer, you get a haven in Kahala. Maybe the best part was a quiet brunch buffet sitting on the beach every morning - great way to get the day rolling.

This is the third time I stayed, and I will keep coming back. Service was excellent, staff was very warm and friendly. Beautiful area, gorgeous view. Just a wonderful stay, I highly recommend this hotel, it is close to downtown Honolulu, yet still very quiet and secluded. Conrad Hilton picked the perfect location on Oahu when he built this hotel years ago. A must stay if you are going to Oahu! What a wonderful hotel and excellent staff.

The Kahala Hotel and Resort is not in downtown Honolulu in the Waikiki area and that is but one of its great virtues for those who want to spend time away from high rises and the business of Waikiki's version of Rodeo Drive and prefer to be in more of a paradise feeling area. It seems that everyone we met who works at the Kahala has been there for more than 15 years and that, alone, says a lot. Everyone treated us with great care and warmth. The room was beautifully appointed, the bed very comfortable, the view from the balcony lovely, the breakfast buffet excellent. Eating breakfast in a relaxed environment thirty feet from the beach, is heavenly. Every request we made, every question we asked, was met with immediate positive, accurate responses. We were never hurried. One of the concierge staff, Gloria Kennedy, was especially helpful above and beyond the call of duty. It was a wonderful experience from start to finish and we will be happy to return there.
user_name:
steven s
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: While I do understand most resorts on Hawaii have been built over half a century ago, staying at them first-hand can leave a different impression. The Kahala features grand elements that suggests it was one of the best luxury resorts on the island back in its prime, but even good maintenance cannot diminish the passage of time.Getting around on O'ahu:Your best bet would be renting a car for your duration, unless you want to stay at the resort for your entire holiday. There is nothing wrong with that, but since there are a lot of sights around, you would be missing quite a few things. The Kahala is also situated on the southern tip of the island, so getting around isn't exactly convenient without a vehicle.The Kahala:From a glace, I would guess that the resort was built sometime between the late 60's to early 70's. Even though the resort has been properly managed, the style and the front desk gives it away. The rooms are fairly spacious, and the staff service is commendable. My wife asked for a kettle (we are used to having hot / warm water), but the first kettle we received had so much rust on the heat coils that it was awful to look at (they promptly returned with one in a much better condition). We got a room with disabled assess, so the bathroom was fairy large. The downside was, the disabled alarm was malfunctioning at 7 am the next morning so that set my wife in a sour mood for the rest of the day. The hotel does have a pool which houses several bottlenose dolphins, guests can get close to the fence to take some pictures or pay a premium for a relatively short interaction with them. Overall, I found the stay below average relative to the price I paid.Activities around the Kahala:The Diamond head national monument is about 10 minutes drive from the resort, and if you are in physically good condition, the 1 hour+ hike is definitely worth the view. There should also be some great dive sites off Koko crater, which is at the southern end of the island - so find yourself a charter and dive away!Hope this helps to those who are planning to visit Hawaii soon! I personally found the vacation rewarding, but for those used to travelling in SE Asia - the 15% gratuity can be a little hefty for the wallet.
user_name:
Heero_Yue
Hong Kong, null, Hong Kong

review_body: We stayed here recently for four nights, and from check in to check out, it was a stellar experience. We used the "Kamaina ( resident)" rate and this included parking, wi-if and a breakfast buffet each day. The buffet is terrific, and the staff will customize your choices. The location of the hotel is off the beaten track, but there is a regular free hotel shuttle to Ala Moana and Kahala Mall, and Waikiki. Highlights include: top drawer amenities, turn down service every evening, free bottles of water every day, tons of large towels, a wonderful shower and soaking tub, and oh-so-soft bed linens. What makes this hotel so special is the attention to detail, and concern for customer satisfaction. Everyone is super friendly and helpful, and you never feel rushed at any time. Even the pool staff is great and will take a beach chair down to the beach for you and cover it with a fresh terry cloth cover. No need to return pool towels or sign for anything: trust is the hallmark of the hotel. When we were there the weather was awful, but we still had a great time because of the many comforts of the hotel. There is even a early morning coffee station in the lobby with free coffee, cream, and tea, and the coffee is premium quality and fresh. We will definitely be doing this again. It's a great place for peace and quiet, tranquility, and luxury. And if you crave the hustle bustle, Waikiki is only a short shuttle or cab drive away. The dolphin lagoon is fun to watch, and the beach is safe for even the littlest water baby

Coming from the crazy busy beaches and streets in downtown Waikiki - arriving at the Kahala almost feels like your entering a safe, silent bubble.....This hotel is soo peaceful and enjoyable!!!Beautiful kept beaches, great service and awesome food - together with a really comfortable room made our stay. We did NOT get an oceanside room, but we learned that the beach is all yours if you go early in the morning! There is not a lot of shade on the beach and the charge you for umbrella's but we never had to get one because we found shade under one of the trees - we rented paddle boards for the kids, they swam with the dolphins (ok - they don't give this away! That was very expensive - but a great experience!). Overall we enjoyed our stay! Our room came with the breakfast buffet so we went to the beach first and had a late breakfast/lunch to make it last for an early dinner... The kids loooved the smoothies at the pool site bar.They have a great shuttle service - and for the early risers like me a complimentary coffee station early in the morning!They have an onsite photograph service = so if you want a photographer take pictures of you and your family - they will be with you for an hour... I was hesitant in the beginning but super happy with the pictures she took... super expensive too so we only ended getting one picture - a nice memory!

We certainly landed on our feet here! Classy, elegant (in a slightly 60's way!), our 2 bed suite with exceptionally well appointed bathrooms, was beautiful overlooking the beach, pool and, of course, the Dolphins (perfect for lazily glazing at by the family) Whilst certainly not cheap (!!!) the attentive service from all waiters, front of house and housekeeping staff is particularly good - they use every hotel trick to call you by your name - which is always appreciated. The same can't be said for the Concierge staff, who we found slightly unhelpful sadly.Restaurant wise - in a slightly captive market - Hoku's is expensive and the portions a wee bit large. Plumeria Beach House good for lunch with a huge breakfast buffet too - the best restaurant for us was Arancino (the Italian) beautiful, elegantly prepared food and super service from Matt & Cody.Would we return - absolutely - as Kahala is THE place to stay - especially if you prefer to be away from the high rise towers of Waikiki Beach.

The hotel is beautiful inside and out. It is extremely well maintained so does not show its age at all (other than the peeling paint that we noted in the stairway to the parking garage). The room was comfortable and the bathroom area very spacious with two basins and closets. The grounds are very nice, the beach clean and comfortable. We appreciated being able to just grab a beach chair and set it up without someone running up to tell us there was a charge or that they had to set up the chair. Highly recommended if you want to be away from the crowds of Waikiki, although the location will be a negative for those who want lots of things within walking distance.

Great service.Great room at an amazing price.Dolphins and great food. This is a good spot in Honolulu We had to leave Turtle Bay Resort because they had tons of mold everywhere and treated us horrible. THANK YOU KAHALA FOR TREATING ALL YOUR GUEST FAIR.

First, who I am. I'm an American who grew up in Asia, Central America and the U.S. I have stayed in hotels worldwide since age 8. I travel twice a month on business. I have stayed at some of the best (Oriental Bangkok) and some of the worst. (No need to name), and some predictable, ordinary ones. (Residence Inn type of thing).At the Kahala, we stayed on the 3rd floor facing the golf course and hillside, that was fine, even though it was not an ocean view. The room decor was very nice, and the room was renovated recently enough not to cause issues with mold or smells. The hotel is placed nicely so that no one has a street or parking lot view, as far as I know. Unlike at *any* American-owned Honolulu hotel, when I called twice in advance of arriving and mentioned that this was a very special occasion, a return to Hawaii with mother and sister and our families 30 years after moving away, AND that I had broken my foot just a week before the vacation, and that we were in one room with two adults and two children, and would appreciate any available upgrade, neither the reservations agent nor the front desk nor anyone volunteered to upgrade us in any way. No mention of a a high floor or an ocean view or a suite or any of the things that would have happened at most Waikiki hotels, and did happen for my mother and sister at both the Hilton Hawaiian Village and the Embassy Suites properties. They were upgraded to two bedroom suites to give them sufficient space at no extra charge. I got the feeling that the staff did their best to give us the nicest room that our room rate justified but were strictly not allowed to give upgrades. I repeatedly felt this way on the property, that the ownership and/or management is so very concerned with getting every last dime from every customer, that the small niceties that a normal human employee would do for a guest are just not allowed without an upcharge. After paying $17.50 for buffet breakfast for my child, where she ate a little fruit and a muffin, when she was crying with hunger and a minor injury an hour later and I returned to the buffet to ask if I could have another muffin, I was told "yes, but I must charge you." I agreed to this but wasn't impressed. As a business owner myself, I can picture the owners paying a pretty penny for the property and needing to get their investment back. But some things were just annoying. At home we own a $250 Caravan pop-up canopy in pristine condition, that even has tent walls. At the Kahala a ratty canopy without walls costs $115/day plus tax and fees, so about $130, to rent some shade for two people per day at the beach when we were already hotel guests. Seems wrong when the said tents are getting quite ragged and broken.The service poolside and at the beach was slow, and I know, because due to my injury, I was hopping all around the place getting my own towels and letting the bar staff know about the tray of pineapple drinks another guest had rudely left in front of our beach chairs for four hours.Seeing the display of straw hats outside of the Plumeria restaurant where the daily breakfast took place, I went to the spa store and attempted to buy one. The worker there first said they didn't sell any. When I explained the display, she said "that must be just for display." When I pointed to the one hanging on the door behind her, she was about to say that it was just for display as well, when I gave her a "look." She took it off the door, and lo and behold, the standard straw hat I could get at my local farmers' market was $156! I had just lost my much nicer straw hat on the airplane, and badly needed one, but just could not stomach that silly price for a hat that wasn't as nice as mine. I ended up buying on at the Hilton Hawaiian Village which has a store run by two nice Korean ladies and has perfectly fair prices. My $28 hat, was indeed, $28.On the day we left, I finally saw the other shops in an interior corridor on the property and there they sold sun hats from $28 to $250. Strange that the spa employee didn't direct me there!For high tea, we sat ourselves down at a sofa and chairs around a large, square coffee table. There were 11 of us. The staff seemed a little irritable about trying to fit so many place mats around one coffee table. I suggested they bring a second one or add tables to the corners of our area to accommodate us, and the server actually refused on the grounds that another customer might need them!!!! Who, may I ask, was a bigger customer for high tea that day than us? No one. And in fact, it was a slow day, being a bit drizzly, and a weekday. The tea was fine.A friend has told me to get the buffet breakfast because it was "the best," so we did. Actually, it was just a very large selection of ordinary and sometimes sub-par breakfast food. I would have rather had a lower-priced, perfectly balanced breakfast each day, creating less waste and not gaining any weight from the need to "try everything" or "get our money's worth." There was a selection of cut watermelon, papaya, pineapple, and strawberries. The papaya was absolutely perfect every day. The pineapple was mostly very good, but oddly underripe sometimes. There was lox and cream cheese, prosciutto and cheeses, coconut tapioca sweet soup, miso soup, and fresh hot rice and pickles. There was a toaster and bagels (didn't look boiled so I didn't try them) and bread, and small sweet danishes and muffins. The blueberry muffins were very good. There were hot foods, including bacon, sausage, potatoes, and sometimes one Asian selection. One day there were char siu bao, which our family appreciated. There was a waffle iron going nonstop and whipped cream, maple syrup or coconut syrup for the waffles. There was a long daily line for the omelets with a nice selection of fillings, including previously frozen bay shrimp, ham, spinach, jalapeno, tomato, shredded cheese, and onion. The cooks overcooked the eggs, though. One day I asked for poached eggs but first they were so raw I had to send them back, and then they were too hard. I could tell chef was boiling them instead of taking them off the heat. There were malasadas, but not as perfect as Leonards'. In retrospect, I wouldn't get the breakfast buffet ($35 per person on the weekdays and more on the weekends) and would either order off the breakfast menu or get a case of papaya at Costco, and eat it in my room or at poolside before heading out each morning. I hope they expand the breakfast menu, add a Japanese breakfast, and teach the cooks to prepare eggs properly.One night we happened upon a seafood buffet at dinnertime at the Plumeria, which was very large and enjoyed by the whole family. Our servers were so kind and helpful.We appreciated that there were child menu prices at all the restaurants on the property. Child meals around the pool or on the veranda were about $10. Arancino restaurant on the property had the most adorable pizzas for the kids. They shaped the dough to be an animal face with ears. There was even a little cheese in the ears, and the child's chocolate cake with chocolate whipped cream was "perfect," according to my 7-year-old. Our server was so kind to the children.I was surprised that even though the hotel now has Japanese ownership, it didn't offer Japanese specialties in its casual dining by the pool or on the veranda, and didn't offer wet towels at meal service. For us, that would have at least made it interesting. It would have been nice to also have a spa menu. I gained a full 5 lbs on the trip with the huge buffet and the fried food by the pool, I guess.The housekeepers were very nice but forgot what time they were supposed to do our turn-down service. They did a wonderful job of making sure we had plenty of towels and cleaning in spite of our wet towel and bathing suit wonderland.The bathroom did not have ventilation, so wet things left to dry on the bathtub just molded, which happens easily in Hawaii if there is not enough moving air.

Really enjoyed our stay at kahala! The hotel is beautiful, and the room is really comfortable.. The beach is just great, it was clean and enjoyable! The only thing that was a bit negative was that you have to pay a bit much for the beach bed with canopy! (Should be included in the price, or at least cheaper ) Other then that everything was great. . The restaurants and the over all experience of the stay is 5 star

We had a great time at the Kahala but the resort itself wasn't the highlight of our time on Oahu like we imagined. Great views and friendly staff as the rooms are only ok. Would most likely venture to another resort and hotel in the area next time we are visiting Oahu.

Me and my husband stayed at kahala for our honeymoon. The choice was perfect. We have to say thanks especially to Julia of pacific dream photography. She is so sweet and she made the most beautiful pictures we have ever had. I reccomend the photo shoot to everyone because You take home the best memories ever.

It started out poorly, called the night prior and they said we had a two bed room in the towers, arrived, got a king bed and a cot. The cot seemed as if it was from 1972. Thin spring, this is a "top hotel" and I do believe it is time to get good fold away beds. Do not try to use two hair dryers, the power will go out in your room. The beach is still great for families very calm etc. The staff I give an overall B. Housekeeping was fantastic, the beach staff, just did not seem friendly at all, and the front desk, they were doing you a favor. The first class feel of the hotel is gone, I suggest an upgrade and at the least get happy staff who seems happy to be there.

Excellent staff and amenities! The staff was so nice and warming. We definately will recommend to our friends and family! Rooms were beautiful! Beach front was clean and well kept. Dining was excellent variety as well as fresh and tasty!

I'm so very disappointed by my stay at this revered Oahu resort. The reviews and incidental praise from friends and colleagues perhaps over sold this old school Japanese owned hotel. The room rate was fair. Everything else was fleecing. The pool and beach chaise lounges and pillows have lived beyond their useful lives. The towel covers and towels are adequate if you can hunt them down with beach and pool service being sporadic UNLESS you want a well priced drink. Mediocre rose $16 U.S. for a weak hot cup. Want a frozen drink, say a piña colada in a pineapple? $32. Buffet breakfast $40/person.Want an umbrella on the beach. $25. :60 minutes with the captive in-house dolphins $335. Let's not forget the taxes, service charges and tips.You'd do better with a daily resort fee and training your beach/pool staff to attend to the guests even when their not 'selling' (drink; umbrella).Last, it rains now and again. Be prepared for it to stop and the guests to need service. A notice that the ocean is closed in proximity to the ocean would help. Some staff at the pool to dole out towels and fetch drinks would as well. It's not as if you're reducing your room rate for the reduced service!

My husband and I live on Oahu and have been to this hotel many times for dinners, weddings, and holiday parties, but this was our first time staying at the hotel. We decided to celebrate our first anniversary with a staycation at the Kahala and it was perfect.We stayed two nights in a scenic view room. Our room was on the first floor with a lanai that opened to Waialae golf course. This may not sound appealing to many (especially when there is a beach on the other side of the hotel) but my husband loves golf and he loved being on the golf course. It was perfect for us.The service at this hotel is first class! The rooms are clean, turndown service always happened when we were out to dinner and our room was always stocked with water and a bucket of ice. Without us ever asking! Also as we were celebrating our anniversary the hotel left a welcome note and a sweet treat in our room. A very nice touch that makes this hotel truly 5 stars. During our stay, we had dinner at Arancino, lunch at the pool and Sunday brunch at Hokus. At Arancino, our waiter Tony did an amazing job recommending his favorites (we got the tasting menus and we were not disappointed). Tony took care of all the tiny details. He had the chef make us an anniversary dessert and even gave us a small box of macaroons for us to take back to our room. Awesome!At the pool, we made an all day cabana reservation and my husband asked if they had a cabana that could connect to wifi (so he could fantasy football draft on his iPad...). The pool staff accommodated this request without hesitation and set us up on the cabana nearest the pool (that has wifi) but is still on the beach. It was absolutely perfect. The husband got to do his fantasy football drafts without fail and from a cabana on the beach! Lunch and drinks also got served in the cabana and we didn't have to move from our spot all day. The service was excellent!Thank you to all the staff at the Kahala for making our stay a great one. We will definitely be back again!

Didn't actually stayed in this htoel but attended a wedding reception there and experienced what a 5-star hotel is like in Honolulu. Thr entrancce lobby and surrounding grounds are impressively spaceous and well-presented with the luxury one would expect. Has it's own private beach with calm waters in coves which well suit family enjoyment.The ground where the wedding reception was held was beautiful and romantic in setting with a spectacular view of the sea and another quiet beach behind.The buffet dinner at the recption was awesome, with a wide choice of authentic international gourment, including Chinese, Japanese, Hawaiian dishes and top grade mouth-watering roast beed being served. The staff service was impeccable as well.All in all, a great hotel that we would like to spend time on our next visit to Honolulu.

The Kahala resort & spa is a magnifiscent place to spend some days! Staff very helpful, friendly and enthusiast to explain anything you may have question on! Show with dolphins in its lake is breathtaking and worth paying to take a 30min course to get familiar with them! Kahala is definatelly a location i would suggest you visit! Unique experience! A little bit far from Honolulu center but shuttle bus is available in hours that will suite you. A must try paradise!

Wanted to leave a day early. Penalty was full payment even though when I checked in they said they had no problem with me leaving early. Hmm. My room was "upgraded" to a partial ocean view. Translate: I am looking at the parking lot with some blue behind it. I asked to be moved to my original view of "scenic" and got a mealy-mouthed response as to why they couldn't move me (checked in full). If you are looking for a hotel that will make it about you, I don't recommend here. The Disney hotel is the one I'm sad I didn't book. :(

Spent four nights here so i could be close to my sister's wedding venue. Ate at Plumeria, Veranda and Seaside Grill all on site. Swam with the dolphins. The staff were friendly, helpful but wonderfully unobstrusive. Very expensive but excellent.

This is a good hotel to stay in if you want to get away from the hustle and bustle of Waikiki. The good news is that if you're looking for more action, Waikiki is only 10-15 mins away. Good restaurants and good views. They have cabanas that sit right over their Dolphin quest attraction although not everyone will be happy to see dolphins in a relatively small tank. It's also not a very big beach although the protected cove makes it a nice calm place to relax.

My second time at the hotel and it is a nice relaxing resort away but close to Waikiki. Service is good and the food is very good. The rooms are very well appointed with great ocean views on one side but bathrooms could use updating. The pool area is a crumb and the beach is also small. The sea life with Dolphins etc is interesting but the small enclosure for them makes you wonder. Overall if you are looking for great Hawaii resorts this is a good one for Honolulu but better options exist at the other islands.

We have just spent five pleasing days at the Kahala hotel and resort. if you manage your expectations correctly it's a perfectly fine hotel. We had a lovely room in the tower with views of both the ocean and the golf course. Do get as high as you can! Although the hotel claims it is a five-star resort and charges accordingly, it is not. Perhaps it was when first built however at this point many many aspects of it fall far from the mark. It's in need of a complete overhaul from the shabby rugs to the worn cushions. However it met our needs. We intentionally avoided the crowd at Waikiki, but it is only 15 minutes away. I don't know if there is a better option. Staff were inconsistent. No welcome lei for us! Sometimes friendly sometime curt. The mile long sandy beach is lovely and the food while expensive, was tasty. It was a perfect spot from which to enjoy the beauty of this island. Our plan was to hike early each morning then return to our hotel for a pretty nice buffet breakfast. There were lots of hungry people each morning, and the food was often in need of replenishing. There were enough choices but not a spectacular spread. Then we would head to beach time to digest. This worked pretty well. We were able to always get a beach chair. We avoid the noisy small pool. We ate each night at one of the different restaurants at the Kahala. All were ok- tasty but overpriced but in a very pretty setting. And easy. We were tired boys and girls by dinner. Lots of beautiful beach long walks outside our door made for a lovely vacation!

We ate brunch at the Kahala as guests of our daughter and son-in-law. The choices were astounding and it was difficult to decide among so many sweet and savory treats. Many places have brunch buffets with omelet bars and smoked salmon; this menu offered Japanese fare, outstanding pastries, and house-made passion fruit and guava jams to die for. The drinks were delicious and refreshing, too. The hotel itself is gorgeous and, while I prefer a less manicured beach, the pool was nice and seated next to a salt-water enclosure holding dolphins and sea turtles among which you can swim for a fee. The rooms were gorgeous and spacious, and, at 300 per night, not unreasonable for a luxury resort.

Our stay at the Kahala Mandarin Hotel and Resort was exceptional. We enjoyed both the food, and atmosphere throughout their hotel, and the beach front location was absolutely beautiful. We really appreciated the live Jazz music; which was playing at The Veranda lounge.

My wife and I were disappointed with Turtle Bay Resort on the North Shore and switched to this location for our last night in Oahu. We both wished we had switched much sooner as we had a fantastic experience at the Kahala. Excellent service is what makes the difference at this lovely location.
user_name:
Nicole P
New York City, New York

review_body: imagine, local people(that's us), nice, we got lei's, service excellent,didn't, wanna go home, at nite, had bubble bath, got up next morn,had breakfast, room service, coffee was nice,everything ono, mahalofor the two stuffed dolphins, was a nice getaway.

We loved our stay here. We were greeted with leis on arrival and check-in was quick. The rooms are large and the bathrooms the size of a NYC apartment. (We stayed on the first floor; If I go back I'd ask for rooms on a higher floor.) There are 4 restaurants on the premises so if you're only staying for a couple of days, as we were, there are enough options without needing to leave the resort. The beach is beautiful and the staff are very helpful in setting up the chairs fro you. Cabanas cost extra -- $45 for 4 hours or $115 for the day; they're worth it if you're planning to camp out on the beach for an extended time. The pools, both the kiddie pool and the regular pool, are rather small. Our teenage kids also were a bit sorry for the dolphins having to be in a small (for dolphins) enclosure; but the younger kids seemed to be having a great time watching and playing with the dolphins. The sea turtles, manta ray and other fish are also fun to watch. We found this hotel to be a great place to end our Hawaii vacation -- a few days of complete r&r away from the bustle of Waikiki.

We stayed in a suite that was called a Scenic Ocean View Family Suite. We loved the size of the room and how it was set up with 2 bathrooms. The MAJOR problem was the pull out queen sized bed. If this is a "Family" Suite, then it is probably typical that someone will be sleeping on the pull out bed. It was the WORST quality bed of any suite/villa that we have ever stayed in. No person, or child of any age, should have to sleep on something so old and cheap, especially at this high quality resort and for the price of the suite. We have experienced MUCH nicer pull out couch beds, so I know that they exist. I feel that for the price we paid for the suite, the second available bed should have been at a MUCH HIGHER quality. After the first night when it squeaked all night and hurt my kids' backs, we asked for an adjustment and for extra padding. It was only slightly better, and certainly not up to par of what it should have been. It really needs to be replaced! If we had known the pull out bed would be so terrible, we would have opted for 2 rooms, with the 2nd one having 2 nicer double beds instead of the terrible pull out couch. The resort does have a great staff and the best thing it that it is not crowded and very relaxing.

Amazing resort that's first class all the way. Service was great and the hotel has many amenities that is expected of high caliber resorts. Loved being able to go to pool and seeing the Dolphins and green sea turtles. The view is simply amazing anywhere at the hotel property. I would go all out for a nicer room with the ocean view.The beach is at the doorstep but you must pay for everything but water. Bring your own goggles so you can swim further out and see lots of cool fish. Would definitely come back the next time around

Coming from the UK we were very tired on arrival and check in being 3pm, the room was not available. We went and got some lunch by the pool which was fine but we were told we would be telephoned and we were not. When we went back the room was ready but we heard several others during our stay say they had not been called either.Our room was immediately on the beach which was very nice, it was quite small and the toilet was so tight you could not close the door easily, you had to maneuver yourself into position. We had two queen size beds as we have a child but one of these was not big enough for myself and my husband to fit into so we had to get a camp bed brought in. Kyle was a very smiley member of staff who we remember for being nice, he said we could change to a room with one big bed and a camp bed but we never chased this up as we couldn't face moving rooms and were happy to be on the ground floor.We went to breakfast the next day which was good but we were told this was not included. We had thought we had booked a package which did include it but agreed to pay 63$ per day to add it on, when we finished breakfast we were given a bill for 100$ and queried this to be told our daughter was over 12 so classed as adult. We said we had agreed to pay the first price and rather than expect the waiting staff to sort this out we went to reception. It wasnt easy to sort out and I would strongly advise you to have written confirmation of what your trip includes. When my husband looked back through his emails we managed to prove we were breakfast included anyway!!We then went to the sunbeds, got comfortable and settled in for the day only for the towel guy to come over and say we had to pay for the sunbed as it had a sunshade built on. This shocked us as there was no sign and we saw many people moved over the week we were there. We used the shuttle bus several times which was good but one day it was overbooked so people had to stand.Restaurants are reviewed separately so I wont mention them.Loved the dolphins although locals do protest at the weekend with a banner saying captivity is cruel but most of the dolphins have been born in captivity so don't know any different.
