The pool area has a bar that has a limited food menu as well. The bar has seating on the beach as well . We tried several of the restaurants and found them all to be excellent. The breakfast buffet at the Plumeria had a great selections of foods daily as well as an omelet station. Hoku's Restaurant was amazing as well. We both had spa treatments while there and had great service. The hotel offers rentals by the pool if you choose to paddle board or snorkle. If you are in Honolulu be sure and stay at the Kahala for a trip to remember!

We have stayed at the Kahala in the past and thought it would be a good way to end our time in Honolulu again. The place is still amazing and we still love it - however the wait staff on the beach were very difficult to connect with (no one around for long periods of time). The other concern was the number of local "kids" who kind of took over the property. It wasn't relaxing - which is what we were looking for. At the price - it was a bit of a disappointment.

This was our third or fourth stay at the Kahala Hotel and Resort (through their various operators). We were there for five nights right after New Year's. The staff is superb - super friendly. The location is great as you are well away from the density of Waikiki. (in my mind there are really only two hotels to consider in Honolulu - either the Halekulani in Waikiki or the Kahala Hotel - but you pay for the service and luxury). Unfortunately the Kahala Hotel does not seem to be quite the luxurious experience it used to be. The rooms are a bit dated and the attention to detail is lacking. For example, bottled water is only sparingly offered in the rooms. They only have single sinks in the bathrooms -not a big deal, but not what you expect in a "five-star" hotel. While we had a room on the 10th floor with ocean view, the lanai was not particularly clean and I was uncomfortable going out in my bare feet. The dining room for breakfast (the Plumeria Beach House) is beautifully situated, but it is a challenge negotiating the enormous breakfast buffet which is their standard fare. It is far from a unique experience and we found the crowd for breakfast to be uncomfortable - there seemed to be some large tour groups there while we were there. We also had dinner at Hoku's which was ok, but not particularly memorable. You pay a lot for this hotel and, while it is nice to be away from Waikiki, the Halekulani provides a more memorable experience. As a final note, while I understand the dolphins are well cared for and have full time attention, it is bizarre to see people in the pools with them, holding on to them to have pictures taken. They are beautiful creatures and it is strange to see them cooped up in the rather small pools. And having people in there swimming with them when they are supposed to be wild creatures.

My husband and I have been staying at the Kahala for years and absolutely love it. It is home to us. The people are wonderful and treat us so nicely. The food is delicious, especially at Hoku's where Dante and his staff rock! They're the best! Also love the spa and the dolphins. Actually, we love it all and can't say enough good things about it.

Our stay was unexpected and unplanned. After 10 days in Waikiki we needed an oasis of rest and relaxation!. We stayed at the Kahala 2 times before and yearned for this resort of hawaiiana , pamper, and luxury. Fortunately they had availability, only one choice but we were elated just to stay there again. We celebrated our anniversary and found to our surprise a bottle of champagne and fruit snacks. Thank you so much for keeping hospitality in high standards and not changing much with the new owners. (We do miss the DimSum lunch buffets)

My family just came back from 5 nights at Kahala Resort. We were in heaven the whole time. From walking into the lobby area to seeing our gorgeous room and view on the balcony we were smiling from ear to ear. The entire staff is so friendly and helpful. Michal and Tatyianna at the High Tea were absolute dolls. Breakfast was delicious and lunch at the Seaside Cafe was beautiful. My daughter along with 3 other women in our group did a paddle board yoga class at sunset and they had so much fun. It was nice to be close enough to Waikiki yet in our own little world at The Kahala.

My family and I vacationed at the Kahala Hotel and Resort for a week long stay and didn't ever want to leave. The location and service were second to none. The staff was incredible, addressing you by name and catering to your every need. This is a must stay and is very family friendly. I have two children ages 10 and 12 and they keep asking me when we can go back. The food was a bit expensive, but so is everything else in Hawaii so don't be shocked when your breakfast bill arrives and it is over $100, it is worth every penny!

Had a lovely lunch here with family. Service and food was wonderful and the view and beach lovely ideal for those holiday photos. The turtles and dolphin show was a surprise bonus and you can swim with the dolphins if you would like with very friendly staff. All in all i would recommend this as a must visit if in honolulu.

Kahala is one of the few places I've been to where I feel like home. The staffs there are so friendly and helpful all the way from the valet to the manger. Even my hard to satified Chinese elite friends are having such an amazing time while staying there with fabulous dinning experience, swimming with the dophines, and chilling on the cananas on the beach. I also love the personal tough they do at the kahala, such as making noodles for chinese birthday celebration!

From the moment we arrived until the second we left it was perfect perfect food perfect teeth perfect service perfect cleanliness and amazing Aloha filled environment. The chef out did himself with the sandwiches pastries fruits vegetables and amazing tea selections.

Eating at The Veranda was a delight! The servers Kellee, Michal, and Tatyana were so gracious and predicted our every need. Thanks for setting up a special setting for Echo's birthday celebration! The valet was quick and the hosts were helpful to surprise our birthday girl. Come to the Kahala for a relaxing Sunday afternoon or a delicious dinner!

One always here's how lucky we are to live in Hawaii and it only gets better when one of the best Spas in Hawaii located at the Kahala hotel is just 3 blocks from my home.Whenever I really need to feel refreshed or going out for a big night I know I can count on Olivia to give me the latest hydro facial that will get me looking radiant for a special occasion-if you are visiting you won't want to miss the beautiful private spa rooms to have anyone of their amazing treatments-The rooms have private spa tubs and showers for complete privacy. My husband and I have also enjoyed a couples massage treatment with fresh strawberries and campaign delivered! The staff is super educated in the latest anti aging treatments and have products and beauty tools that you can purchase and take back home-one of my favorite treatments other then the hydro/oxygen facial is the anti aging June Jacobs hydrating facial-I also ask for the addition of the face lifting treatment with the Nu Face Trinity-your face and skin will look amazing. I am so lucky to live here and have such a wonder spa so close. If visiting Hawaii and even if not staying at the hotel this is one spa you should not visit-with Aloha Devra

For the celebration of my milestone Birthday, my wife choose to organize a private dinner with an intimate group of special friends at one of our favorite location in Honolulu, The Kahala Hotel and Resort. The exclusive experience and prime location of the hotel inspired us to have our wedding there and being Honolulu residents, each time a special occasion comes with our family, or for business purposes, this is our destination.My wife, Marisa, had a pleasant time working very precisely with the management of the Hotel for the planning of this special birthday, taking place on the magnificent beach front lawn of the private room of Kahala O Ke Kai. On the evening of the dinner the General Manager, Roseann Grippo, and her management team were on location to welcome personally my wife and I on our arrival, and impressed us with an outstanding setting and surprised us with unexpected beautiful flower arrangements. Absolutely delightful! Our guests arrived and were impressed also by the setting and private location, the dinner was just about fine dinning, impeccable service in every detail, bringing our experience above expectation.The evening was a complete success and this special birthday will remain unforgettable.

This is our 3rd stay and second review of The Kahala Hotel. We were having brunch at the Plumeria Beach House yesterday morning when we suddenly thought, why not stay the night? My daughter wanted to use the pool. :) Overall, still love the hotel and the staff are mostly awesome. With ONE exception (and this was the same even with our previous stays)....why is the front desk/reception staff find it sooooo hard to crack a smile? Why is answering a question such a hassle? I also had the feeling that one of them didn't want me to book a room. I walked up from the Plumeria Beach House and asked a lady in the front desk if there is a room available (I was doubting it due to the Sony Open). The first lady said there was only ONE room available and it was an undesirable room on the first floor with a view of the front of the hotel (where people drive in). I told her I will ask my family first. When we decided to go for it, I went back to the front desk to book the room but found another lady available to help me. I asked the same question and she said there was a room on the fourth floor with a nice view of the golf course/mountains. So was the first one lying? I took the fourth floor room but when the second lady was processing the transaction (by the way, the whole time, NOT a single smile or friendly small talk), I had a quick question. She actually had the gall to say, "wait I don't know where I am now," while staring at the computer screen the entire time. Maybe I should not have bothered her while doing rocket science work of booking a room - my apologies! But talking to me like that was RUDE!!! Rude!!!!! I don't want to end this review on a bad note so I must say that the valet service folks were exceptionally nice as well as the guy who delivered our bags to our room. Room was super clean, very big with an awesome view of the Sony Open! Housekeeping staff was also super, super nice.Dear Kahala --- we live in the neighborhood but check in for staycations and have also celebrated milestones there (our wedding, our eldest's baptism & first bday party). We also plan to have our second baby's second bday party there. Please train your frontdesk to more polite and to show a little bit more Aloha. It's such a shame when one of the first people you encounter upon checking-in seem as though the last thing they want to do is help/serve you.

My husband and I spent Christmas Day at Kahala Resort. We had a wonderful brunch at Hoku's where you can find a diverse blend of trends and culture influences. My favorite was ahi sashimi, king crab legs, bread pudding and never ending champagne:)After brunch we walk around the resort area enjoying all the activities Kahala Resort offered. I recommend Kahala Resort to people who love good food and good time.

I loved this place.First impressions weren't that great, it looks quite old (which it is) and the high rise in particular looks very dated. Up close you see that everything is in immaculate shape. Every inch is freshly painted and clean and there is a real classic feel. FOOD:(my priority)Food was great, breakfast standard buffet but perfectly fine, except that the wait for a table was 15min once or twice, admittedly on the two busiest days of the year. Poolside drinks fantastic, reasonable range of poolside food for lunches. Dinner options good, the bar outside the main restaurant had great drinks, very sophisticated ambience with a superb musician and sleekly attired staff, good wines. Hoku was a fine restaurant, great wine list, and priced OK if I remember rightly.POOL/BEACHESThe pool is pretty small and generally too warm although it cooled down after a couple of days. The kids loved it. I was a bit surprised at how kid-friendly it was as a few people had suggested the Kahala was a more adult-oriented resort...in fact I find it hard to imagine Hollywood celebrities hanging out by the pool which is a pretty noisy hive of activity..lots of great pool toys in the pool or for sale for the children.Beach was stunning, the staff set you up with a deckchair or pod chair, the beach here is totally calm and perfect for canoeing. You can get more privacy here if you want. We were at ground level so could walk out onto the sand within a minute. Beautiful night sky and stars.SERVICEImpeccable, friendly, service, coming from Australia especially you really appreciate people just going out of their way to make sure you are completely happy. Can't praise this highly enough.SLEEPNo noise issues of any kind that I recall (except for New Year's Eve fireworks)OTHER15 minutes to Honolulu can't be beat...we had dinner at Nobu and then popped back to our "private" beach, what a setup!NEGATIVESWell none to do with the hotel at all, but as you may know the hotel is built around a lagoon housing dolphins. I feel strongly (even more so since my stay) that these animals should not be kept in captivity. They are obviously cared for to the highest standards but this sort of attraction will hopefully be a thing of the past soon. I still give the hotel 5 stars as this is a personal opinion only.

My girlfriend and I spent my birthday here last year and I have to say, it's been the best experience I've ever had at a hotel. We had a gorgeous ocean view room. There is nothing like waking up to dolphins swimming right outside your balcony. Their fantastic staff made it seem like going out of their way to make your stay enjoyable a common thing. The hotel's GM even took a moment to strike up a short conversation while passing us in the hotel lobby. The food was incredible, and the lounge and atmosphere was nothing short of perfect. My girlfriend has been looking forward to returning there for her birthday this year.

I live here on Oahu, and I spend a lot of time at the Kahala Hotel and Resort with my family. For the second year, my wife and I put her parents up at the Hotel during the Christmas holidays. Their stay was perfect. The service, atmosphere, and hospitality shown by the staff and service people are absolutely the best on the Island. The rooms are beautifully appointed and large. The beach staff will make sure your drink is always full. I recommend a Tropical Itch while on the beach. You even get a backscratcher! Highly recommend this be where you stay on Oahu.

There is a reason I like this hotel. Everyone here caters to your needs in most sincere way. Because of hotel staffs' dedicated personal care, my trip to Hawaii was the most memorable. Hoku's dinning experiance was exquisite and fantastic although I wish there was more variety of menus that I can select.Kahala was just what I needed for my 15th anniversary.I highly recommend this hotel to anyone who wants tranquility and piece of Hawaii in their mind. - Freezerman from JIC -

for lack of pictures, let me describe in the minds eye, the utter attractiveness of a private invitation only exclusive event for the treasured guests and local clients of Honolulu's magnificent high class hotel: imagine pulling up the spacious horseshoe stone driveway and your door graciously opened and keys handed to a smart gentleman whilst your family is also attended to, immediately mesmerized by the christmas music, walking through the graceful decorated entrance arches to be greeted by attentive servers with delectable morsels and fine wines and freshly squeezed juices for your nourishment, seeing the happy smiling faces of the well dressed companions on this balmy starry holiday eve, children chasing each other through the small safe indoor outdoor crowd through to the guarded balcony overlooking the tranquil cerulean pacific reflecting the giant moon, jolly santa ho-hoing and picture taking in the gift- laden corner, and the unbelievably sky reaching tastefully ornamented christmas tree as the focal point of expectation....as the conversational hum of the guests begins to somehow harmonize with the angelic music, and children from the schools with matching heavenly voices decked in their best attire sing their rendition of holiness...parents and grandparents bursting with pride and good cheer; a brief, respectful speech by the hotel's general manager- the lovely Roseann Grippo...culminating to the wondrous eyes of all, the lighting of the blessed arbor....(perhaps i had too much wine, but it was genuinely a delightful evening..and so indicative of the service and hospitality i have come to expect and is consistently delivered by the classy Kahala:)

My wife and I had our wedding here in January, and were delighted with every aspect of this beautiful resort and its services.If you are seeking a beautiful, elegant, and also warm and friendly destination for your wedding/honeymoon/or other special occasion, look no further. This is the best Hawaii has to offer!Food and service at all levels were outstanding. Hotel staff up through the top levels of management personally went out of their way to ensure our group had a wonderful time. Thanks again.

Having had an incredibly busy year, I picked the Kahala Hotel & Resort as it is away from the hustle and bustle of Waikiki and I wanted a relaxing atmosphere in which I could just unwind with my family. My daughter was absolutely thrilled with getting to play with the dolphins! I would definitely recommend experience swimming with them at least one time.What's really nice is if you want a little retail therapy the Kahala mall is 5 minutes away. And if you want a date night, the Kahala has baby sitting services. Which is absolutely fabulous when you are traveling with little ones.

I LOVE this hotel and the whole experience of staying there! It is 1st class all the way...elegant and gracious...luxurious and comfortable...the restaurants are excellent and the service is impecable. I feel pampered and cared for whenever I am there. The GM, Roseanne Grippo, is amazing! She does everything in her power to make your stay the best experience possible! Friendly and warm and very supported by a wonderful staff..Carrisa and Dante are great! Its clear that everyone is very happy to be there and are treated well and their work is respected. I highly reccommend this hotel experience and again kudos to Roseanne Grippo for a job well done!
user_location: New York, New York, United States
user_name:
Mary G
New York, New York, United States

review_body: I've been a frequent guest of the kahala, and thought I'd share a bit about it. From the minute you drive up the private road you feel removed. Removed from the hustle and bustle. Back to a time where people provide the service you deserve when coming to a luxury resort. I spent the holidays there, and had an incredible time. We also spent our NYE there, what a fun night! The staff did everything they could to make us feel special. We spent our first day of the new year calmly relaxing by the pool. That is where I eat the best burger on earth. If the kahala hotel can make a cheese burger that good, imagine how your whole stay will be! See you all again soon,Aaron

It's such a wonderful spot on the island, only a quick ride out of the busy Waikiki and absolutely a wonderful experience. Very clean and staff is so friendly. Kahala is our favorite place to stay when we come to the islands !

Yes, there are other luxury hotels on O'ahu. And yet I find that I keep coming back to this hotel (several times this year) for its understated charm, luxury and the elegance of its character. These virtues are reflected in its staff - nothing is too much, just ask! - and in the layout of the property and rooms - always a quiet space, no sense of the hustle and bustle you have in other similar size properties (if you want Waikiki, it's just a 15 minute drive). The Kahala is graced with the repeat visits of many dignitaries, couples and families as it is, simply, the best hotel on Oahu and in the best location. That it's also a favourite place for discerning locals to visit for dining or special occasions says it all.Given the choice I would probably move in full time. Leaving is ever difficult! ('Parting is such sweet sorrow', someone once said ) How many hotels make you feel this way?

I have been to Oahu 6 times, the last and most fabulous time I stayed at the Kahala. Everything about his hotel was impressive. On arrival I was greeted warmly and given a beautiful shell Lei. The foyer of this hotel is all class and elegance. It is beautiful and well maintained. Check in was quick and much earlier than expected as my room was ready for me on arrival at 8:30am. After a long haul flight from Australia this was a godsend. My room was beautiful with a view to the mountains in the distance. Just outside on the balcony stairs I could see down to the Dolphin pool. The bed was very comfortable, and like a previous reviewer noted, like sleeping on a cloud. Service was excellent and pleasant. Complimentary pupus (which were delicious!) and a cocktail in my room made me feel very welcome.Breakfast was delicious and the omelette chef was absolutely gorgeous. As i said in the title, I could stay here forever, such was the wonderful welcoming atmosphere. It had a more personal touch than any of the other hotels I've stayed at in Honolulu. Hats of to the manager who clearly has the staff working beyond their best.I look forward to returning- in fact I wouldn't stay anywhere else.

From the moment we pulled up to the valet at the porte cochere my friends and I had the most luxurious stay, enjoying not only the pristine service but also unique property. I had never stayed at The Kahala Hotel & Resort before, however I had always heard about how relaxing the resort is from friends and family. The fact alone that it is only a 10 minute drive away from Waikiki however is completely surrounded by a golf course is the best of both worlds, the city life and the traditional Hawaiian vacation. Two of my friends from our travel group were really interested in the famous shopping and activities in Waikiki, while the rest of the group just wanted to sit by the isolated beach and get a tan...The Kahala was the ideal resort for this type of situation. At night after we all went out and did our own activities, either on property (The Kahala Spa is one of my new favorite places, because of the private rooms with their own infinity spa tubs...their Lomilomi massage is better than Four Seasons resorts in Hawaii) or in the city, we would eat on property. We stayed for a week, so we were able to try out their various restaurants including their newly renovated The Veranda. The waitress showed us pictures of what The Veranda looked like before, so if you have stayed at The Kahala previously you should try and look online and seriously consider going back, because I think the hotel is always developing to extend the beauty of the property. The entire feel is outrageous, with the open room just next to the lobby, offering a delicious and wide new dinner menu and after dinner drinks menu. We ended up loving this so much we would get drinks there before walking just across the room to Hoku's, their upscale island restaurant. The service across the hotel really was what made our stay over the top, with every staff member ready and willing to please our group. If I could go back again this year I would. If you are looking for a Leading Hotel of the World in Oahu with a large standard room, you need to look on The Kahala's website and really consider about how much this hotel has to offer, not only for a group of friends but for families and couples too (They offer dolphin quest and private dinners.) The property also offers great rates depending upon the season- so make sure to check out their rate promotions on their website. I ended up getting this great deal for their "Spring Package" that gives 20% off on the room price with daily free breakfast buffet for 2 people.

Every time I visit the island usually stay in town but this time was the 1st I decided to stay here. As expected the staff is friendly, hotel room well organized & the property is easy on the eyes. I look forward to soon to coming here again! Thank you The Kahala!
user_name:
Rommel G
Redondo Beach, California, United States

review_body: If the hustle and bustle of Waikiki is not your thing, Kahala is your best bet. Located 10-15 minutes east of Waikiki, the resort is situated in a tranquil and private location conducive to watersports on their section of beach, golf, or a swim with the 6 dolphins that call the lagoon of Kahala home. Customer service is extraordinary (as to be expected), and the restaurants and paddelboard/canoe rentals are great. In high season, the cheapest rooms start around $700/nt, going up to the thousands for the multiple bedroom suites, which are fabulous for families or luxury travelers. If you want to be in the middle of the action on Waikiki, stay at Halekulani or Royal Hawaiian (we've been to both and they're great), but if you want a little more quiet, Kahala is the place to go.

My husband and I just recently stayed at The Kahala for our yearly Hawaiian vacation. This was our first time staying here...what an amazing experience! The staff went above and beyond to make sure that our needs were met and we were impressed! Anyone looking for an upscale, top-notch Hawaiian vacation needs to experience staying at this resort! We can't wait to come back again next year...Mahalo!!

We had the best vacation ever in The Kahala, Honolulu! The staff was the best ever, they all behaved like they went through charm school and were genuine in trying to make our vacation the best ever successfully! The room was fabulous, the view brought tears to my eyes every morning. The bed makes you feel that you're on a cloud. The restaurants on the property are wonderful and responsible for quite a few extra pounds by the time we returned home. Hoku's lamb chops are out of this world!

Just returned from a beautiful environment, fantastic food and caring staff experience at the Kahala. Kahala is just as beautiful as I remembered! The food was amazingly good. My absolute favorite was the hot Caesar salad as it was so different and yet so fantastically tasty and attractive. It was my first trip back after the death of my husband of 46 plus years so it was so hard to be there without him. The staff were so welcoming to me, expressed such loving sympathy and worked so hard to ake me comfortable. I watched their interaction with other guests and they showed each person individually how much they wanted them to have the best of hotel stays. Kudos to all of you!

My wife and i stayed at while visiting customers in Honolulu. We had dinner at the hotel and it seemed like a blast. The restaurant is truly a gem but the rooms and hotel do hold something to desire. I think it can be said it needs an update. Room was spacious but the views are stinky. We tried to get a room with a partial ocean view but the partial was left to the imagination from the balcony. We then moved to upgrade at $175 additionally each night only to find the parking lot view was worse. We went back to our keyhole view of the ocean. Room was pretty, colonial in style and old in my opinion and the interior and lower level is all dated. Service is good and the outside bar is pleasant. Frankly most of Honolulu needs the same type of face lift and any hotel taking the first step will get the benefit the investment deserves. I would certainly recommend the place especially if the golf course is available to you via reciprocity from a mainland club. Great course!!

Kahala HotelWe came here after 5 days on the North Shore at Turtle Bay Resort for the final 5 days of our vacation. It was a serious let down.The GoodLocation is great – away from the noise of Waikiki. The beach is lovely, nice sand and great swimming conditions.The Dolphins are wonderful and the Dolphin Quest team is very friendly and helpful.Service at Hoku’s was excellent. The food was of a good standard - not great, but better than the rest of the resort food.The BadThe cabanas. Normally you can rent for an hour but over the holiday period you have to take for the whole day. The second cabana we booked took over an hour to deliver and they are like mini torture chambers – very hard and not long enough to hold a standard person.The rooms – while large they are poorly laid out and you have to perform a contortion act to get into the tiny toilet cubicle which seems smaller than an aircraft toilet room.The food and service at Plumeria for an evening meal was ghastly.The beds are not comfortable.The UglyAs previous reviewers have mentioned not getting the bedding configuration you booked and how the front desk staff handle this. We too booked back in August and ended up with the two single beds instead of a King size bed. An argument ensued at check in which was not handled at all well by the check in staff who seemed to blame us for not knowing that this was their policy. It is ridiculous when you are paying $1000 per night that this is “on request”. Imagine the plight of a honeymoon couple booking a king size room and ending up with two single beds! Beyond a joke.The breakfast situation is the worst we have experienced at any hotel. Based on the reviews we tried booking a time for breakfast, but even that didn’t work – we were kept waiting almost 45 minutes after our reservation time for a table. First you queue to register then you queue to wait for a table – there is no waiting area so you are left standing the entire time. The frustrating part is that there is no reason for this – there are plenty of empty tables, it is just very poorly managed.To sum up, the resort has huge potential but it is very poorly managed.

I note there have been plenty of positive reviews of the Kahala Hotel and Resort. I would like to offer a different perspective. First thing to consider is that this is a very expensive property. Rooms cost more than $750 a night in peak season, breakfast not included.Second is that demand is so strong for Hawaiian hotels - 2012 will an all-time record year for visitations - that the hotels in Waikiki/Honoloulu don't have to try for business, it just walks through the door. The knock-on effect is that some staff, especially at the Kahala's front desk, are good at saying "Aloha" and "Mahalo" but out of their depth when there's a genuine issue.I would argue that they are blind to the basic needs and expectations of customers, such as that you'll get the room you have paid for. In our case that was a garden view room with two double beds. Check-in was from 3pm but our family of four - including two teenagers - was not given a room key until 40 minutes later. No staff member approached us during this time to offer hospitality of any kind - drinks, snacks whatever. In Asia, at this kind of rate, we would have been fawned over. Anyway, I got the key and checked out the room which had a double king bed and nothing else in it. In other words it was not the room we had booked. I returned to the front desk and dealt with another receptionist, told her brusquely we had the wrong room, please fix it. She is a little taken aback and informs me that there is no guarantee at the Kahala you will get the room you have booked. She says it's not a firm booking we have made but a "request" for two double beds in the same room.I check the fine print and she is right. Two double beds is classified as a "service request". There is no guarantee we will get what we paid $2,290.64 over three nights for. We made the booking and paid 75% in August, the balance in October.No-one from the property has contacted during this time to advise that the room we had booked, requested or whatever would not be available. So, our expectation was that it would be.Anyway, I get angry, we've been waiting forever, paid $750 a night for truly awful service, drop the f-bomb as in just "f_______ fix it" and walk away. We wait another 20 or 30 minutes, again no one offers any kind of hospitality, until my wife approaches the front desk and told "great news, we have a room for you".I take a look and there are two large single beds, a chaise lounge and a rollaway bed to accommodate our family. Again, not what we had asked for - or so we thought. At least give us another rollaway bed and get rid of the chaise, which had no bedding.We are later informed that we have in fact been given two double beds. Huh? They look so small. We measure and find they are 1.4m wide, big enough for a couple of honeymooning midgets but not much else. I've just checked with Wikipedia and the official US double bed measurement is 1.9m - 500mm larger than what the Kahala is calling a double bed.But I digress. We are still upset at the lack of hospitality we have received and ask for breakfast to be included and instead get into an argument with the receptionist who does nothing at all to defuse the situation. Instead, she further inflames matters by blaming us.At no stage over the preceding 90 minutes has any staff acknowledged that a series of errors from the hotel has brought us to this point. We have been offered zero hospitality. Somehow they think it is all our fault.The customer service director is brought in one assumes to calm matters. Instead she adds fuel to the fire. Another staff member joins in and adds another voice to the argument, the hotel's voice of course.By now the volume is up. Loud but not shouting. Again, I repeat, no effort has been made to defuse the situation. In fact, the customer service director says something like "ok that's it, I am calling security" with the implied threat we are getting kicked out of the hotel.For what? Sticking up for ourselves? Raising our voices in an argument that is 90% down to the Kahala not fulfilling its obligations - not one of them - as an elite hotel charging $750 a night.Who knows. The fact is that Honolulu./Waikiki is totally told out. It is two days before New Year's Eve and there is literally nowhere for us to go. Somehow we get the keys back, go to the room and try to calm down.My wife, who worked as a flight attendant at Qantas for 14 years, is incredibly upset. The staff have been doing nothing but sticking up for themselves and their mistakes, then call security to sort it out.It's bizarre.I later speak with the front desk manager who was aware of the fracas at the time it was happening but did nothing to intervene. I ask him why did this occur and he once again offers the hotel's perspective, which is essentially that nothing is guaranteed.He does not acknowledge the lack of hospitality we received while waiting for the room ("we only say check-in is after 3pm, not at 3pm"), and also attempts to justify offering us a king room with a single bed for four people, the basic error that led to everything else.I ask him to make my wife happy. He sends up a bottle of domestic sparkling wine and a note that offers no apology just the message: "We hope you are feeling better".He offers also breakfast as token but, not as it turns out, for all of us. Just two people from our family of four get breakfast on the house, everyone else must pay.As for the hotel and infrastructure, it's quite nice but nothing special. Great location, small pool, crowded, decent beach. Guests - lot of Japanese and a mix of other nationalities.Breakfast buffet is average, the food at Plumeria good, as is the wine list.For these reasons I will give the property two stars. If this was only on service, the Kahala would get nothing.In summary, front desk staff are poorly trained and have no idea of genuine hospitality or how to deal with a guest with a justifiable complaint. A bit of customer service 101 would have nipped this whole thing in the bud.Of course, that did not happen.In fact it was the customer service director who called security rather than making her guests feel special.It's so ridiculous, you just have to laugh.

My wife and I took the kids to Kahala last June and had a wonderful time, so when we were deciding on a vacation for just the two of us the Kahala was the perfect choice. For the most part, our December trip met or exceeded our expectations. The rooms are magnificent and the views from our fourth floor mounain side room were great. We enjoy the retro design of the hotel along with the modern interiors. If smoking was allowed and people dressed more formally these days you could imagine that you were in a Mad Men episode. The pool and the beach were perfect places to relax when it wasn't windy or rainy. I thought the breakfast buffet at plumeria was a good value, especially if you can eat late enough to make it more of a brunch that will get you to dinner. We also had a wonderful dinner at Hoku. We had two criticisms. As with our prior trip, the service at the pool and beach, as well as the lobby bar, can be spotty. There are some very good folks working outside, to be sure, but some of them are slow. A couple of the waitresses at the Vernanda seemed downright unfriendly. When I asked one of the waitresses about my bill--I thought I was being billed twice for the same drinks--she told me that she was sure she hadn't made a mistake and she "had not been drinking." Again, there were a couple of very good waitresses at Veranda, but a couple of them are probably in the wrong line of work. I will say that the food at Veranda as well as outside is excellent, especially the nachos and burgers. And the drinks were very good as well. The other criticism I share with some of the other reviewers is that the seafood buffett was a real disappointment, especially given the price. I expected overflowing amounts of fish, clams, lobsters, oysters, etc. The food at this buffett did not meet expectations.All of that said, it was a wonderful trip. We love the class, charactor, and elegance of the Kahala and will go back. But for the service issues we would give the place five stars.

We have stayed many times at the Kahala over the years through its various incarnations; in the days it was a Hilton, a Mandarin Oriental, and now with its current (non-affiliated) owner. Things have never been better at this classy and elegant resort a few miles from Waikiki.I used to tell people the service at Kahala suffered from a slight air of haughtiness that always tainted our stay. That is GONE...nothing but sincere and friendly smiles to make sure your stay is as pleasurable as possible. The outside hotel structure which epitomizes some of the more outdated ideas of building design from the 60's gives no hint to the elegance you will encounter within.From the drive-up and efficient (and free!) valet service, prompt and courteous counter check-in, you are ushered to your room with luggage and given explanations about the resort. We had a seamless experience. There was never any hint of an expected tip (although of course we did).The spacious rooms have been slightly updated to be more modern with a cool palette rather than the traditional mix of Polynesian and Boston colonial furniture (the traditional Hawaiian mix since missionary days) they used to have. The room was impeccably and absolutely clean. Everything was in perfect order. Internet service was complimentary. The bathrooms remain unchanged with two sinks, two closets, separate shower and bath and a huge array of lotions and complimentary supplies. If you pick up the phone, they know your name. Housekeeping and turn down service was discreet.Their main hotel restaurant, The Plumeria Beach House (aka Plumeria Cafe) which borders their beautiful, private sandy beach has been reverted back to a tropical garden theme, and service and food is friendly, effiicient, carefully prepared..and delicious. Choose to sit on the patio if it is a nice day. The breakfast buffet is back to its top-notch offering; of course at $31/person now, the price is top-notch too (we were offered and accepted a price break of 50% for two including tip and taxes if we pre-paid at the time of our reservation). High quality ingredients and careful preparation. This is easily one of our favorite eating spots in Hawaii.I'm sure others will say they prefer the Halekulani and that their very reason for being on Oahu is to enjoy and be a part of the hustle-and-bustle of urban Waikiki and if that is why then certainly stay there, but if you want to enjoy the amenities of Honolulu and Oahu without being directly in Waikiki, the Kahala is an oasis of peace and gracious living that I highly recommend.

Our family had celebrated many milestones here at the Kahala Hotel. I remembered the quiet, elegant service, the beautiful settings, the amazing view and the delicious food. May it be brunch with my folks, birthday celebrations or weddings, we all left delighted and extremely happy. This property has been THE HOTEL in Honolulu; its name would garner a bit of envy and praise. Unfortunately, the locals only speak of it with nostalgia; the Kahala hotel is a "has been," with falling standard of service. The location of this hotel is excellent; adjoining the Waialae Country Club and with its own strip of beach. It is extremely private but with very easy access to Waikiki; furthermore, the small Kahala Mall is just a stone throw away. The lobby is still exactly as I remembered: grand and beautiful. It was exquisite to see the sun slowly resting over the horizon, to feel the trade wind gently circling and to smell the very impressive Christmas tree towering over the lobby.We had excellent reception by the valet; luggage were quickly retrieved and delivered to our room. The check in took a little longer than expected, but this allowed me to relive nostalgia. We had a room in the lagoon wing overlooking the country club. The living space is well appointed and the bed is extremely comfortable; in fact, it is quite large for Honolulu standard. However, the bathroom is in need of a major face lift. I don't know if this meant to be part of the ambiance, but cracks on the tile and cabinets and chips on the furniture seemed a bit out of place. Also, the Tommy Bahama brand toiletries are a bit odd; it doesn't fit the over feel of this hotel.As I walked down the corridor, I see the signature markings of this once Mandarin Oriental: there are beautiful pieces of furniture and Ming vase lamps. The tranquility and the soothing glows of the setting sun were simply amazing. Of course, this blessed evening was marred by the forgettable dinner at the Plumeria Restaurant.Plumeria is one of those nuisance flowers that grows everywhere on the island, and it rots quickly. This restaurant has very similar qualities: very common, over priced and understaffed. As reviewed by Glenn B, the buffet is $55 per person and the offering is very underwhelmed compared to other establishments in this buffet-rich city. There were large parties, and the food were gone quickly, but took quite a while to be replenished. The hostess and manager were in foul mood that night and servers were assigned too many tables to offer adequate service.An otherwise pleasant stay was scarred by misinformation given by the morning receptionist. We were to be stranded at the hotel and to miss our flight due to the start of the Honolulu Marathon. Our hearts skipped a bit, but we got out and arrived at the airport in plenty of time. So much for a pleasant lasting impression.We would stay here again for the location, and living quarter is quite good. The valet and bell hop are first rate. However, I can see why this hotel is not quite five star. The management has changed so frequently in the past that this once grand dame of Honolulu is having a bit of identity crisis. A grand lobby with chipped bathroom, Tommy Bahama theme toiletries, Denny-like food and service just don't harmonize.

We only had one night at the Kahala during a recent cruise holiday, but wished we could have spent several days there. Beautiful property, enormous rooms (and quiet!), and a totally relaxed atmosphere. Would highly recommend!

Great staff, great location, mildly over-priced. You can get more bang-for-your-buck on Oahu in Waikiki or Ko'Olina... but Kahala is away from the hustle-and-bustle of Waikiki, but close enough to the action for a short taxi ride away if that is your thing.Dolphin show is great for the kids, beach is nice, protected unless there is a big south swell. Average grounds- it's Hawaii, but I've seen better landscaping at similar class resorts.Did I say a great staff?The server at the lobby bar/lounge area open in the evening I found to be a little on the salty side, but by and large everyone else at this resort was great.As a local I've stayed at resorts on Maui, Big Island, Kauai and Oahu, and do so fairly regularly for work so I feel like I've got a good grasp of the market and what is available here.Stayed one night for a sunrise wedding on 12/12/12, and I don't think you could ask for a better staff to plan your wedding- Amy, the wedding planner, is VERY good, and for someone coming from the mainland, she will make your special day a true delight. Highly recommend her.Otherwise, it's all about the name at the Kahala- it's pretty much the top name resort you can stay at on Oahu, but that's more because of the location and heritage. (Kahala neighborhood is one of Hawaii's wealthiest)As other local reviewers have noted here, it's really not that special... there are better beaches, better sunsets, and better locations, but the Kahala has a special feel to it and has played host to a number of celebrities over the years, probably more because of it's seclusion yet proximity to town. (Check out the wall of celebrities- it seems like every A-list actor from Hollywood present or past has stayed here)Looking for 'The' name-brand high-end resort on Oahu? This is it. Looking for the best in value amenities, sunsets and beaches? There are better, newer resorts... but this one will certainly do... just be prepared to pay a premium for the name.

It has been a few years since we've traveled to Honolulu, but have always stayed at the Kahala (since I was a child and it was the Kahala Hilton) and have seen it undergo many changes. However, during this most recent stay we were not disappointed - it is still my favorite place to stay when visiting Oahu. The location is perfect - away from the hustle and bustle of Waikiki yet a short, convenient drive to the action there. The dolphin lagoon is always a pleasure to observe and the pool area and beach are perfect for relaxing. Dined at Hoku's, which is a true culinary experience and I do not plan on waiting so long in the future to return to the Kahala. A perfect few day get away from the pace of everyday life.

This hotel is beautiful and the people here are so friendly and helpful... A place you must stay at!!!The breakfast was to die for, it had everything you can image. The lobby was decorated with Christmas trees and it looked great. The rooms are big and very clean.

Beautiful spot, so booked and identified it as my wife's birthday. Advertised as a seafood buffet with lobster and crab work station. In fact the work station was seafood pasta. No lobster, no crab. Lots of mussels. Cost of $55 each is expensive for a pasta dinner. Buffet items overall flavours quite similar, lots of cream sauces. the starch was fried rice! Nothing done about the birthday event. Finally, we were sitted near the bar and smokers light up just outside a nearby open door, which filled our area with smoke. Hawaii is like France in that non-smoking is a very poorly understood principle. Never going back. Much, much better seafood buffet is on weekends at the Prince Waikiki. On a birthday they will give you a small cake with a candle.
user_name:
Glenn B
Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada

review_body: We have been coming to the Kahala for several years and love the location and staff. This trip we found some changes. They appeared to be cost saving measures, although the room prices are not reflective of the changes. You no longer get fresh leis but plastic type ones. For a luxury hotel, it seemed a bit on the cheap side. In the room, the toiletries were no longer the French ones that they used for years but Tommy Bahama. They were okay. My biggest complaint was there were no coffee cups in the rooms only paper ones. Really? An expensive, luxury hotel with only paper cups in the rooms for coffee. The breakfast buffet no longer allows you to get your own juice, you must ask for it. In addition, the selection of pastries and other items has been scaled back.We love the location and the spaciousness of the rooms. However, our bathroom tile was chipped and marred, again not indicative of a luxury hotel. We do love the beach here and the rooms but would hope they would do a bit more maintenance to be at the level of a luxury, pricey hotel.

This is our sixth stay at The Kahala. Prior to coming to The Kahala, we usually stayed at the hotels in Wakiki. Wakiki simply became too crowed and the beach is jammed packed; no longer a pleasure to spend a week, a day maybe. (take the Kahala shuttle to Wakiki Beach)Kahala is about 15 minutes east of Wakiki. Located at the end of Kahala Avenue (the most coveted address in Honolulu, I think), it is secluded with lovely surroundings. Without big waves and a gentle slope, swimming in the ocean is a pleasure. (only beach that I can swim without getting knocked about by waves) Best of all, i've never seen more than 10 swimmers at one time.Delicious buffet breakfast is pricey but if your vacation package includes, it is a fabulous treat especially if you go at 6:15 AM and watch the sunrise as you enjoy the freshly cooked omelette, incredible pastries and of course,fresh fruits.Downsides: the pool is dated, small, and less than five feet deep. This resort is not design for children, except very young ones. With the exception of dolphins, it is not a children friendly resort. It is designed for weddings, multiple weddings in one day. Parking is expensive and no street parking available.

My husband and I were on a two week vacation on Hawaii and we were staying at the Kahala for our first 3 nights. We cannot speak highly enough of this hotel. It was our first time there and will certainly not be our last. Our accommodation was top notch, very spacious and the bathroom was excellent with his and her sinks at either end of the room, separate bath and large shower, fridge and safe, plenty of hanging space in the bathroom, again his and hers. We had a large balcony with partial view of the ocean (normally we prefer ocean front but the view we had was great with the golf course, mountains and homes at the back and the ocean to the side). The breakfasts were excellent although we only ever had the continental which gave us ample choice without needing any of the cooked options. Unfortunately we didn't get to try Hokus restaurant as I was unwell the night we had booked so had to cancel our reservation. We can both thoroughly recommend this hotel, the location is a little away from the downtown area but that suited us as it was really quiet and we had a rental car anyway. The actual pool area was a little small but the beach was just adjacent with very comfortable beds and full amenities so that's where we did our relaxing in the sun and swimming in the ocean. The dolphin attraction was wonderful, we didn't actually swim with them ourselves but watched others and did a lot of filming. So to sum up, luxury accommodation, staff were extremely friendly and helpful, service was exemplary, overall experience first class.

My husband and I stayed here quite a few months ago, so my review is a bit delayed (remembered that I forgot to review when I logged in to TA today...).This property was a bit far from the downtown area, but we had a car, so we didn't mind and we actually enjoyed being away from the noise and commotion of downtown. The hotel did offer a complementary shuttle, but we always opted for our own vehicle, so I cannot speak to the shuttle service.Our room was absolutely gorgeous on the top floor overlooking the ocean. I loved sleeping with the veranda doors open and never had an issue with bugs coming in. The room was large and mostly well-maintained. I really enjoyed the separate vanities in the bathroom, which made getting ready in the morning much easier for two people. The bedding was also extremely comfortable.Our rate also included breakfast. Wow! This had to be one of the best breakfast options that I've ever had as included! Fresh squeezed juices, omelets, pancakes and waffles and fresh fruit, yogurt, etc. There were enough options that I could have eaten there all day. I'd definitely recommend trying to get a breakfast-included rate though as it was quite expensive if you paid separately. There were also a few other dining options on property that we found to be good (food and service), but nothing over-the-top spectacular.The beach and pool areas were also very clean and beautiful. I especially love the privacy of the beach and the little island that juts out (makes for some great photos). We never had a problem with getting chairs, towels, etc.The service was also attentive. The front desk staff was very accommodating for a few special requests that we had such as check cashing, recommendations, etc. They also promptly took care of a problem with our original reservation.

We booked with the Kahala after getting a good deal with Expedia. We knew full well it was an expensive 'resort' from the start but we were not happy with a few things when staying here.PROS:The valet/bell boys out the front were great, friendly, and always had some cold water and a beach towel for us.The food at the Seaside grill was actually quite good even though it was a bit expensiveThe dolphins, swimming pool and beach were all really niceThe bed was comfy and amazingCONS:Everything costs extra - want an umbrella? Sit in the shaded bungalow? Borrow a pool toy? They all cost extra. Even when there were only a few people by the pool, staff still wanted to charge for the bungalows.The shuttle bus to Waikiki only starts at 10am and last pickup is 9:45pm. For such a large hotel, one bus per hour that holds 12 people is not sufficient. We would have spent over $300 in cab fares just to get to Waikiki and back during our 10 day stay. I'm sure you can afford a second shuttle bus that runs on the half hour and for longer hours?No information/out of date info: No-one told us to book the shuttle, we had to learn that the hard way by not being allowed on and having to pay for a cab. The info book in the room mentioned a sushi restaurant - after walking around trying to find it we learnt it had been shut down.WiFi was hit and miss, and we were only on the 1st floor.We were not allowed to have a late checkout on our last day, when were were doing a Pearl Harbour tour - forcing us to check out at 5:45am and leave our bags in storage. I know they were not that busy as to need the room straight away.No free breakfast - even the cheapest Holiday Inns have free breakfast, come on guys. There isn't even a microwave in the room either, just a small fridge.In short, unless all you want to do is sit by a pool or the beach, this is an expensive inconvenient hotel. We were on our honeymoon and apart from some champagne in the room on the first night, we felt that the service was not up to the price of our stay.

Stayed here for four nights, staff and service were exemplary. Restaurant meals were excellent and the overall experience was first class. Location in Kahala is quiet and far from the noisy Waikiki beach area.

This hotel is a place that my family has gone to every Thanksgiving for the past several years. In addition, I went as a child thru my teens during Christmas vacation for ten years. Wonderful, for families, special secluded spots or weddings, and honeymoon couples. Fantastic lobby that is beautifully decorated for all the holidays. All the food is delicious! My favorite is the macadamia nut thin rolled pancakes. Looking forward to my next trip back to the Kahala.

The hotel's location on the beach is fabulous. Hotel premises,however, have seen better days. Also, the staff at the reception desk was not that friendly or helpful. Pool is very small and also in need of an update. Don't think the resort warrants the high cost of their rooms. We will return to Maui for our next vacation.

We stayed here for our Honeymoon and it couldnt have been any better!We got an upgrade to a suite, lei and champange on arrival and the staff were just so friendly!The room was gorgeous and spacious, we had 2 windows with different aspects so it really was gorgeous waking up everyday especially looking out and seeing the dolphins swimming and jumping around!everything about the hotel was just perfect, the pool was nice and quiet, you only have to take a stroll onto the beach and the food was unreal!!They operate a shuttle bus back and fro from waikiki, which is about 15 mins away, but it was fine as the bus was regular. The only thing was that it stopped pretty early in the evening, but you cant really fault them on that who would want to be driving around at all hours of the night! A taxi back to the hotel didnt cost that much so it really wasnt an issue.I just cant say enough about thsi hotel, its by far the best hotel we have ever stayed in! You didn't feel out of place there either like you can in some fancy hotels, you knew it was very high class but everyone was welcome!

We stayed at the Kahala resort for only a couple of days, but they were magical. Had a room on the 9th floor with a spectacular view of the ocean. We could look down and see the dolphins at the dolphin quest enclosure swimming to their hearts content. Very spacious and well appointed room. The resort is a quiet refuge.. on the opposite side of Diamond Head from Waikiki beach. Very charming and sedate! Just what we were looking for. Staff was very accomodating and friendly.

Just gotten back from a stay at the Kahala Resort. We booked 2 rooms @ Mountain Lanai overlooking the lush Waialae Golf course. Ocean-view will cost a lot more. We had stayed here a few times in the past. In its glory days, it was an exclusive enclave built by the late Baron Hilton where the Rich and Famous and Holloywood set gravitated. There is an impressive photo-ops and words written by past famous guests lining a wall, including Kings and Queens. The latest movie guest staying here was George Clooney when he was filming the movie 'The Descendants'.PRO:* Subliminal beach setting* Extremely private and relaxing. No cell phones heard at the beach.* Friendly staff * Staff Karen/Roger coordinated & arranged a seamless tennis day at the Waialae Country Club down the road.* Great customer service from Dianah (sp ?) at the Business Center & Randy at Plumeria restaurantCon:* Rooms are older, no rain showers or up-to-date stuff like phones & TV's in bathrooms* Better buffet spread and quality of towels and bed linen when the hotel was managed by Mandarin Oriental Hotel* For value rendered, would not pay rack rates, but special deals like stay 4-and-pay-3 with breakfasts included are value for the money. Must stay at a lanai room inorder to fully enjoy the super views* Free shuttle serive got booked up quickly when we were there. At high season, it would likely be hard to get by. On previous occasions, we rented a car or took taxi to Waikiki, Ala Moana and dinners.SUMMARYThis is more like a place to kick off your shoes and totally relax. I would not compare Kahala Hotel to the 4-Seasons or Mandarin Orientals except perhaps to the Oriental in Bangkok for its imbued history. When in Honolulu, we stay at either the Halekulani or Kahala. They are different. You're buying a particular kind experience with each. 'No muss, no fuss' if you don't go looking for deficiencies at Kahala due to the age of the property.

We recently stayed at the Kahala for 9 nights. The room overlooking the dolphin pool and ocean was beautiful. Breakfast that was included daily with the room was incomparable with fresh fruits and juices and an enormous variety of foods. The staff was great. The only downside was the up-charge for an umbrella on the beach and for lack of flexibility for a late check-out. We requested a 4-hour extension of check-out time because of a late flight time and were offered a 2-hour extension for an $80 up charge.
user_name:
Gabpt
New York City, New York

review_body: The keyword to this review is $35.00…remember, $35.00.I just returned from an 8 day vacation to Honolulu, HI, and had a great time EXCEPT for my short visit to the Kahala Hotel & Resort.A friend of mine who lives in Honolulu wanted to take me there to see the dolphin lagoon and the sea turtle pond, and to see the grounds.We pulled up to the parking lot, he pulled a ticket out of the machine, and drove around to find a parking space.I enjoyed seeing the dolphins and the sea turtles, and took a few pictures of the waterfall and the lava rock orchid wall.We considered eating lunch there, but decided not to because I didn’t feel like paying $20 for a hamburger or $18 for a chicken sandwich, figuring it would probably be ho-hum, typical hotel restaurant food/service. So we left. (Turns out other reviewers on this site confirmed my suspicions.)Upon exiting my friend handed the ticket to the guy in the parking booth, and the guy said, “$35”. That’s it – just said, “$35”.So I said, “What?!?!”, and my friend asked, “How long were we here?”The answer: “1 hour”We were both in shock, and the guy said if we’d spent $25 in the hotel they would have validated the ticket, but there was no clear signage as we entered the parking lot that showed that!o.k. we decided not to argue the issue, and my friend handed the parking attendant his Visa card, and was told, “Cash only”.Friend didn’t have that much cash on him at the time – and luckily I’d put some cash in my wallet for the days outing; I don’t usually carry cash with me, but it’s a good thing I did that day!Hmmmm, I wonder what would have happened if we hadn’t had the 35 dollars in cash?All that said, I realize Honolulu is a very expensive city to visit, and typically parking garages/lots in big cities are very expensive – but 35 bucks for ONE HOUR?!! C’mon!!I realize, too, that we should have probably stopped to read the fine print on the sign before we pulled in to the hotel – but we didn’t. Actually, I’m not quite sure it was even posted; in hindsight we should have looked closer. But when I’m a passenger in a car, I don’t think of such things.Another reviewer wrote of a similar experience back in June of this year. Apparently the Kahala has started this parking fee policy since my friend had lasted visited, and he wasn’t aware of it.The grounds were nice – nothing particularly special – the Hilton Hawaiian Village is way more spectacular! The dolphins & turtles were cute, but I sure as heck don’t think seeing them was worth 35 bucks!Doing some research after our “$35 Kahala experience”, I learned that the Kahala Hotel & Resort is supposedly one of Honolulu’s more “classy” hotels, so they figure they can charge this outrageous parking fee for the casual visitor. Apparently they figure that’s the “price of admission for looking at 'classy'”. Personally, I think it’s ludicrous to have that kind of a minimum parking fee, and I will never, ever go back to that place again. I think their parking rate and policy sucks!So, I’m just writing this to warn others: BEWARE!! If you plan to visit the Kahala for a short visit, be prepared to pay for it.Final note: In view of the fact that I paid just $70 (with a discount coupon) to park my car in a parking lot near Phoenix Airport for the entire 8 DAYS I was in Honolulu, it makes the whole “$35 Kahala experience” seem even more ludicrous!

We just returned from the Kahala after a 10 day/9 night stay. I would echo MikeK's review completely actually but would also like to add a few other points.To the good. The valets greeting you are exceptional. Always with a smile wishing you a good day and welcoming you back. They easily and freely gave directions, and recommendations for local attractions and eateries. Far more knowledgable than the concierge actually.Housekeeping was okay. They did an excellent job tidying up but timing always seemed to be off. Given we had a few days with a conference with set itineries I felt that the staff should be aware of when guests would be in room or out and make them up accordingly as well as turn down service. (they generally showed up at the door at 6pm for turndown as we were trying to get ready for evening events or activities on our own)The concierge was not very knowledgable about dinner recommendations, or general hotel policy truth be told. Without someone at the activities desk all the time or at guest services full time the logical next choice would be the concierge. Take my word for it and ask the Valets. Wifi in our room was spotty at best. Two days it was excellent. 7 days I had little luck staying connected. I had a much better connection on the beach. On our last two days I mentioned it to the concierge and our modem was replaced but it was placed on top of the garbage can. I would advise whomever placed it in the room that perhaps the desk above would have been a better location. The electrical plug in our bathroom was also faulty. If you fiddled with your curling iron just so you might get it to stay working. It was a gfi plug so I reset it assuming perhaps it had tripped. No...it was just poorly wired. Fortunately there was another mirror in the toilet room. There actually were very few plugs in the room at all. We had utilized all the plugs around the desk to charge phones, and ipads. I need a cpap so I had to unplug the light beside the bed if I wanted to charge my camera battery overnight and use my cpap.Overall the hotel was nice. It could use some updating. The rooms are very spacious. Our "ocean view" was hardly that. (Leaning off the edge of the balcony to see the ocean is not what I call an ocean view. ) Given we spent little time in the room and we were paying a conference rate that did not bother me too much but we also stayed an extra 6 nights in addition to the conference so one would hope that would have been taken into consideration when allocating rooms. If I had paid regular rates I would have been less than amused.We had no issues with the beach staff unlike the previous poster. $26 for an umbrella is a little pricey and I hate being nickel and dimed after checking in but we bit the bullet and learned not to rent an umbrella again. The wait staff in the restaurants were wonderful. The quiet beach delightful.There just seemed to be something lacking. Looking at their regular rates (not corporate conference rates) I would expect exceptional. Other 5 stars in that price range we've stayed in have been exceptional. Ritz Carlton, Fairmont, etc. It seems the Kahala is trying to catch up to the times living off it's former glory. I think it can be exceptional again. When paying top dollar for a hotel one expects not to have to worry about a broken coffee pot, electrical plug, modem. etc. I would stay again for under $325 a night but would not stay again over that rate.

While the beach property is terrific and the rooms spacious, I have been disappointed with very average & disinterested service, overall feel of the pool area being run down and unappealing, all while the prices of everything are more expensive than a Four Seasons. This is the final stop on a three island vacation (with a work conference for 3 days) - I could not be more positive on all aspects of our stay at the Grand Hyatt in Kauai and at the Four Seasons in Kona -- 2 hotels that exceeded my expectation for beauty, fantastic service, exceptional food and stunning pool and ocean areas. As I read the reviews, maybe the hotel stills believes in its legacy as a leading hotel - but management should visit some of the higher ranked hotels to figure out what it will take to bring this place back to its legacy. More importantly, the service staff are not fitting for a top-notch hotel, for example: concierge staff had limited knowledge or willingness to help, even getting a couple of chairs set up by the pool seemed to be a hassle - while others in the hotel have been better, just not excellent. It is clearly time to revisit what the Kahala wants to be; either lower prices and be a four star, or make some substantial changes to compete with a Four Seasons or even Grand Hyatt.

Hello. We visited here for our Honeymoon in October. Mr Kalozois. The following review is 100% honest and not seeking anything from the hotel, for either good or bad comments. Room Type: Partial Ocean Lanai - $700 p/n including breakfast. Check-in:Lays on arrival. Extremely friendly staff, from bell staff to check in desk. 5/5 here. Rooms:Complimentary Brut for our honeymoon was appreciated. Unfortunately we found an empty water bottle underneath our dresser on arrival. Bath tap dripping. Strange tapping noise from air conditioning. Nice CD music - hawaiian music playing on arrival. Nice wicker fan adds to look of room. Great beds. Awfully large LCD screen bolted to wall, smaller LED tv would be expected in hotel of this standard. Expensive pay per view movies, and very limited non HD offerings on television.Very nice bath robes. Good selection of bathing products. Poor floor tiling in bathroom area. Broken thermostat in shower, didn't compromise use, but plastic handle easily came away from fixing. Excellent room service. Excellent housekeeping after initial bottle under dresser. Very very friendly housekeeper. Extra coffee left upon request. Nice view. Dining:Excellent buffet, but expensive if not included. Valued at $90+ per couple. Spotty service, good one day, not so great the next. Even when breakfast is included the bill is shoved under your nose immediately after sitting down. Our table was completely cleared when we went to get a plate of food together. Overly eager to get you out. One would expect sincere apology and a rush to get cutlery and drinks back to table. Not so, some ten minutes waiting for this. No apology, but laughs from the staff. Not impressed here. Hoku restaurant barman asked for ID from us even though we were in their system, we are 27 and 31 respectively. Not worried as is law, but expect they could check ages on system instead of embarrassing us in front of other guests. Very expensive, and cocktails so so. Better value in Waikiki beach. Service impeccable from waiting staff they received a very large cash tip, as we did not want bar staff to share. Complimentary water at various points within hotel. Overall dining could be improved but buffet at breakfast offered great choices and quality. Beach/ pool area:Exceptional service upon asking for towels and chair covers. Staff will set you up on the beach or by the pool without you asking and do so with a smile. I tipped $2 each time for this. Very happy with this service. Quiet beach area was appreciated. $25 charge for umbrella was steep, but considering the staff have to dig a hole and position it each time, is understandable. $100 for cabana was very steep and not necessary. Quality low. Not net curtains but canvas, and steel not wood. Small pool but not many using it so this was acceptable. Excellent service at pool side bar, very pleased here. Excellent staff. Prices reasonable. $15 for burger and fries. We were told that the hotel is non smoking so we paid extra for a partial ocean lanai which is smoking. We waited until in the room or went to designated smoking area to have a cigarette. Unfortunately double standards allowed guests to smoke on the beach as it is classed as public property. Upon complaining I was informed there was nothing that could be done. In terms of law, fair enough, but feel this double standard let the hotel down wildly. This upset me greatly. Additional services/ amenities:Shuttle service into town is booked up extremely quickly and no second run if overbooked. They would also take you out and leave you there if not return space is available forcing between $20-40 return taxi dependant on drop off point. Surprised at this.Dolphin lagoon is dreamlike. Early morning feeding was wonderful, impromptu show of jumping was spectacular and the trainers were friendly and informative about the dolphins and lagoon. Excellent addition to the hotel. $125 experience, seemed good value. Shops in hotel expensive, but cater for the type of clientelle expected.Limited evening activities, forces you into Waikiki too often. Overall:Service was exceptional. Let down by a few points of carelessness and double standards with smoking.We would stay again, but would hope these points of contention are ironed out before returning. Hotel manager and staff do their jobs very well, and cannot control everything, but one would hope the information filters to the people who can make a difference. Aloha!x

The Kahala seems like the ideal hotel for my grandparents, a family with kids, or a wedding. Everything about the hotel is very nice without being extraordinary--the food, the pool, the beach.My room was nicer than I had expected. I was upgraded to a "partial ocean view" but it seemed like a full and very beautiful ocean view to me. The room is nicely laid out and reminded me of a hawaiian version of rooms at the Lungarno hotel in Florence. The bathroom was very large and spotless (the entire hotel is very clean, especially for a tropical location) and the Tommy Bahama soaps were nice (although I had heard the hotel stocked floris soap in the past). I was only in hawaii briefly but wanted a tropical resort feeling without flying to Kauai, and the Kahala was a perfect place for this. It delivers a lot for the prices it charges.
user_name:
Gandaratravels
New York City, New York

review_body: The Kahala stands on one of the most beautiful sites I have ever seen. The Paciifc ocean ahead; the golf course behind; a dolphin pool with six very playful dolphins on the side. There are two swimming pools for adults. There are more pools for fish, including giant turtles. It is paradise on earth. BUT, and it is a shame there are a few "buts" all is not perfect. Surely someone should have taken us to our room when we arrived and shown us how all the gadget there worked. Surely the mini-bar should have been stocked and,when I asked for beers, wine, etc., I should not have had to pay a service charge. The lavatory inside the gorgeous bathroom was too small - you had to wriggle to get inside the door. And, writing about lavatories, the ones by the main pool were a disgrace. Again tiny, and often smelly. Also, just one cubicle for men and one for women, certainly not enough for all the guests. The restaurants were not bad but not that good either. There were only two to choose from, again not enough for a large hotel like the Kahala. The bar between the pool and the sea was charming, however, and the service superb. I had not been to the Kahala for 31 years. If it wasn't so far from the UK I'd go back like a shot BUT the hotel management should look at some of the small criticisms I made - particularly at the lack of restaurants and the sameness of the menus.

This is still a member of 'Leading Hotels of the World',as well as having other memberships.It now appears to be part of Japanese Okura group.The rooms and public areas are still very good and well maintained.The real let down is in area of restaurants .Despite brochures in rooms,hand outs on check-in stating that there is a Grill & a Japanese restaurant,these are now closed.All that is left is snacky food around pool and on veranda and in nearby lounge.The main restaurant,'Hoku's'is closed Mon-Tues so that leaves only 'Plumeria' open 7 days.Hoku's is a high class restaurant and very good.Sadly Plumeria is the breakfast buffet lunch restaurant with a very ordinary small dinner menu.Quality is the same. It was interesting to note that on the Wed night I was in Hoku's,is was a completely different crowd from the previous 2 nights in Plumeria.

Stayed here for my birthday with my fiance. Absolutely wonderful service and a special dessert waiting in the room when we checked in. The staff are friendly and accomodating. This was our third time we have stayed here. The food is delicious at the restaurants, the whole fish at Hoku's is the best! It's great for overnighters and short getaways. The beach is perfect for sunning and pool is right there too. Love the convenience of being so close to everything but yet not in the middle of Waikiki. Parking is free so you can come and go as you please. The Dolphin Quest people are very informative, what a wonderful dream job!

We spent the last night of our honeymoon at the Kahala resort. We had just spent a week in Maui, so to be fair,there is nothing that can compare to that. Oahu was a overly crowded, hectic place. If we had known what it was going to be like we would have enjoyed one more day in beautiful Maui. The Kahala is a beautiful hotel, but just not as beautiful for the $$$$ you fork out to stay there. We saw hotels that were better for less in different areas. We were supposed to have been allowed a "honeymoon upgrade", which was a joke. We actually ended up paying them even more money to see the ocean instead of the parking lot. I'm pretty sure if they could charge you for the air there, they would. The plus side of this hotel is the private beach... that was the best thing about staying here. If you have seen any of the other hotels in this area, they are very crowded. It was nice to have the beach pretty much to yourself. We will not be staying here again though..

We went because of business meetings and spent an extra two days. They were very relaxing and enjoyable. With the exception of not having a golf course immediately available as part of the resort (such as at resorts on Hawaii), everything needed was right at the Kahala. The food was good and the service attentive. We will return. For those that are adventurous the ability to be with the dolphins in the water is a plus. The special dinner events at the hotel were superb! They went the extra mile and paid attention to details. This is probably the best hotel on Oahu and, being away from the crowds of Waikiki is a real plus.

I had my wedding there last year and spent one night there. I am only reviewing the hotel and not my experiences with the wedding (which was good overall). I have been to Honolulu 7 times & stayed in different hotels - mostly in Waikiki (Marriott, Hotel Renew, Pacific Beach, Ilikai, Aston Waikiki Beach Tower). I was pretty excited to finally stay there as my sister & her family live next door to the Kahala & we dined there frequently. Unfortunately, I was pretty disappointed with my one night stay. # 1. check in took a very long time & there was some confusion at the reception. # 2. We had breakfast included as part of the room but they would not confirm that and argued that was not the case until they found the reservation.
