I was put on hold (on the telephone) for a long time until this was straightened out. # 3. we found the bed to be incredibly uncomfortable - we ended sleeping on the floor (the mattress is very, very soft - like sink in soft - in all fairness, if you like that type of mattress, I guess it would not be too bad but my husband and I both prefer firm mattresses). My parents were staying there for one week and they had the same issue with the mattress and had to have it replaced. As we were there for just one night, we didn't think it was worth complaining about. # 4. The service was average for Hawaii standards and not exemplary as expected in a hotel of this star rating/price. To be honest, I experienced more genuine Aloha in the hotels in Waikiki.The good of Kahala is of course the unmatched location right off the most beautiful part of the island away from all the craziness of Waikiki. View of the sunset from the beach is amazing. The room was large, clean and well decorated. It was nice to watch the dolphins from our balcony. We ordered room service for the wedding party and the food was quite yummy. Restaurants on site are all very good. Overall, I was disappointed with the value we received and I doubt we would stay here again. There are too many nicer hotels (& less expensive ones) to choose in Oahu. It seems like their rating on Tripadvisor has gone down in the last year or so - I remember they were #1 or # 2 on the list for a long time - maybe they need to consider making some changes to bring them up to the level they were at. They definitely have the potential to be an exemplary hotel.

We just got back from a four-night (aka too-short-of-a-stay) stay at the Kahala Hotel & Resort. When we arrived, the front desk took the liberty of upgrading us to a room that opens up right into the golf course next to the hotel. Every morning we could see the golfers driving by, it was absolutely lovely. The beach area is relatively small but has everything you could ask for -- serenity, private beach, multiple restaurants a few steps away and, last but not least, the resort's very own dolphin lagoon. We didn't get to do a dolphin quest but will surely do so the next time we are in Honolulu and we'll be staying for a longer time for sure.
user_name:
gtsjyq
New York City, New York

review_body: The Kahala IS the BEST Hotel on Oahu!!! From the incredible service to the comfortable rooms and fantastic restaurants. I highly recommend this hotel to anyone who wants a relaxing and enjoyable vacation. The rooms are very big and spacious bathrooms as well. The entire staff was always helpful and knowledgeable.

My husband and I stayed at this hotel from the 22nd September until the 28th September.Everything about this hotel is first class. I would recommend this hotel to any one who wants to enjoy Oahu but also wants privacy.I wanted to make special mention about Billy on the the class instructors, his tuition and knowledge is the best that I have ever experienced.Good luck with your future career.A very special hotel for those wanting a little luxury.We will be returning.

What can I say about the Kahala that hasn't already been said? We stayed here for 4 nights before going to Maui and maybe should have stayed here the entire time. Yes it was that good. Compared to the hustle and bustle of Waikiki this is an oasis. Waikiki reminds me of The Vegas Strip. Been there done that. Too crowded and commercialized. Maybe we are getting older but the calmness and serenity of The Kahala can't be surpassed. The beach is absolutely gorgeous and uncrowded. No trouble getting lounges by the pool or on the beach at any time of the day. The Mai Tai's are to die for. Our room was partial oceanview. Well this was the best. We had a view of the mountains, golf course and the ocean. We felt this was better than a oceanview room because we had all views in one room. The room was large, the bathroom to die for, and it was spotless. We sat out on the lanai every morning watching the sun come up. Doesn't get any better than that.Service was impeccable. After one day most of the staff called us by name. We ate in most of the restaurants and overall the food was exceptional.The Kahala doesn't get mentioned much here on TA but it should. After doing the Waikiki thing I will never stay at any other hotel on Oahu but The Kahala. We have already started talking about when we can go back. Yes it is worth every dollar they charge. To everyone at The Kahala a very big MAHALO.
user_name:
BigDaddy1114
New York City, New York

review_body: The Kahala is our favorite resort in Hawaii. It has class, but is comfortable. It is private, but only 10 minutes to the sights, action and great restaurants of Honolulu. The rooms are huge and were redone in the last couple of years. The staff is lovely and helpful. The beach is very private without any high rises to be seen. The spa is top notch. A direct and hassle free vacation to Hawaii in the lap of casual luxury!

Let me begin by telling you, this is my first trip advisor review. I would never normally write an online review, but following my stay at the amazing Kahala Hotel & Resort i feel compelled to give them the praise they rightly deserve! Our honeymoon consisted of a few nights in vegas and LA sandwiched with 9 nights at the Kahala. I understand this is not everyone's idea of a good honeymoon, but for us we are very active and while we enjoy an idilic beach we like having the option of lively restaurants/bars and plentiful activities nearby. The Kahala proved to be the perfect balance for us.Upon check in we were greeted with wonderful lei's, complimentary bottles of hawaiian mineral water and very friendly and helpful bell staff. As we made our way to the check in desk there was no que and a very helpful receptionist who explained the layout of the resort and informed us we had been given a complimentary room upgrade to the dolphin lagoon wing (i must admit, we had emailed the resort ahead and explained it was our honeymoon, and if they could do anything to make our experience even more memorable it would be much appreciated). Once we reached our room, we found a complimentary bottle of champagne and chocolate dipped strawberries! The room was a very nice size, with a huge bathroom (double sink, large waterfall type shower, large bath), a supremely comfortable queen bed and small sofa. Our room was also in a perfect position, at the end of the dolphin wing, which meant we were a short walk from the lobby, but a stones-throw from the beach. the room was overlooking the mountainside/golf course which was very nice. I have read other reviews complaining you get woken at 5:30am by the golf course being mowed, i heard it once and to be honest the only reason i heard it was i had woken early with jet lag - it was so insignificant i cant believe people actually commented on it! The complimentary resort wifi came in very handy for me and the wife making friends and family jealous with pictures and facetime calls!The beach at the kahala is absolutely gorgeous, i don't think the pictures online do it justice. It is flanked either side by small rock peninsula's which provide awesome views of the bay/resort and the mountain side. The sun beads are free as are the towels/bed covers - its worth noting a lot of waikiki hotels charge for use of their sun loungers. The selection of beach activities are very good - while not being intrusive to other beach users, there are a selection of canoes/kayaks/surf boards but our favourite was the stand up paddle boards. There is also a small reef which protects the beach from the larger waves and provides ample snorkelling terrain.We ate at the plumeria beach house for breakfast and the beachside bar and grill for lunch. The breakfast buffet was fantastic quality and vast, my favourite meal of the day! Another nice touch is the complimentary Kona coffee they serve untill 8am outside the plumeria beach house. The staff are all excellent - addressing you by name everyday.Another nice touch is the complimentary shuttle service which takes you to the kahala mall, ala moana shopping centre or the centre of waikiki at regular intervals throughout the day and night....this is good as it saves you approx $20 a time in a taxi. It takes approx 15 mins into Waikiki and we used the service most evenings as we loved the dining options that waikiki offers. Yes it is built up, but not in a tacky way - international restaurants, hawaiian style restaurants and plenty of nice shops and bars to keep you entertained.Ok, so my only gripes with the kahala were the spa pricing. We were both looking forward to having a nice massage/treatment upon arrival, but when we saw the price list there was no way we could justify the price. Im sure like everything at the Kahala, the massages/treatments would be outstanding but i would like to see them adjust their pricing to make them more accessible to all.So in summary, i believe the Kahala is the best hotel i have ever stayed in. They helped to make our honeymoon absolutely perfect and i would love to return sometime soon!

My husband and I booked this hotel as part of a 2 week holiday. We stayed at the kahala for 7 nights, following a hectic few days in Los Angeles. We stayed here in 2009 as part of our honeymoon on a weeks holiday and decided to return . We wasnt disappointed,The hotel staff were friendly and helpful. The staff were really attentive. Nothing was too much bother. there is free wifi throughout the hotel. The public areas are tastefully decorated and very spacious. We booked a garden room and this overlooked the golf course. The rooms were tastefully decorated in a lemon colour and spacious. The toiletries and bath towels were replenished every day. We had an evening turn down service. There was a large separate shower and bath. There is a dolphin lagoon and ponds with various turtles and fish. it was beautiful to see the dolphins. We swam with the dolphins previously, this was excellent. There is a large swimming pool, jacquzzi and child's swimming pool. There was plenty of room to get a sun bed at the ,various times of the days we went. there are restaurants that overlook the beach. The beach is small and caters for mainly the guests of the hotel, but continue walking and you walk to residential areas We booked breakfast at the hotel for one night and this was $35 per person without taxes and tip. this was a buffet breakfast and the food was exceptional and well with the money. Plenty of choice from fresh fruit, to continental, yoghurts, pastries, cooked food. The hotel has a complimentary shuttle to Waikiki, Alamano, and kahala mall. You will need to book the shuttle as it does get booked up quite quickly. The first bus starts 10.30 and the last picks up 8.45. This is a good service, but they could look at having a later shuttle back say 10pm. The hotel is about 10 mins in the shuttle. This hotel is in a good location, and away from the main waikiki.. We opted for a cab back to kahala a couple of nights but this was $25. The views and location of the hotel are superb, and its nice to get away from the hustle and bustle of Waikiki Looking forward to returning again soon, as coming from UK it's a long flight

It was some time ago that i stayed at this hotel with my boyfriend and his family at Christmas time , very fancy to say the least , i had never stayed at a hotel like this before , at night i remember returning to find our beds turned down and a little plumeriam on the pillows . the lobby was decortated for the holidays of course but with a Hawian twist , also there were all sorts of tropical plants all over the place and pools of salt water with friendly dolphins swimming around , being born in NJ i had never seen anything like this , it was like a fantasy !

We stayed at Kahala for three nights after landing in Honolulu before flying on to a different island. The staff was attentive, friendly, and very accommodating. The Kahala is perfectly located because it is so close to Waikiki and the airport but when you are on the hotel grounds it feels as if you are on a completely different island. I loved seeing the dolphins swimming around in the middle of the resort. Overall great stay and can’t wait to go back!
user_name:
GToohey
New York City, New York

review_body: dined with local friends on a Thursday night , service was OK did and said all the right things , bit mechanical , food was disappointing for a hotel with such a reputation style of presentation a bit dated and flavors not quite there, service could have been more smiles just seemed a bit flat that night. does have an old world charm about the restaurant , overall a disappointment for us .

We absolutely loved our stay at the Kahala. We just returned from 4 magical nights. The hotel, the people, the location, the beautiful beach and the food were splendid. Our room was amazing! We loved it so much that we had a difficult time venturing out from the hotel. We had dinner at Hoku every night because the food and the atmosphere were fabulous, but also because the people; Dante, Danielle, Lisa, Giorgina, and Charlotte were pleasant, fun and interesting people. One afternoon when we did venture out, we rushed back because we could not wait to come back to paradise. We cannot wait to come back to the Kahala, we miss everyone there already.

We loved our stay at Kahala, located a relaxing distance from nearby Waikiki for this 'mature couple'! This hotel has a grand old world luxurious feel; its long history of famous patrons is well documented in photos on display. The Piano bar and restaurants were great (although the margaritas were average, but they were everywhere on this island), the service exceptional as it was in all parts of the hotel. Our large upstairs room overlooked the lovely beach where we swam every morning. The bathroom was spacious too with 2 wash basins and ample storage space. Only odd thing was having to prepay for drinks, which were then delivered to the minibar, requiring exactly the sort of forethought that minibars are supposed to obviate! But overall, top marks.

I wrote early this year about our disappointing stay at Kahala in January due to construction noise. We were invited to return to the hotel by the hotel manager who felt awful about our experience. My wife and I are glad that we took her up on it! We just returned and had a wonderful time. Perfect weather! Great food! And the beach and views are among the best in Hawaii.While our experience in January was certainly disappointing, this latest trip made our year! If we return to Honolulu, this is certainly where we will stay.

We spent 5 days at the Kahala and enjoyed ourselves. The beach is clean and very swimable and much wider and quieter than any of the downtown hotels. I snorkeled at the reef and enjoyed that.The service was great and the food - especially breakfast - was superb. The room was clean and well appointed . . we had a mountain view / partial ocean - which was fine except for the mowing of the golf course next door at 5:30 AM. But the hotel can't do much about that.This is a resort however, and we went as a couple. I would guess that over half the guests were there with children - so if you want quiet and seclusion - it's difficult. The pool has children playing and parents in with the kids - so if you want to swim laps or relax in the pool - it's tough. I spent most of the time at the beach.My wife enjoyed the spa and was well taken care of.My only complaint - was if you go to the beach and want to sit in a "cabana" - really just beach chairs with a cover - they charge you over $50 for the day. I don't want to sound cheap - but if you are paying over $500 + a day . . that's a bit steep for some shade.
user_name:
Stuart L
New Rochelle, New York

review_body: Best testimony is that I'm looking forward to staying again ASAP. From the floral lei greeting, checkin to checkout it was all I expected and more. Truly amazed at the attention to details and sincere aloha. The only complaint and criticism is that thee was a bit of construction going on but that still represents improvement. You'll thank me later.

Hands down the nicest, most friendly staff I've ever experienced. They made our stay wonderful and memorable. The beach is calm and secluded; perfect for those who want a quiet place to relax and for those with young children. (Older kids may find it too calm and secluded.) The rooms along the golf course are great- quiet, with balconies and partial ocean views and you can hear the surf as you drift off to sleep. Only downside is that the shuttle into Waikiki only runs on the hour and is often booked, so you may want to rent a car if you want to leave the resort. (The hotel restaurant is very expensive and limited in selection.) They used to rent bikes, which was wonderful, but not any more.

This resort has a magnificent setting on a tropical lagoon inhabited by dolfins and turtles.We checked in at the last two days of our seven days trip in Hawai.The first five days we stayed at Moana Surfider and we were not happy. Restaurant at the pool and the beach were great.Our room was overlooking the beach and it was very spacious with a very large bath. Ovearall a very nice stay but very pricey!

We have been staying at this hotel for numerous times over the past 20 years. We even got married here. Every time we come here, we have great experiences and memories, thanks to warm staff and nice services. Kahala is a beautiful hotel in a quiet location, so you will be totally relaxed and in vacation mode instantly, unlike any hotels in Waikiki. Architecture and decor of the hotel are timeless and luxurious. Dolphins and turtles in hotel premises with secluded beach are perfect for family as well. I hope, one day, hotel provides washer and dryer so we can pack light for children. Hotel staffs are always smiling and provide detail service. One of the staff, Grace Chen, was especially helpful in many different events (especially our memorable wedding!). We cannot wait to return to Kahala for next vacation!
user_name:
IwataS910
Los Angeles, California, United States

review_body: The Kahala is old style luxury and service with every modern convenience. I practically wept when it was time to leave. The hotel is outside Honolulu on a beach with views of the ocean, mountains, and palm trees....sitting outside in the early morning, enjoying said view, and one of the best breakfasts I've ever had, I felt pure happiness. This was indeed paradise. We had a junior suite as we were travelling with children and the rooms were large, pretty and clean. There were two large bathrooms and a balcony to enjoy the daily complimentary cocktails. Ok, The Kahala IS expensive but there are deals to be done, and we had breakfast, free wifi (though why any hotel thinks it's acceptable to charge is beyond me), and daily use of a cabana included in our rate. We stayed at The Four Seasons on Maui and The Fairmont Orchid on the Big Island, both wonderful resorts, , but The Kahala was our favourite.

My family and I stayed at this resort one night, but we definetely wish we could have stayed longer! We were greeted by friendly staff, and the bellman took our luggage and showed us down to our room, giving us helpful information about the property and answering any questions we had. When we got to our room, we found freshly baked complimetary chocolate chip cookies. We ate at the poolside grill, which had very good food. I would definetely recomend dolphin quest, we had such an amazing time! We did the dolphin experience. We would definetely go back!

I travel about 200 hotel nights a year. I really thought that the Kahala would be an excellent experience. It was not. The terrible rating is for the management of the hotel. Upon check in Carlos asked me what time I would be leaving on Sunday. If I were to leave after noon time there would be a charge of $80 That was unusual and made me feel like the hotel is only concerned with revenue and turning the rooms over and certainly no aloha spirit there. I also have never been asked that before upon check in. The reservation was for two and he also asked if a "Mrs" would be coming along. Again another unusual question. It reminded me of something that would be asked in the 1950's The toliet clogged and it took them an hour to get someone to correct the issue. At that point I decided to call the manager. His name was Paul Lukela. What a mistake! He was condescending. He said they only took 15 minutes to fix the problem whcih was not true. In additon when I told him what happened at check in he offered no apology. Most people want to relax on vacation and not deal with issues.and the way Paul responded was not acceptable. I asked for the corporate number and Paul's response was oh dont worry I will call corporate and tell them what happened. What does that even mean? It gets worse. I decided to call the general manager Roseann Grippo. I was told she was in a meeting. The entire day Friday passed and she never called back. I called again on Saturday not expecting a manager to be in the office. Again I got voicemail and no return call. Being in a meetng is not an excuse to not call someone back. Since they asked for my email and phone at check in I would have thought that she would have called on Monday. Again no call. I guess she feels that she does not need to for a guest paying $800 per nightThe waitress at breakfast was not attentive and never cleaned the dirty plates. The day before I had a different waitress and when I asked for help with the birds that constantly try and get your food she said "you know I am not your waitress" I thought that was an unusual response for a five star hotel. I did speak to the manager Joy and she corrected the issue. Joy handled the problem better than the general manager!

This hotel was much nicer that I expected. We checked in as the last few days of our 10 day trip to Hawaii. I only booked 2 days because, based on trip advisor reviews, this seemed to be the nicest hotel in the area we wanted to stay. Only a few negatives. It's time for a refreshing of the rooms. The carpet needs replacing, it's showing the signs of wear. The conceige (Julie) was not very good. Sent us to an abandoned Golf course with no driving range! Now for the positives. The Kahala rooms are very spacious and I loved the bathrooms. The rooms were very clean and the bed was spotless (this was nice after my experience with The Ritz, Maui).This was my favorite hotel of the 3 that we had stayed in during our 10 day trip. The view from our room was fantastic,we had a waterfall just outside, a view of the course and a view of the dolphin pool. We ordered room service our first night and it was outstanding! We order the sea salt roasted chicken with potatoes and asparagus. The coconut cake for desert was very fresh and moist. We ordered roomservice for breakfast our last day and it was a home run as well. We are already planning to return to this hotel in March, I wish I had planned a longer stay at the Kahala. Thanks to everyone for making the last few days of our anniversary trip the best!

Aloha! We just returned from a fabulous stay at the Kahala. The property is beautiful and the location is perfect. If you want luxury, beauty, a great beach, and a true Hawaiian experience I would recommend staying at this hotel as it is the best on Oahu. The staff is very friendly and efficient. Food is good, albeit very expensive, and food service is a bit spotty (seemed isolated to cases of new employees).The rooms are well done and they have put thought into ensuring any and all amenities you may need are stocked in your room. We opted for the Oceanfront lanai and it was well worth the price for the view of the dolphin lagoon, the lush grounds, and the water. The hotel attracts tourists from all over the world so you have to go in with an open mind and understanding of different cultures. No place is with without flaws or issues, but the sign of a truly great hotel is how well they are handled. We had a couple of very minor issues and the hotel handled swiftly and professionally. You can take comfort in knowing that the hotel will strive to ensure your happiness during your stay.Here are a couple of words of advice for when you book your stay at the Kahala… 1. If you are an American Express Platinum customer, book your stay through Amex. The discounts that you will receive are substantial (discounted room rates, complimentary breakfast, spa discounts, dining credits, and more). 2. If you are planning on eating at the hotel make your breakfast and dinner reservations in advance. The wait will be long otherwise. 3. Book a cabana! 4. If you happen to have a room facing the ocean, look to the far right of the beach sometime around 3 or 4 pm. You might see paparazzi. We saw them twice. Then you and your travel companion(s) can play the guess-which-celebrity-is-staying-at-the-hotel game.  I hope you enjoy your stay at the Kahala as much as we did!

We returned to the Kahala Hotel in late May of this year after an almost ten year hiatus. Despite the ownership changes over that time (formerly the Kahala Mandarin Hotel) the Kahala has maintained its grace and beauty and personifies the spirit of Aloha. We were greeted warmly by the fawning staff on arrival and provided leis and flowers. We traveled with our three boys which made an adjoining room necessary and the Hotel did not disappoint. Our rooms were as attractive and sumptuous as we had remembered, accented by bright linens and dark rattan. While not inexpensive, the dining at Plumeria and Room Service was exquisite and bursting with the tastes of Hawaii, Kona coffee in particular was excellent. That said we were somewhat taken back by miscellaneous charges which cropped up such as wifi internet access (tip is free for 30 mins in Business Center), parking, and cabanas. Still all in all this must be one of the finest hotels in the world and surely the best in Oahu, hope we all can return in less than a decade next time.

My wife and I were married here in 1981 next to the waterfall. I also grew up in the area so I know this area well. Looks a little worn at the registration desk especially the floor. Our room was 1226 on the second floor with a partial ocean view. There were two sinks in the bathroom. I had the water running, brushing my teeth and I felt water on my legs. I thought WHAT? I looked under the sink and the drain pipe was totally disconnected so the water was running directly on the floor. Unbelievable. Ate at the seafood buffet for $55 each. I wish I could get my money back. The edges of the sashimi were turning green (old). The poke was overseasoned and there was gristle running through the pieces (lower grade). The sushi rice was too big and not seasoned well if at all. OK, the bad stuff done. The good stuff is that the beach is great. Kahala beach is usually a little windy in the afternoon but the days we were there was just right. The staff was great! Worked very hard and very eager to please. Kathy the bartender, was terrific. Housekeeping staff was very very good. You can tell they took pride in their work. The piano guy at night was soothing, really enjoyed sitting and listening. Overall, maybe a little over priced, but it is the hotel where Presidents stay and it is away from the craziness of Waikiki. Yes, I will go back. It is the Kahala!

This Hotel is very unconventional and quite hard to get to grips with.On the one hand it is certainly a smart, 5 star resort with very attentive staff, fine dining and all the trappings expected.It is immediately obvious that the guests dress far more smartly and are far more formal here than in a typical Hawaii Hotel of similar standard.On the other hand they have this superb Dolphin experience right within the pool area, literally 6 Dolphins, all clearly very well looked after, live in a huge pool area adjacent to the swimming pool, this is superb but seems out of character, though I certainly am not complaining as it is wonderful.The actual swimming pool is not particularly special or large, it's merely adequate. That's fine for a smart Adult's hotel, but doesn't seem very child friendly.In brief, it's the sort of lovely quiet place to go as a couple or perhaps to take the children, if you don't really want a family friendly Hotel and all of the noise that entails.Dining can be hugely expensive, although we bought a breakfast package deal which was a reasonable $16 per head, if you don't buy the package expect to pay at least $40 for breakfast...plus extra cost for grapefruit juice or a latte! We didn't have Dinner at the Hotel for the same reason.In conclusion, this is a comfortable, smart hotel for the well healed only. You won't find any Stag Parties staying here! '

After having a great dinner at Hoku's (Chris Pliska and Robert,waiters) where those two employees were so engaging,we went to the Veranda for after dinner drinks.....well the service here was almost non-existent. 2 managers standing around not even helping the 3 people working in there. This kind of place charging these kinds of prices!! Shame on the owners for letting this happen. I have lived in Hawaii for 38 years and the Kahala has always been known for service. They need to fix whatever it is that is wrong.....The waiter tells me ''our bartender is in the weeds''. This was 9:45 pm and it was not even full, but what really hurts is watching those two managers just standing around..........HELP!!

We spent 5 days at the Four Seasons Maui, 6 days at Grand Hyatt Kauai and we ended our 2 week trip with 3 days at the Kahala. I have to be honest, we were all dreading leaving the "real Hawaii" for the big city Hawaii. However, I wanted my family of four to experience Oahu. WOW!!!! What a way to end our trip!! We were all blown away by the Kahala! We were greeted with smiles, leis and fragrant towels. We were also told that they sold out of our dolphin room, so we were upgraded to a dolphin deluxe at no charge with 2 roll away beds for our twin 12 year olds. We walked into the dolphin deluxe suite and couldn't believe our eyes. The room was absolutely beautiful! We had 4 giant cookies with "Aloha" written in chocolate and a bottle of champagne waiting for us. WOW! The room opened up to a patio with dolphins wrestling right outside our door!! My kids were so excited and so were we! The rooms, grounds, ocean, people etc... are all magical! My son sat for hours watching the sea turtles and the fish, while my daughter met all the trainers at the dolphin lagoon along with the owner of Dolphin Quest. The trainers answered any questions, brought the dolphins over by the different viewing areas and told us to get ready at different times for picture taking opportunities. We missed the 6 o'clock shuttle to Waikiki, so we decided to eat at the hotel on Saturday night. We went to the seafood buffet at the hotel. It was like no other seafood buffet we have ever been to. The food, presentation, and sheer assortment of shrimp, sushi, salmon, salads, desserts, etc... were beautiful and best we have ever had a buffet. Even the tea is better at the Kahala! We loved walking the beach and looking at all the million dollar houses. We wanted to rent bikes but ran out of time. The guys at the valet were extremely helpful. They packed us with towels, waters and free boogie boards when they heard we were going up the coast to some other beautiful beaches. Everyone, from the servers to the front desk and valet were shard the aloha spirit. My whole family wished we had more time to spend at this magical place! It was perfect for us. We drove to Diamond Head within 7 minutes and hiked to the top. Then went on to Waikiki to take surf lessons and shop. Going back to the Kahala after a long day was like coming home. We loved the turn down service every night and Tommy Bahama bath amenities. We did not think anything was better than the Four Seasons on Maui, or the Grand Hyatt on Kauai, well the Kahala rivals them both!! We will be back again to discover more of the beautiful island of Oahu! Thank you and Aloha!

We stayed for 10 days in August, really lovely resort far nough away from the bustle of Wikiki but easy to reach great resturants, sights ect. We hired a car for 4 days which was just enough, the hotel shuttle will take you to the local shopping centres, you can walk to the Kahala Mall in about 10 mins and it is a nice walk. Fantastic resort did not want to come home.

The Kahala Hotel and Resort is absolutely amazing. The staff is very pleasant and accommodating. The views from the hotel are simply breathtaking. You are able to sit at any of the beautiful restaurants (all are fantastic) and have a spectacular ocean view. I had my wedding at the Kahala Hotel. It far exceeded my expectations. I could not have asked for a more perfect wedding. From the staff to the scenery, it was just amazing. The wedding went very smoothly with the help of the staff. Everything was in order and looked great. The rooms were very clean and very comfortable to be in. The entire hotel property looked exquisite and the dolphin lagoon was very enjoyable. I had an amazing stay at this hotel and an amazing wedding!!:) Thank you for making my special day perfect!
user_name:
Tiffany Lynn B
Brooklyn, New York

review_body: Beautiful, quiet, and very relaxing resort away from the hustle, bustle, and overcrowded Waikiki Beach. We very much enjoyed the nightly entertainment in the open air lounge--a fantastic piano player who sang a wide variety of oldies and current music. The resort is impeccably clean. The staff helpful and friendly. We had a mountain view room overlooking the golf course. Our room was quiet and very comfortable. The bathroom had double vanities with two closets, a soaking tub, and a separate shower. The food in the restaurants was very good--albeit quite expensive. A taxi from the Kahala into Waikiki Beach cost about $20 one way. A taxi from the airport was about $45 each way. Although we didn't participate in the hotel's dolphin encounter, we enjoyed watching others who did. And they all appeared to be having a fantastic time. The hotel's pool was refreshing and the beach sublime. We never had a problem getting lounge chairs.

We went to the hotel for my daughter 11th birthday. A beautiful setting and everything you need. The dolphin lagoon was excellent and good fun for the whole family. Depite the tour company plastering the booking stating it was her birthday the hotel didnt make a fuss which is what we are use to in Italy and other 5 star hotels. The facilities here were very good, a spa, gym, shops, dolphins etc and we made use of most of them. The private beach is great with waiters to serve food and drink if needed. the breakfast is vast and caters for all needs. Rooms were spotless and if you needed anything it arrives swiftly. Our two disapointments were that the room wasnt ready when we arrived after a 22 hour trip to get there so we had to wait when all we wanted to do was swim and take advantage of the environment. Still at check in time we were delayed another 30 mins and for a 5 star this wasnt up to standard and a let down. Staff in general were great apart from one in the reastaurant who was seating breakfast or lunch - despite tables being available we had to wait 15 mins. We were told we couldnt even sit and wait or have a drink we just had to wait. The other experience of the Veranda was a girl informed us we couldnt have drinks in the lounge despit all tables being taken in the veranda- and all that after being told we had to wait for an hour for a dinner table. So in other words an hours wait for dinner ( because tables were reserved for hotel giest- not sure what we were then) and we couldnt get a drink either in this lovely 5 star hotel. They got the service very wrong on this day with breakfast, lunch and dinner. Also no apology! Poor for the standard of hotel. Despite a couple of hickups the hotel is lovely and very relaxing. They need to take a long look at the Chewton Glen Hotel in Hampshire UK to really find out what 5 star service really looks like. Chewton get it righ year on year and have got me business for life.

This resort is an excellent find. Our stay was for 4 days and this place paid attention to detail and made sure all of our needs were met. The morning breakfast was delicious and fresh! all of the wait staff were attentive and polite. The rooms were nice and provided real bath mats and not the cheap towel mats most hotels provide. The Kahala paid attention to detail. The staff at the bar and restaurants made a point to take time and ask about our stay and recommended wonderful finds in Hawaii. I would definitely return when i return to hawaii.

Fellow travellers,The Kahala Report is an absolut gem !! Everything about this hotel and resort is world class. It's hard to know where to begin. Let me try and break it down.First and foremost I need to say that Flora Lamontagne (Director, Guest Services) went above and beyond to make our stay exceptional. She is a gem. If your reading this, thank you again Flora !! You are the best. Location. Beautifully located in one of the best neighborhoods of Honolulu, sandwiched between a beautiful golf course and a magnificent beach front. No matter which way your room faces, you get a spectacular view. We had a "partial ocean view", which means we had a view of the golf course and the mountains studded with what are some pretty amazing houses (even from a distance). I have seen some other reviews that say you pay a lot for the partial view, but frankly some of the ocean front views actually look over the parking lot - so I would rather see a golf couse and mountains myself. It is away from the hustle and bustle of Waikiki - which from my perspective was a substantial blessing. A peaceful oasis of beauty and calm describes the Kahala location.Room. We had a superior room on the 10th floor with a large balcony. Room was beatifully done in what might be termed upscale Hawaian. Very comfy bed with nice linens, very large bathroom with two seperate sinks (one on each side), plus a large tub and good sized stand up shower. Two seperate large warddrobe areas with lots of hangers. Excellent and super quiet air conditioning - nice hair and body goodies - coffee maker - fridge, can't think of anything that falls short. Yes - it was absolutely worth what we paid in my opinion.Service. Superb service from all staff, from front desk to cleaning. Example: Whenever I called for my car, the phone was answered in no more than 3 rings, with a friendly voice saying " Aloha. How can we help you Mr. Canada?" If I wanted my ca, it was always there when I got downstairs, no matter how fast I went. Amazing. Room was cleaned spotlessly every day, with turn down service provided. I think we also got water bottles replentished every day. If you were heading to the beach, the valet desk at the front was happy to provide you with towels and extra water. Wonderful. The staff went out of their way to provide advice and direction on where to go and what to do - especially if your like us and want to find those hidden beaches that only the locals know about.Food. The food at the Kahala was excellent, from the beach-front to the upscale Hoku restaurent. Waiters are attentive and well trained, and the chef's are as good or better than you will find at any other restaurent on the island. We ate at all "the best" restaurents around (the top 10 per TripAdvisor) so had a good measure by which to go by. The cost was no more expensive than any other top restaurent in it's class. Other. After several trips to the East shore and up to the North shore, we decided to chill and and spend an entire day on the Kahala beach. It was wonderful. We rented a cabana for the day, and swam - had lunch on the beach - and used some of the other fun stuff that is available right there. One of the local companies is on the beach and works with the Kahala to offer outrigger canoe trips and stand up paddle boards and kayaks. We did the 45 minute outrigger canoe trip ($70 for two), and I tried my hand at stand up paddle board Hawaiian style. It was great. Summing it up - one of the best 11 days I have spent in many years and many vacations. The Kahala Hotel and Resort may have spoiled me the same way that travelling Executive Class does when you fly. Once you experience it - everything else just pales in comparison.If you have any specific questions, please feel free to email me.

We thought it would have the best of everything with the price. However we had several problems. The service was great at the pool restaurant and on the beach but the front desk and other restaurants were less than great. We really liked our room but the conciege did not have info they should have.

The Kahala Resort is absolutly beautiful! Great service by all employees! Loved the dolphins and beautiful pool area. We loved Michael at the cabannas, Aimee the events/catering manager :), and Joy at Plumeria. Can't wait to go back!

The Kahala Hotel is the best place for a wedding reception - the best food, ambiance and also the best staff. Aimee Graham was a great wedding coordinator and I can say that she helped to make it one of the best days of our lives. The hotel went out of their way to personalize our wedding reception the way we wanted it. If I had to do it again, I would definitely choose The Kahala.

We were lucky enough to have our wedding at the Kahala resort in May 2012. We live in Sydney Australia and could not have dreamt of such an awesome day.The resort is immcaulate, the service was exceptional, the food, well nothing less than amazing. We had 22 guests attend and they were absolutely blown away with the whole event, comments were: we have never had such beutiful food and service at any other wedding we have attended to.Aimee Graham was our event manager, now to say she is an expert is an understatement. She had everything under control and made the day fabulous. Her catering team were wonderful, friendly and very accomodating.We didnt stay at the resort, however had our photos around the entire resort, being in a property management role at home, the resort is very well maintained and presented.We will be back, and next time we will be staying at the hotel so we can have many more Lava Flows.Thanks Kahala and Aimee for having us, we cant wait to get back there.Shane and Christine

Not a good start. The reception staff need to left their game and need to be much more welcoming. We had to wait for some time for anyone to greet us or to speak to us when we arrived and we were rather tired having arrived from Sydney.  It took 3 hours to get our room ready but we discovered the holdup was to replace a light fitting in the bathroom. Eventually a receptionist noticed us still waiting and allowed us to go to the room while we waited for 3 men to replace the light fitting. We sat on our partial ocean view balcony while they worked on the light fitting, which took about 15 minutes. It's a pity we had to wait so long in the lobby for maintenance staff to do repairs at 4.30pm in the afternoon.The room was comfortable but the bathroom was dated with the toilet in tiny cupboard sized area.It was hardly a partial ocean view. The view from the balcony was of the golf course and if you leaned over the edge of the right side privacy screen you could see glimpses of the ocean. The table on the balcony was quite rusted and definitely from the 1960’s.It was difficult to find out information about facilities and we missed out on dinning in their signature restaurant because it was booked out on our first night. We then tried for the 3rd and 4th nights of our stay to be told it was closed. There was little choice at the hotel and the food was very pricy for what is was. Eventually we extracted Information from the hotel to get a list of restaurants in the area. Our package included breakfast and we were shocked to find 50 guests crowded ahead of us waiting for tables. Guests who knew to make a reservation sailed in ahead of us.The hotel seemed geared up for Japanese, it was predominately occupied with Japanese tourists and specialized in weddings In fact there were multiple weddings of Japanese tourists every day. Many of the staff were Japanese too and at times I felt like I was in Japan instead of Hawaii. I would have preferred a more Hawaiian experience.The best thing about this resort was the private beach. It was quiet, nicely landscaped and set up with plenty of deck chairs. The staff needs to be more welcoming and helpful with information to guests. We would have appreciated some advice about their restaurants, an offer to make reservations and to warn us about the need to make reservations for breakfast. This hotel has seen better days, it is evident that it was built in the early 1960’s.

The most beautiful hotel on Oahu! After pulling up a winding driveway, you are greeted with a lei and a very attentive staff. I was at the hotel for my daughters wedding, Wow! If you are thinking about a wedding in Hawaii, this is the only place to be. You will not be sorry. The gazebo's (there are 2) ) are so spectacular overlooking the ocean.The layout of the hotel is excellent also. My 17 yr. old daughter was able to walk alone to the dolphin lagoon,the pool and the beach,it was a very safe environment. We had the mountain room. It was calm and very pretty( I especially liked the furniture and the ceiling). I've never felt a bed as soft and comfortable.The sheets were very soft as well.The rooms are so clean as is the entire hotel. The fresh and clean smell is wonderful. The entire staff is very very friendly well mannered and helpful. After coming from New York, my expectations were exceeded by the Kahala. It's an outstanding hotel!
user_name:
Rose Ann G
Brooklyn, New York

review_body: Should be far more luxurious considering the price, it would also benefit from a more personable attitude towards guests. The whole approach of the hotel is geared towards getting as much money out of you as possible and it isn't subtle about it either. The dolphin lagoon and beach area are incredible, beautiful and serene. Overall i'm glad we stayed there due to the fantastic location and some amazing scenery, however we will not be staying there again i'd have thought. I would say that they also need to make the guests children adhere to pool rules, as during our stay the pool was overrun with inflatable dolphins and people somersaulting into the pool. Whilst it is not the hotel's responsibility to teach the (very rude) parents how to look after their children, they could at least make sure the hotel stays peaceful and comfortable for the guests without children.

Let's start by saying my standards are pretty high.When I travel I try to go first class and stay at places that are five star. The Kahala is not a bad place to visit but it is not at the calibre of other luxury hotels. If I were in the Caribbean it would be as nice as a Sandals but if you are a fan if places like th Trump Chicago or any of the best Vegas hotels this place is not up to par.Lets start:Rooms: we booked a two bedroom suite (2 kids and my wife and I) the rooms were large but worn and dated. The soft bed had a hill in the middle from too many visitors althpugh our view was nice the only suites are located near the elevators so guess what you hear all night. We were on the fifth floor and we could hear everything going on above us...including some adult activities. Patio table on put balcony was rusted and had two chairs.....there were 4 of us. In my opinion if you are trying to be a first class destination you need to anticipate that....duh...maybe all four of us would want a seat on the balcony.Food: food was good at all restaurants but very pricey. Make sure you get the breakfast included as the $160 shocker of a price for four people may bug you. With the suite we got coffee wvery morning delivered...nice but that was it. In addition we were supposed to get preferential seating at Hokus...well the two times we went we say at the Chefs table(basically the worst table in the restaurant.Service: Overall the service was good and the staff tried to go out of their way to remember you. However, as you can imagine we did talk to a manager on our third day about changing rooms due to the issues above. He asked for specifica so I mentioned the patio chairs, noise and lipstick on my coffee cup. He did nothing. He told us there were no other suites available and said he would follow up with us the next day. He did not. I figured they woulD at least have had two more patio chairs brought up or something but no....the concerns were basically ignored.Location: Quiet beach but windy. Private, no nightlife. No surfing at the beach. It was good on the one hand as there were no crowds but most hotels have something going on and this one did not. Dolphins: if tou have done it elsewhere dont bother. Yes they are cute but 125 bucks for 15 minutes?Overall: they have pics of celebrities on the walls but I did not see any from 2012. I think this place was probably a big deal at some point but is now trying to hold onto a past that it cannot sustain. The building is too old and needs too much work. Although the people are nice it is a money making machine first and and seeking repeat clients second. Next time I wilGo someplace that has standards they uphold...not just talk about in the brochures.

The Kahala Hotel is the most luxurious I have ever experienced on our travels. We were treated like royalty, even with teenage kids. The staff are the most pleasant I have ever known. We all went for a massage which was out of this world. The whole experience is expensive. You cannot compare it to a normal hotel and talk about pound for pound value for money. It is something you either save up and commit to it, or don't go. There are some ways of saving money, ie booking a deal with the hotel directly as we did of including breakfast for the room for a knock down price. That saves a fortune and the gratuity is included. Also not eating dinner in the hotel unless you go to a weekend buffet, which is very good value. Signing chits for drinks by the sea is great fun, but expensive. You have to use some common sense here. This is a hotel without comparison that offers you fresh towels by the front door as you leave for a taxi to a beach. You barely have to get dressed by yourself, let alone worry about how to manage anything! Of course it is expensive! The rooms are sublime. Comfort is key here. The bathrooms have his and hers wardrobes and basins. The shower is big enough for at least two! Slightly spooky toilets though. Obviously designed for Japanese with cleaning jets and so on! We tried the reef fishing as well which the boys loved. Swimming with dolphins at the hotel was brilliant. We also hired a driver for a few hours to take us to North Shore for jet skiing and the turtle beach. Our driver was called Brian, attached to the hotel. He talked us through all the history and the geography of the whole island and we stopped off for garlic prawns by the roadside on the way back. Great fun. I have to say, eating in Waikiki was a little cheaper, and we had the best steak meal ever in our lives at the DK Diner on the third floor of the Marriatt Hotel in Waikiki. It was recommended to us by a local and certainly lived up to expectation. Mouth watering. The Spa at the hotel was absolutely wonderful. I had a Samoean lady called Fina who is like a goddess. The massage was like an out of body experience. I have never felt so wonderful. Expense was beside the point. We went to Waikiki expecting a laid back surfing town. Oh my goodness - it is a modern shopping town on steroids! Designer boutiques abound. The Japanese shopping addiction is rife here. Think Bicester Village at full price 50 times bigger! Pricing in the US of hotels and services is always misleading, as they quote a price and then add tax and you have to add gratuity. Something we English do not always take into account. Usually though, the service is so far above what we get in England, we are happy to reward it! We would all love to go to the Kahala again anytime. We have moved off to another island now, which has a great deal to live up to! Mahala Kahala!

We go to Hawaii at least once and usually twice a year. In the last 20 years we have been staying in Kauai or Maui. Oahu was our destination for reunions, business meetings, etc. This was the first time we stayed at the Kahala. It certainly will not be our last. What a wonderful resort. The Kahala has not lost its grand Aloha spirit. We stayed in the dolphin lagoon rooms. Besides being close to everything the hotel offers, watching the dolphins play from our patio was a special treat. The morning buffet is amazing as is the other restaurants. Everything is first class. Wonderful beach and swimming. It was a bit windy while we were there but no matter. It was just a joy to be there. Rooms are lovely, the Spa wonderful, management and staff excellent. Believe me, "It doesn't get better than this". We plan to go back next year and stay longer.

My stay at The Kahala Resort was Excellent, i've been to Hawaii multiple times and this is sure to be the best resort i've stayed in so far in Honolulu. On our arrival my mother who i was travelling with at the time, we got treated like royalty. The service here is perfect, always getting well looked after. The spa is was a bit of a turn down, the only thing they were offering were massagers at the time and we were looking forward to get a good facial. The location is great, its very exclusive. I find staying in Waikiki way to busy and over crowd. Shuttle system they offer is a great idea, they take you to all the best shopping streets and mall straight from the hotel for free. i'd deffiently stay here again.

The Kahala Resort and Spa was a memorable stay in a hotel on the beach, away from the noise of Waikiki yet 10 minutes from it. There were dolphins that swam in this huge area in the middle of the hotel. The staff was always courteous and helpful. There was a spa where I would pamper myself or get a massage in my own room. Fronting the hotel is the Waialae Country Club where the Sony Open is played every year. I stayed in a room that was right where the dolphins were so when I went on my lanai there they were.

My family and I spent 5 blissful days at the Kahala. We chose it because it is positioned away from the fast pace of Waikiki but only a 15 minute cab ride to get to all the action. We were impressed with everything about the hotel from staff to the beds! They were like sleeping on a cloud! Great private beach, lovely restaurants. A must is the dolphin pool, although expensive it was the most incredible experience swimming and kissing the dolphins! I would definitely recommend the Kahala.

We just spent four days at the resort, after spending the amount of time in Waikiki at the Westin Surfrider. While I'll agree with the attraction of getting away from the crowds, I'll agree even more with the criticisms about too many fees and lack of upkeep. A resort charging upwards of 500 dollars a night shouldn't be charging you for internet and forcing you to pay an 18 percent tip on an overpriced "free" breakfast. And don't even get me started with the laundry fees -- yikes. Fourteen dollars to launder a toddler dress?! The basic amenities for Surfrider were every bit the equal of Kahala, without the incredibly windy weather and smaller beach whose water lacked the clear blue because of the breakers off shore. The food at Plumeria House was mediocre as well, hardly to a five-star standard. The dolphins are awesome, no doubt, but simply come out to see them and leave.

My family and I stayed here for 6 days and had an awesome time! Upon our arrival we were greeted by bellmen and then my family and I were "lei'd" w/ beautiful shells by a hostess. We were then escorted to reception and was asked to wait an hour before our rooms were ready. Now how can you complain about the wait when your backyard is the beautiful ocean. As a Leaders Club member we were upgraded to the Dolphin Lanai from Partial Ocean View Lanai, all the more reason why there's no complaint about waiting an hour for the room. DINING:While waiting for our room we had lunch at the Seaside Grill which was SUPER EXPENSIVE! 3 salads/1 kids meal/4 beers/3 cocktails came out to $170 for LUNCH! They offer a pretty good buffet breakfast at a pricey $39/person. However, all-in-all the culinary at the Kahala needs improvement. I highly recommend you eat elsewhere. THE ROOM:The room is very spacious. We got a King and a rollaway and still had plenty of space to walk about. I must commend HOUSEKEEPING! They are awesome! Whenever I had a request, I simply just wrote a note, left a little tip and voilà! For example, after our first night, we noticed our bed was super noisy and lumpy and I knew there was no way I could sleep another night. So I left a note asking if it would be possible to replace the bed and so they did. The bathroom was spacious w/ his/hers sinks & closets. ACTIVITIES:They offer lots of activities at a price of course. But I must say having the dolphins onsite was a treat for my 10-year old daughter. The gym was great for what I needed and it was never crowded. STAFF:Never experienced one rude employee. Not sure what peeps complained about from prior reviews but I thought everyone was friendly and accommodating and yes, called us by our names which was classy.I plan on returning next year.

There are too many fees at the hotel. My phone was running low on power so I call the front desk to ask how much to make a local call. $1 per call. I didn't need to ask if I called the mainland USA. Parking out here is too expensive at $25 since it is so far away from Waikiki it is not that crowded, but then maybe expensive area. Internet at $15 a day is about what other places charge. No little stuffed animals that the hotel makes and sells as gifts for the children.The Hotel Manager must either have a low standard or the owner is too cheap because all through out the hotel there are areas that need to be kept more perfectly in terms of fresh paint or cleaning. The manager and owner should more frequently visit every room and every part of the hotel on an inspection walk.Overall though I would say it was a decent value for being on the beach and the quality of everything. I would go back.One decent thing is the free bottled water at turn down service (although turn down didn't come every single night.)Kids loved the hotel because it was on the beach and not too huge like some resorts where walking from the desk to the room was not an ordeal.

I joined this hotel for my training in year 2000 and it was a nice hotel. In my orientation I had the privileged to see the massive rooms with full of amenities. The deco of the rooms and other public areas was attractive and the Dolphin Interaction Program was more significant.

Honeymooners in our early 30's here.We liked being further away from Honolulu + Waikiki (being from NYC, Waikiki reminded us of Times Square). It was close enough to go into town in our rental car, have a great dinner, some ice cream and then go back to the peace + quiet of Kahala. The hotel was pretty empty while we were there, mostly older Japanese tourists, so we did miss interacting with younger couples, which we found at Four Seasons. I didn't love the beach at Kahala but it got us to explore the other side of the island - spending the day at Makapu'u Beach for a day was one of my favorite things on the trip. While it was smaller, personally I found the breakfast at Kahala to be tastier than Four Seasons, hotel for week #2 of our honeymoon. I lived on waffles for the week :-) Shelly the omelet chef was our new best friend. A++The staff was very friendly - concierge was great to suggest off-the-beaten-path things for us to see. The pool-side staff, while friendly, was very thin so it was kinda tough to get service, despite it being empty. Some of the drinks were absurdly priced, too. $14 for a weak pina colada was crazy. I've read some reviews say the staff was not friendly. We didn't see any of this. Everyone from the front desk to valets were exceptionally friendly to everyone we saw. I wonder if the reviewers who say "unfriendly" are rude themselves -- or unreasonably demanding. We did receive our upgrade (breakfast buffet included and free parking!) by booking with a travel agent but our room had a very, very minor gnat problem; they upgraded us on Day 3 when we finally said something and immediately moved our rooms to one with a partial ocean view. They were very apologetic, so it was no big deal at all. They handled it perfectly. We did have a car so able to head into Waikiki when we wanted and explore other parts of the island. We would have been bored without the car -- the resort was very quiet (middle of June). It's definitely not in a hoppin' area. Overall, EXCELLENT resort and we really enjoyed ourselves.

This resort is very special for us. We had our wedding receptionn as well as our first baby's baptism and 1st and 2nd birthday parties here. For her second bday, we stayed the weekend and the service was phenomenal. From check in to housekeeping to the staff at Hoku's restaurant, everything was great! Note that locals can get a discounted "kamaaina" rate :). That helps! Rooms are spacious with fab views - we actually had the golf course/mountain view. The most impt part for us is that this resort is NOT in Waikiki. Far from the noise and craziness. I've also tried the spa, and it is heavenly! :)

This hotel was horrible. It is no 5 star hotel, maximum a 3 star hotel. The buildings are extremely old, the fitness area and sauna are aging, old, dirty, uncomfortable. At the breakfast there are birds on the food, sitting on the food and nobody cares. And then the price for staying there is extremely high. If it were a 3 star hotel with a low price you could go there, but it definaltely is no 5 star hotel.The only nice thing is that it is directly at the beach.

This is a must when travelling to Oahu. RoseAnn treated us like royalty. The room was right on the beach. It felt like the nearest thing to heaven.Mahalo to my amazing new family at The Kahala!I will be returning.: )

We had an ocean view room which was spacious with a large bathroom and always kept clean by housekeeping. The valet service was excellent. As another reviewer said, they thought of everything we might need from bottled water to umbrellas and even driving directions. They even took the time to remember our names. My only complaint is about the breakfast buffet. I believe the buffet is $38 per person and while there is a good selection, there was always some type of bugs (probably gnats) on the food, especially the fruit. I understand that it's an open area, but something needs to be done about that. We only ate there twice during our stay because $38 per person for is just too expensive for a breakfast with bugs flying around. Secondly, we found a much better spot to eat breakfast and it was less than a 10 minute drive away.

Cannot wait to return to the Kahala when next we visit Honolulu. So prefer it to the crowded downtown Waikiki hotels. The food is extraordinary, the ambience in every respect is delightful, beautiful and relaxing and the staff is so attentitve! It is just what I want when on vacation!

Words and pictures really can't do this place justice. What a truly unique property and staff. From the moment we walked in until we left we were enchanted. The lobby is one of those unique lobbies that you want to just sit down in one of the chairs and soak it in for 30 minutes every day. Every meal was outstanding and the service is right there with any four seasons or other 5 star experience you are likely to have. Of course this place is not cheap but we spent our 15th wedding anniversary there and it was worth every penny!

We thoroughly enjoyed our stay. The location, privacy and proximity to a nice beach was exactly what we wanted. The house cleaning, valet, pool and bell staff were excellent. They truly made us feel at home and tried to satisfy our every request. The valet staff truly excelled by thinking of what we needed even when we didn't, such as providing water when we went hiking up Diamond Head and asking if we needed umbrellas when it was raining. The only thing that disappointed us was our dining experience. As much as the other parts of the staff excelled the dining staff suffered. The attentativeness of the wait staff was mediocre at best and at times lacking. An example of such a case was when we were served the wonton soup appetizer but were not provided soup spoons. Also consistency was lacking. After realizing we did not order enough we had ordered another wonton soup and the second came out with a piece of shrimp tempora on it while the first did not have any. And again no soup spoons was provided. Also I had ordered a special cake for my wife's 40th birthday to be served after our dinner but the staff forgot and had to spend quite a bit of time trying to find it, to the point one of my children fell asleep waiting. I will say that the manager there did make us feel that he was truly sorry about it, but it shouldn't have happened in the first place considering I had ordered the cake months in advance to make the arrangements. Another area of improvement that our dining experience needed was the quality and taste of our entrees. The food was just "ok". It was not bad but not something I would consider up to the quality of the rest of your resort and definitely not on par of which we were paying for.Also the available food selection for our children was very poor. Even my young children have tastes beyond chicken strips and cheese pizza. It was not practical for them to have so few choices for a week long stay. Some additional pasta or other choices would have made us more likely to eat at the resort more.

My husband and I took an extended vacation to celebrate our 10th anniversary and included the Kahala Resort among several places we stayed. While other resorts and hotels may have your room ready when you get there and the front desk staff may check you in promptly, at the Kahala Resort, we felt like they were just waiting for us to arrive so that they could treat us like royalty. Upon check-in, Linda described our pre-assigned room and then gave us keys to 2 rooms and suggested that we view both and then call her from the room we wanted to stay in and she would have our luggage delivered to it. The rooms were equally luxurious, so we picked the one on the higher floor. On every second encounter with a staff member, they always greeted us by name. All the staff was exceptionally helpful and eager to please, e.g., when the valet brought my car around, he asked if I needed directions and then proceeded to draw a map that took me exactly to the ArtsFest at Kapiolani Park and on to the art museum. I must admit that with all the royal treatment, I actually had to convince my hubby to leave the resort and see other things on Oahu. The Kahala has several restaurants and the 3 we tried all had excellent food with varied selections. Our most delicious meal was at the the Oceanside Grill, and we enjoyed tasty breakfasts in the Plumeria. Live music by wonderful pianist David Swanson provided a romantic backdrop for cocktails and dinner in The Veranda, a magnificent space.I guess royalty doesn't spend much time on the internet, but we're accustomed to checking our email each morning and internet service in guestrooms is an extra charge -- unexpected in an ocean of wonderful experiences.

My family and I recently stayed at this fine Resort, prior to a weeks stay on Maui. We knew we were going to stay at the Four Seasons in Maui, but agonized over our first 3 nights in Oahu We saw some touchy comments on this site, but in the end booked a suite (with the amenities package) and could not have been happier.We booked a partial ocean view suite (which was awesome) for our family of three. My 15 year old daughter really loved her own bathroom and my wife and I the extra room. I think the suite package was very reasonable when you consider the airport transfers and very pampering in the niceties of morning coffee delivery and evening Pupus and cocktails. The cost of 2 rooms would have been more and 1 room without amenities not that much less.Reception was seemless, including lei greeting and a relly nice man playing ukulee and singing great Hawaiin tunes for your pleasure. Service without exception was friendly and spot on. Loved that they remembered to fill the ice bucket each night at turn down.The grounds were very well cared for and the "private beach" really great and calm for swimming. My wife and daughter did stand up paddle boarding one morning with Peter (he was really patient and genuinly nice) and had no problem switching from a surf lesson to paddle board even with no notice and a lower billing for his company.I mention this, because at no time did I experience any nickle and diming as some reviewers have suggested. Of course, when staying at a resort of this caliber you should expect to tip generously for the service and experiences you are enjoying.One note on location, we found it perfect for us, but if you are staying for more than a few days, a rental car would be nice. We did use the shuttle one aftrnoon and rented a car for one day right at the resort. Both experiences very easy.Breakfast at Plumeria each morning was really good and the location stunning. We were at first disappointed to find on our arrival that Plumeria had recently been closed for dinner on Wednesdays. However, we ended up enjoying our first night meal at the Veranda off of the lobby. Very comfortable (we ordered off the Hokus menu and the more casual Veranda menu and enjoyed the best of both worlds). Im sure I am missing something, but let me reiterate book the room you want/can at this resort and be prepared to really enjoy yourself. When we return to Oahu I would not consider staying anywhere else. Sorry about any misspellings but very tired from 24 hours of delayed travel home from Maui yesterday.

I read only great reviews on "Tripadvisor" regarding this hotel however we were not impressed with the rooms that were appointed to us. We booked 2 rooms and were given 2 rooms about 4 rooms apart and both with no balcony. When we requested one balcony we were asked to pay and extra charge. Then the "Dolphin Quest" program wanted to charge us a cancellation fee for wanting to up-grade our pre-reserved dolphin encounter from one person to 2 people! Finally, we were always getting interruptions in our room regarding our credit card charges which were not going through when we had specified upon checking-in that we preferred to settle the account at the end of our stay so we didn't incur too many bank fees every single time our card was charged.
Very nice hotel to stay in but it's too far from Waikiki.Great breakfast buffet (=

My husband and I had our wedding reception and honeymoon at the Kahala in 1972, then returned for our 25th anniversary and just spent the last 5 days for our 40th Wedding Renewal and it could not have been more perfect. What I have always loved about the hotel is it's elegance and sophistication with a warm and personal true feeling of the Aloha spirit. We had several friends come in from the mainland and they also fell in love with the hotel. The staff were all very attentive, courteous and could not be more helpful.The rooms have always been and continue to be very large, luxurious, well appointed and very clean. Even though our room was within close proximity to the elevators, the rooms are so well sound proofed that we did not hear any noise, not even from the room next to us.

We stayed here for a family vacation in a partial ocean view suite. We've stayed in a number of high end hotels around the world, including names such as Ritz Carlton, St. Regis, Four Seasons, Orient Express, and others. This may be the best place we've ever stayed. It is not luxury in a stuffy manner - but they've got the simple elegance of island luxury down. It was like staying at a (very) wealthy uncle's oceanfront home. Four things make this resort stand out - and only one thing brings it down.1) Staff Friendliness. I cannot remember making eye contact with someone who worked at the Kahala who did not say hello (or aloha or good morning). They were so friendly and accommodating - from the escort to the suite and the explanation of the resort (for which a gratuity was declined) to addressing our many requests, such as our rotating times for coffee and drinks (see suite amenities).2) The Suite. This room was huge. There was a very large (700 sq ft?) bedroom, an equally sized living room, and two full bathrooms, each with double vanities, standing showers, tubs, and closets. And very well appointed with nice furnishings. Every suite comes with a range of 'extras' such as morning coffee, afternoon drinks and appetizers, cabana at the pool, etc. I know that you pay for these with your room rate, but it is a nice touch to know that you have all these things - we even made it an evening ritual after the pool time was over to come up to the room, shower for dinner, and order our cocktails. Very nice touch.3) Marine Life and Landscaping. At the resort are the much trumpeted dolphins, but also there are sea turtles, colorful fish, and birds. This and the general well appointed resort just made everything beautiful. The entire resort was a postcard.4) The Veranda. I wasn't expecting this, but the Veranda at night had an entertainer who was so exceptionally good, just sitting there having a drink was an event by itself. I think that most nights, I went down there for a drink and to listen to some outstanding music.5) Location. Some people may not like the seclusion of the resort, but for us, the distance from Waikiki was a huge advantage. Having just stayed at the Royal Hawaiian the two nights before, we were looking for something away from hubbub of the traffic and the strip. The Kahala is all by itself among multi-million dollar homes. We had the public beach to ourselves (who would venture out that far to get there) and never ever had any difficulty finding a place for ourselves.As I said, I had very few complaints/areas for improvement. For a resort of this quality, you would expect an equally spectacular pool. However, it was only a very simple, oval pool like you might find on a nice cruise ship. Also, the coral was so abundant and so close to shore the actual useable ocean near the resort beach was quite limited. However, the best accolade I can give the Kahala is that my 7-year old daughter, for the second week of our 2-week trip to Hawaii, kept saying about every other hotel - "this is nice, but it doesn't compare to the Kahala." I wouldn't hesitate to go back.

Yesterday, my husband and I went to visit the Kahala to see if we wanted to stay there at a future date. We come to Hawaii most years and have just spent over 4 weeks on Oahu in wonderful rented houses by the ocean.As we drove into the garage, we thought it said $4 for the first half hour but can be validated. Our bad that we did not read more carefully. It turns out, it's $4 for the first 10 minutes, then $35!!!! You could spend $25 at the resort and get validation but we had already spent $12 for two Haagendaz ice cream bars and knew there was nothing we wanted to purchase, so simply paid up. But, it hurt and makes us never want to come back. Not a good way to drum up new business! #disappointedThe resort seemed nice but a bit cramped and dated. From the pictures in the hotel, you can see that it used to be a place celebrities had dinner at and some stayed there. But this seems to have been a while ago. And as the parking attendant told us, they just introduced the very expensive parking fees - probably to reestablish exclusivity. I think this is a nicer location than Waikiki, as it is quieter, and there are obviously not a lot of resorts outside Waikiki on Oahu. I think for the money, you can get a much better value at the Turtle Bay Resort in a quiet and natural setting. But, if you like to see and be seen, this might be the place.

We stayed here for the last night of our honeymoon and it was suppose to be a special place... It is awful!! And I was I tears we were spending $700 for it when ever $400 a night hotel has exceeded this. The staff here almost rude and completely unfriendly. The room was shabby and uncared for (ie scuff marks all over walls). The pool area not relaxing or enjoyable. And the food mearly mediocre (ie processed chicken on salad not even real chicken!) I said to my new husband after being there 30 minutes... Should we move hotels? We really should of and strongly suggest not staying here. You will be dissapointed.

We stayed here for one night only, when my husband had to work for a day on Oahu whilst we were on family holiday. We picked this resort so my daughter and I could entertain ourselves as my husband work. It was fabulous everything about this place is perfect, the staff, the check in the rooms, the views, the food, the pool, the beach, the communal areas (check out the chandeliers in foyer). This is the way to holiday, yes it is pricey but you get what you pay for . We had a Dolphin Lanai room close to the end of the building so only a short walk out of the building down the steps to beach, this room was quite expensive compared to std rooms, the resort is so good though a std room would make for just as an enjoyable stay. You really do unsderstand why presidents, royalty and emperors have chosen to stay here. However this is not a pretentious resort, it is a very relaxing and welcoming place. For our second night on Oahu we stayed at The Royal Hawaiin in Wakiki, which was a top notch hotel but it came nowhere close to the Kahala. Out of all our hotels on Oahu and The Big Island the Kahala was just heads and shoulders above them all.

We've stayed at the Kahala for the past four years over the holidays. The upcoming year will be our 5th time. We usually stay for 2 -3 weeks and it's never long enough.The hotel is beautiful. The rooms are big. The staff is wonderful. We travel with our dog and it's a very pet friendly hotel. We love the *private* beach.It's expensive over Christmas and New Years, but I never feel like they don't live up to our expectations for a high-end hotel. Prices are lower throughout the year and I've seen some great deals advertised for other months.It's very crowded between Christmas and New Years. We put up with the crowds, but always ensure our trip includes dates before and after the holidays. It really clears out after New Years and you get a couple of fabulous days without crowds before the people with the golf tournament come in.The Kahala burger is one of my favorites....egg, avocado and bacon!We originally planned on getting married there several years ago on New Years Even and I'm really glad we didn't. The view is beautiful, but if you are getting married over the holidays you are in the middle of a ton of people.

We stayed at the Kahala Resort for 5 nights and the experience was great. Jackie was great when we checked in and was always very helpful for anything we needed. The balcony in our room overlooked the golf course as well as the beach. The food was delicious and the waitstaff always accommodated our needs.
