The hotel is not right on Waikiki which is nice because that area gets very crowded. The beach right outside the hotel was in great shape and very well kept.

We just returned from our, I believe, sixth stay at the Kahala. As in the past, we greatly enjoyed our stay. I have previously posted about prior stays so feel free to review my post from June 2011. Instead of providing another point-by-point description of the various amenities, let me give some general observations and advice.As many have noted, the Kahala is not a brand spanking new hotel. It is definitely an older property and the style is likewise not ultra-modern. If you are looking for super updated, slick and shiny, the Kahala is not the place for you. Instead, it has a relaxed charm while still being upscale.About the rooms: unless you are booking a suite, the rooms (at least in my experience) are pretty much the same. We have had 5 different rooms in both the tower and the dolphin wing and all were virtually identical; we also tried a suite which was gorgeous but expensive. There really are only primary two variations in non-suite rooms (well three, if you count price): view and balcony. The only other variation is the tower, Diamond Head v. Koko Head. The Diamond Head Tower is closer to the parking lot and hotel entrance while Koko Head looks more over the dolphin lagoon and is slightly closer to the beach. In case you haven’t seen it, the hotel has a color coded map showing where each room category is located: http://www.kahalaresort.com/rooms-suites/index.cfmDecide which components are important to you, what you can afford, and go with it. I personally prefer the Koko Head Tower or the dolphin lagoon rooms. We have always chosen to have a balcony and have made great use of it. One more tip on room selection: do not expect to be upgraded from the category you book. Unlike other hotels we have stayed at, the Kahala does not seem to do this, even when rooms are available, for special occasions (or when you are multi-repeat customers like we are).Now for the criticism. First let me say that I find the staff that you interact with day to day to be amazing. They are extremely friendly and accommodating – the staff in the spa and bar remembered us from a year ago. But I think that hotel management should take a serious look at its higher-level customer service practices. In addition to my earlier comment about room upgrades (not to mention the point in my prior review about our ignored anniversary) I am very much starting to agree with comments from posters about being charged for everything. Case in point: we asked if a late check-out would be possible. Absolutely! We could check out at 2 pm – for the bargain fee of $80. Really? Come on now, either you can do it or not. If not, no biggie, but $80 for 2 additional hours? Sorry, but much as I enjoy your hotel, even I, an extremely loyal customer, cannot overlook that one. I have already overlooked the high parking, internet, beach chair, etc. charges but I have never seen a late check-out fee before. I sure hope this is just the Kahala.Sorry for the rant, but on our last day, this really rubbed us the wrong way. In any event, I still give it 5 stars. We very much enjoyed our stay from food, to spa, to room, to beach. Just know the lay of the land so your expectations will be reasonable from the high-level service perspective.Notwithstanding the foregoing, we definitely recommend the hotel and will probably stay again on future stays.

We stayed at The Kahala for 5 nights and it was a wonderful experience. From the minute we arrived we felt like special guests. I have stayed at 5 star resorts before, including The Four Seasons and The Ritz-Carlton, but the service we received at The Kahala exceeded both of those. All of the staff greets you by name throughout your stay. If you have gone to dinner in Hokus, the next morning when you are at the breakfast buffet the hostess/servers ask about your experience the night before. We had the breakfast buffet included in our package. It was a very nice start to each day - great views and good food.We had a corner room on the top floor with partial ocean view. It was a beautiful view of the golf course and ocean. Since we were on the top floor, the balcony was very windy, to the point that we needed jackets out there at night. Room was very nice and well appointed. Some aspects of the hotel show a bit of age, but overall grounds are beautiful and well kept. We will definitely stay here again when we return to Hawaii.

As a local who knows all the hotels on the island and someone who has always been a big fan of the Kahala Resort, it is clear something us changed. When we went to the beach, which was very empty due to the high winds and spotty weather we were told we could not sit under a cabana or in the lounge chairs with a cover as those go for $50 to $100 a day. It was 3:30 and we were asked to move. Really? Since when does the price of the room not entitle us to sit anyway. Reminds of those hotels who tried the "resort Fee" and we all know how that went over. Went to the bar for a drink at the hotel lobby bar area and ordered 2 nice glasses of wine. Was expecting some nuts or something while enjoying our drinks before dinner however nothing arrived. When we asked the very lovely server said "of course she would bring something". Next a small bread plate arrived with a handful of peanuts! Tacky and just embarrassing. It would have been better if she just said they don't serve anything. Clearly the hotel is pinching pennies and it shows. I hope it gets better as we just arrived today and the staff is terrific but the management clearly is having financial issues. Disappointing at such a Grande Dame of a property

We spent 4 nights at this hotel as part of a work trip last week. Nice big lobby, with our room being on the 3rd floor with a mountain view. To be honest, the view was still spectacular even if it wasn't the sea. The rooms was lovely, 2 massive double beds, great big bathroom, nice shower, seperate sinks. Nice and spacious. The maids were very polite and friendly, always saying hello.We were quite surprised when we got to the pool area. The actual pool is tiny compared to the size of the hotel. I get the impression this is quite an old hotel with some heritage as is shown by all the photos they have hung up in the main corridor of all the famous people who have visited. And maybe back then having a large pool was not so important. Ironically there is a pool lagoon, where they have a turtle or two and some dolphins. I guess it depends on whether you agree with dolphins in captivity or not, but the kids seemed to enjoy it. Personally I would open that pool to the public and release the dolphins :) Service is not the best at the restaurant at breakfast. It's not cheap, $30+ per person, and clearly they have more guests than seats, as there is a queue, yet I always saw empty tables, so I think maybe it's moer about the time to clear tables. But the view from the breakfast restaurant over the ocean is incredible. Breakfast too is a little disappointing. Nice lady who makes the omelettes but I don't think she knows how. Several people returned theirs. More scrambled than Omelette.The gym is great, with modern equipment, headphones etc. Hotel also provides a free shuttle to Waikiki town centre, although it's incredibly touristy, top end stores catering to wealthy Japanese tourists, designer stores etc. Parking was $30ish a day, not cheap. But having a small pool and small beach area, gave us an incentive to hire a car from Waikiki and drive up to North Shore and drive around the perimiter of the island. Awesome. So best of both worlds, enjoy Oahu and sleep in a nice room!

This hotel is about 30 min from town so you don't feel the business of the city. It's calm, serene, and beautiful. My room was a perfect size with one wall of sliding doors which we kept open to hear the ocean. The bed was so comfortable, I melted to sleep each night.We were greeted with a complimentary bottle of champagne to celebrate our honeymoon.We had breakfast and dinner at the Plumeria beach house. Nice breakfast selection and very helpful service during dinner...food was excellent too.We were up early enough to watch the dolphins get fed in the morning and have their morning play sessions.The only negative aspect of the hotel (and so minor) is I wish the pool area was bigger. Since I was only in Honolulu for 2 nights this was even an issue but it would've made the resort perfect.Would definitely stay here again and recommend to others!

This is paradise. The entire family enjoyed it. Every person we met was friendly and helpful. The suite was divine and the view from the balcony was gorgeous. The food was delicious. The beach was gorgeous and we enjoyed Stand Up Paddle Boarding. We never tired of watching the dolphins in the lagoon.

I stayed here for a business event. The resort property is beautiful. Our room was on the golf course side which felt tucked away and secluded which was nice. The room was gorgeous and very spacious. The bathroom was very nicely outfit as well. The highlight of the hotel property are the dolphin pools. I could sit and watch these guys swimming around and doing tricks all the time. As I was told "those dolphins are going to make us late to everything."The pool area and beach are very comfortable, however service on the beach and at the beach restaurant were ridiculously slow - with the only exception being Kelly Ann. The last day we sat at the beach restaurant for a solid ten minutes without ever being greeted although two servers walked right by our table. When we finally got menus that we got for ourselves , we got waited on. We both ordered a fish sandwich and a salad to split. The table behind us even after ordering after us received their food and finished eating before we even got ours. After the first 30 minutes I asked where it was and how much longer and our server actually told us that he gave one of our sandwiches away and they were having to cook another one. This was all the service we got after aggressively tipping30% for the whole trip. It really left a sour taste in my mouth.

After having taken almost a ten year hiatus from the Hawaiian Islands it was an absolute delight to return to the legendary Kahala Resort . From the moment we pulled up into their circular driveway one could feel the understated mid-century elegance ,casual sophistication & warm aloha that exudes from the Kahala hotel & professional staff. Amazingly well kept throughout the property Kahala truly feels like your peaceful luxurious home away from home !Most staff are proudly & amazingly the same some after nearly 15-20 years ! I think this says alot about a resort. Rooms are cool,spacious & soothing in light cream & white tones with solid wood beds. Bathrooms are long & spacious. ( Odd having closets in bathrooms though ) . Personally I'm not one for stereotypical Oceanfront view units. If I want beach I know where to find it. I much prefer the Koolau Mtn views w essential balcony overlooking Waialae golf course. It has much more sedative effect especially at dusk. Breakfast buffet is food highlight here and a must to have included in stay. Plumeria for dinner extremely competant as well. We didnt do Hoku's this time around. Plus the old Japanese restuarant is now closed.  Pool area is very small & compact but great.Small kids pool for toddlers & jacuzzi too. BEachfront is perfectly suited for swimming and sunbathing. But no interesting clear waters or reef systems . Most people probably feel that it's a "schlep" and inconvenient distance from all the action of Waikiki , but that's exactly what Kahala's asset is . It's designed to be an oasis from the noise of modern urban Honolulu citylife !! Car rental is essential to shuttle to & from Waikiki or do excursions up North . Kahala's not cheap (ie $500 +/ nt ) but show me what is anymore . But I'm selfish and shouldn't even be writing this because I'd like to keep Kahala an exclusive secret hideaway. So please don't listen to me . Keep staying in downtown Waikiki at the big Hyatts,Hiltons,Marriotts and leave this inconvenient far removed 50 year old hotel to me !!

Stayed 5 nights at the Kahala Resort. We had stayed before at the Outrigger Reef in Waikiki, and this time, for our wedding anniversary, decided to splurge a bit and stay at the Kahala. I guess I expected too much - from the reviews and from the photos online. Don't get me wrong - the room was beautiful, the mountain view was nice (overlooking the golf course), the lobby was grand, the overall architecture of the hotel was gorgeous, the dolphin lagoon was a pleasant surprise, but there were certain things that just disappointed my wife and I. The foremost negative experience was the room service schedule. Their website said 24 hours. And in our room, the menu listed schedules for 10:30 PM onwards. My wife and I got back to the hotel late at night, went to the gym with the intent of having room service for dinner after gym. So, after looking at the menu, and choosing the food, when we called room service, we were shocked to learn that the service was closed from 10 PM to 6 AM. So, we couldn't eat. I then went down to the lobby and asked the front desk if I could order from any of their restaurants (Hoku, Plumeria, Veranda), but Bart of the front desk said all were closed already. That was frustrating. There I was, hungry from working out, and we couldn't order food. Bart tried to do his best by getting food from his office (I'm assuming the food was his), and though his intention was good, I felt insulted by what he did, like I was receiving hand-me-downs from him. I felt they didn't go out of their way to help me with my problem. I decided to ask about nearby food joints that were open and he suggested a McDonald's (which closes at 11 PM - this was around 1045 PM already). Again, I guess Bart assumed I had a car, which I didn't. The whole experience was sorely disappointing, for a hotel that had a high reputation. Moreover, the hotel didn't even have a 24-hour convenience store?! I mean, the hotel is located around 6 kilometers from Waikiki and Kalakaua (you're surrounded by the golf course and apartments, and no 7-11 stores within walking distance). Needless to say, the next night, my wife and I bought take-out food from the Royal Hawaiian Center food court for our late dinner. The other negative experience was the bed and pillows. By the 2nd night, my wife and I had stiff necks from the pillows. The bathroom in our room looked old. It looked out of place versus the room itself, which was beautiful. The tiles in the bathroom were ugly. As for the room itself, it was very nice. Spacious, with lots of sunlight, a huge window showing the mountains and the golf course. It was nice that when you entered the room after checking in, the CD played soft guitar music - relaxing. The breakfast was superb. We got the breakfast package so we had breakfast every morning (expensive, at 77usd for 2 pax). You had eggs, sausages, rice, fruits, salad, yogurt, cereals, oatmeal - great selection. The staff in the Plumeria restaurant during breakfast were nice - like Corrine.The beach area was not as good as I thought it would be. The shore was not wide. The water was too shallow for swimming and snorkeling. The water was murky when I tried swimming. I noticed that not a lot of people were lounging at the beach area. Yes, you have some privacy in the beach, but after a while, it was boring. Having a free shuttle to the Ala Moana Mall and Royal Hawaiian Center was very important for us, because then we could eat and shop and stroll in the Kalakaua area. If you decide to stay at the Kahala, buy some take-out food and water from Royal Hawaiian or Ala Moana Mall for your late night eats. The people in the Kahala were good. Allison of the Business Center was great and accommodating, the check-in staff were ok, the bell desk people were helpful (like Dean). They always tried to address us by our surnames. You had 30 mins free Internet in the Business Center daily. And you had free water bottles every night when the housekeeping staff turned down your bed.A surprising touch was the dolphin lagoon. We didn't expect that we'd be able to see dolphins anytime we wanted. It was fun seeing the dolphins there. Make sure you look at the photos on the wall going to the Business Center - you'll see all the celebrities who've stayed at the Kahala - like Alicia Keys and Michael Jackson. It's a shame that we had negative experiences at the Kahala. But the room was nice, the service was good, the breakfast was delicious, the hotel grounds were beautiful. I just wish they'd have a convenience store (sell snacks and sandwiches), and also have a microwave in the room so that night owls can eat at night. And change the pillows and bed please. For the same price, one could stay at one of the hotels on Kalakaua (like Halekulani or even the historic Royal Hawaiian Hotel). I don't think we'll stay at the Kahala again.

My husband and I came to this resort 9 years ago on our honeymoon, and it may have been under different management at that time. We were in heaven then, and we were in heaven when we returned this month. The Kahala has timeless charm. Though you are near Waikiki for shopping, beach activites, and food - you feel a thousand miles away. The pace is so much calmer at the Kahala. We loved watching the dolphins! You should swim with them if you stay here. We did it on our honeymoon and it is an experience we will never forget. We had the best jumbo prawns while sitting on the veranda. The rooms are exceptional. This is a place to go if you want pampering. We will always hold a special place in our hearts for the Kahala!

We have just returned after a 8 night stay at the beautiful Kahala Resort (our second visit).Yes it is beautiful, the rooms luxurious, the beds so comfortable you would like to spend the day in them. The pool and beach fantastic, service great, nothing is too much trouble. All positive.On the negative side, we had a 9th floor room (partial ocean view) and after seeing it we requested a room on a lower level - nothing available even over 8 nights! The carpet needed cleaning. We found the restaurant menu after 18 months (last visit) was basically the same and choices are limited. The room service menu needs a serious update. The Kahala is a five star resort I can make a tastier pizza at home than the one served to us the night the main restaurant was closed. Very disappointing. To end on a positive note you can spend all day just watching the dolphins BLISS!!!

This was the nicest hotel room I have ever stayed in. We used American Airlines miles to pay for it so it felt like a great deal too. Service was excellent. The public areas were a zoo. The place was over run by children. Maybe I was just jealous, my parents never too me to a fancy hotel. Restaurants were mediocre and impossible to get into. You had to make reservations for breakfast or stand around for an hour waiting to have your name called. Not what you want to do in Hawaii! Plus, I hated to see the creatures on display. I wanted to set the poor turtle free! Those beautiful animals belong in the ocean.

Some 20 minutes drive from Waikiki, it is located away from the busy area. So guests get a secluded paradise by the cost of time and $20 taxi fare. The hotel also provides a not-too-frequent free shuttle bus to Waikiki.The resort gives you that kind of up class resort feeling once you stepped into the hotel area. Grand reception, high ceiling, beautiful chandlier, big sofa, light breeze, spacious verandah, everything one is looking for in a resort.Room is wide and spacious, writing desk and a lounge chair in the room, another lounge chair in the lanai, great view to the ocean, light music played on CD, spacious bathroom, double washing basin, double closet, separated shower and bathtub...... there is not much to critize.Breakfast restaurant is decent and quiet, with tables extending to the lawn. Small sized pool with some other smaller jacuzzi pools. There is a dolphin training class on site and a few pools with 5 dolphins in it. Residence can join the course and play with dolphins. Although it is not a private beach but you don't see many outsiders except hotel guests at the beach. Many kinds of water sports class is available. There is a Japanese restaurant in the hotel but I did not try.I would recommend staying at Kahala to enjoy the vacation and commute to Waikiki for shopping.

Kahala resort is not on Waikii Beach, it is away from busy streets, restaurants and shops. So if you really looking forward to relax while you are in Honolulu, this is the hotel to stay.This is a very nice hotel but room rates are overly charged. Hotel was full and we didnt have reservation so our room choice was mountain view room. Hotel has two sections, one section has tall building and other section has two floors. We stayed in room 1214 looking at golf course which was very green, quite and peacefull. If you stand in balcony, you can see the ocean from between trees.Room size was large enough with a small couch and two comfortable chairs. Bed was high bed and very comfortable. Bathroom was a very nice size bathroom with two seperate sink and closets. There is a coffee maker to make tea and coffee.Breakfast was a nice buffee with many different selections.The restaurants for lunch has a very limited menu. Since this hotel away from restaurants , you would expect more selection. Almost every day we had to eat same food for lunch since we didnt like few other choices in the menu.We ordered room service in the evenings except one night. Room service was fast and ok food. Only one evening we ate at the restaurant and food was very good. I highly recommend reservation for dinner at the restaurant since local people comes here for dinning.

The Kahala is in a peaceful location with access at the cost of time, money and some inconvenience to Waikiki. The decor of the hotel is pleasing. The dolphins and the seclusion are the highlights. Based on our experience and other reviews the standard of service, cleanliness and upkeep is not consistent and is not always acceptable. For surfing, swimming and sunsets I would recommend one of the Waikiki hotels. For calm and quiet the Kahala could be for you. Use hotel website to check for specials and promotions or call them. Website has diagram of room locations. Our experience:1 hour before check-in our room was ready. No lei greeting, leis are included in some packages but not all. I declined to pay extra for them, as for me that defeats the purpose. We had enjoyed leis at other top hotels already. The room (dolphin lanai): the minibar in the room is empty. An empty fridge can indeed be useful, but understand there was no bottle of water, nothing, in the room. To have a sip of water we would have had to order and wait for room service. (Maybe the tap water is fine, but facing a long flight the next day it is not the time to take a chance). Room and bathroom/dressing area spacious, pleasant color scheme, furniture especially beds not to my taste but not bad. Bedding is of a high quality. Nice view of dolphin lagoon and dear child very happy to find a little stuffed dolphin on bed. However I don't think I have ever been in a room with that many scuff marks and digs in the walls. Next to everything that moved, there was a deep dig into the plasterwork: the lights above the beds, the television, even the towel rails next to the vanities. I felt insulted to be put into a room in that state of repair. We were there as a special treat for our dear child, so I sucked it up. Toilet is in a closed off tiny room, on the plain and ugly side, but more disturbing to me were 2 marks next to the toilet roll holder that I was able to easily clean off. Shame my disinfecting wipes got thrown away by mistake that morning. Dh and I clean the 2 chairs on our lanai which were filthy. Verandah: We had a late lunch and tea on the open air part of the verandah, decent food, very helpful hostess, very peaceful setting. Off to the beach. We let the pool/beach boys help us so they could explain which seating needs to be rented and which not, etc. Lots of complimentary loungers available. Our towels were lain on loungers and then the beach/ pool guy walked away, leaving us to brush the pile of sand from the previous users off of the foot part. I can't believe it. I think of the St. Regis pool boys, trotting back and forth with warm towels on a drizzly day, and immediately cleaning up when someone left. The beach in front of the Kahala is peaceful (nearly empty) and the waves break quite far offshore - you cannot bodysurf or boogeyboard here, for us disappointing, but not the Kahalas fault. There is a platform one could swim to and jump off of, fun for dc. Dh tries swimming parallel to the beach, but the depth varies and he could not swim properly as too shallow in parts. Maybe unlucky. Dh, like another reviewer, suspects the sand is industrial and does not belong on a beach, I did not look too closely. We tried out the main pool, a reasonably sized oval with a built in bench along one side. Had fun there with dc until 6pm, when pool closes. There is also a small pool for toddlers and a hot tub/jacussi - but the ?hot tub had an ugly strip of plastic yellow tape across its entrance while we were there. During our short stay 2 weddings and 1 event are held, but to the sides of the pool and beach area, we didn't feel inconvenienced and dc enjoys glimpsing the brides. Back to our room to bathe - dc choses the tub, so I checked it - 2 pale (head) hairs, I looked closer and then ran my hand inside - lots of white residue, soap scum or product residue. We were furious. I called housekeeping, who came a few minutes later and started cleaning. In our wet bathing suits and beach covers we waited half an hour to have use of the bathroom. Following regulations the door to our room was jammed wide open, so in that time our family and our things were on full view to those passing by. At least we had a lanai, so we waited there and watched the dolphins and a chopped piece of the sunset. The location of the Kahala is not the best for sunsets. I spoke to the manager, who apologised and offered to make some form of ammends. We chose to go to the Friday night buffet at the Plumeira beach house and the hotel offered to pick up the tab of dinner and a round of drinks, which was something and calmed dh down somewhat. The food at the buffet was excellent, we went back and forth more than we usually do. We did not hear other guests from our room, but the airco does cycle on and off so make arrangements if you are a light sleeper. I had a hurried but good breakfast and took dc to a kid's Dolphin Quest program - an hour of marine animal instruction and 30 minutes with the dolphins for $287. Dc was the only one signed up that morning, so I did feel it was fair value and a fabulous experience. Not sure in a small group with less dolphin time how I would have felt. The trainers were really really great with our dc. I did find that $150 for a cd of the photos taken robbery. Later dc spent a few happy hours with a new friend by the pool before we checked out. I paid $80 to have the room for 2 more hours, which I suppose is a reasonable charge compared to the room rates, but I had to be moved to another room for those 2 hours. It was all easily arranged with the front desk and bell boy staff, who were very helpful and courteous. Dc (5) loved loved loved the dolphins, but found the pink palace (Royal Hawaiian) better because of the surfing at Waikiki and the slide at the neighbouring Sheraton's pool.
Can't say enough of how much we loved the Kahala, on Oahu! Everything was perfect, from our room, the service, the food and especially the beach.

We choose this hotel for a 2 day stay before going on the ncl cruise round the Hawaiian islands. The hotel is beautiful with a lovely beach and they have their own dolphins too. We arrived late having travelled direct from the u.k. Our room was upgraded on arrival, it was a huge room with a massive bathroom that had a walk in shower, bath and double sink, and with a balcony overooking the golf course, I wish we could of stayed longer, I would recommend getting away from the hustle and bustle of Waikiki. Lovely breakfast, we sat each day overlooking the ocean - perfect. we did have dinner at this hotel too, quite expensive but I guess you could get a taxi out, we just didnt bother!! Loved it.

We stayed in a partial ocean view room. I know some people have complained that it is a view of the car park, but it is a great for people watching so I would recommend it if your a but nosey like me! However if you don't like the sound of that i'd recommend a mountain view room because it looked beautiful. All the staff we met were extremely friendly and helpful. We came for our first wedding anniversary and when we arrived we received a complimentary bottle of sparkling wine and yummy chocolates which was a great start. The beds were super comfortable and the bathroom was very good and spacious too. We went for the ocean package that includes breakfast buffet. The breakfast was delicious and the staff were very attentive even when it was busy. Pretty much every morning when we were having breakfast we saw couples getting married which was lovely. We also had afternoon tea on the Veranda which was also delicious. It is also fascinating to watch dolphins and turtles that live at the hotel :) The only bad points I would say would be that the carpets looked a little worn and like evrybody else says...you have to pay for your internet except in the business centre (C'mon Kahala sort it out!) If you think it is too expensive don't go! I think it is worth the money, you would pay a lot of money for a hotel in England and nowhere in England is a nice a Hawaii! However I would definitely recommend a lanai. The best part of the hotel was the staff they made us feel very welcome and made sure we had an excellent holiday. If i lived in the US I would go every year!

My husband was on business to be held in the conference center at the resort and I tagged along for a vacation. From the lei greeting when we arrived to the hugs from the staff we got to know when we left, this resort was outstanding. Once we were checked in, we were escorted to our room and given a tour of its features. The rooms are very pretty with elegant furnishings and a huge 5 piece bathroom. The two sinks were on opposites sides of the bathroom allowing 2 people to get ready without being in each other's space. There was a welcome gift of Kahala chocolate covered macademia nuts that were delicious. Once we got settled, we ventured downstairs to the Plumeria Beach House for a light meal. The food and the mai tais were awesome. The next morning we had the breakfast buffet at the Plumeria which was delicious. There are coffee makers in each room but if you are out for a sunrise walk, coffee is available downstairs. It's only available for an hour or so. The concierge staff was very professional and helpful. Special thanks to James for helping me plan a couple of hikes and a trip to the Palace. The private beach is a wonderful departure from the chaos of Waikiki. The hotel shuttle goes to the Royal Hawaiian Shopping Center and from there, you can walk much of Waikiki. Dolphin Quest in also on the grounds and is fun to watch. The hotel offers some classes during the mornings on the Hula, Lei making and Ukelele. Aunty Pricilla, the teacher, is a lot of fun. This hotel is wonderful and should I travel to Oahu again, I would definitely stay there.

The Kahala Resort and Hotel has a wonderful reputation which is absolutely unfounded in my opinion! After a long wait for our room, we were taken to an 'upgraded' room that was dirty and generally 'tired'. The decorative cover at the foot of the bed was full of sand, leaving the bed gritty, the furniture and floors had old stains and built up dirt. It just needed a good cleaning. This was a complete turn off for me! The food and service were fine but nothing spectacular. All in all a very disappointing experience at a very high price.
Nice hotel away from the crowds in Waikiki. Nice views and quiet. Rooms are comfortable and spacious. All the restaurants are pretty good.

my wife and I stayed here in late march 2012...our 2nd time and we love this place. It's a place for complete rest and relaxation away from the crowed streets of waikiki. It would be nice to find a small fault with the Kahala but the fact is...there is'nt any. We both are still talking about the beds and the linen and how wonderful it is. My wife loved the bathrooms with the separate vanities. The grounds are lovely and the staff ever so helpful and polite. This truly is paradise waiting.P.S. I did find a small fault (sorry)....the coffee makers are too noisy!

Views like you see in the movies and set in amongst suburban homes and Golf course.Very quiet with amazing views.Yet only 15 mins max from Waikiki.Free shuttles to local shops or Waikiki or Ala Moana.The Dolphin Adventure is a must.Huge rooms with huge bathrooms.

This was a wonderful change for us. We had been at another respected hotel but things did not work out well so we left and found this place. What a spectacular find. Our room was luxurious and well appointed. The bathroom alone is worth the stay. We ate in the restaurant every day. The days on the beach were very pleasant. I don't approve of the keeping of dolphins but at least the ones kept by this hotel received continuous loving attention.The pool was not heated but the weather was cool so I would have preferred it were heated. All in all, we enjoyed our 4 days there.

The hotel is situated at the end of the road on the east side of Diamond Head on a beaurtiful site with a lovely long beach. Know that it is too isloated from any activities in Honolulu so you have to rent a car or pay a 45$ cab fare each way. There is a free shuttle service to the malls however but not to off property restaurants you might want to try or scuba/snorkling boat trips on the West side of Oahu.The lobby has high ceilings, open air, with shops, bar, area for tea overlooking the lawns and pools. One large lagoon pool for 4 male bottlenose dolphins which are always being attended to and which guests pay to swim and pet. Another pool for fish and turtles and one for kids and one large pool for adults and kids. Lots of chairs for everyone.The rooms that face the beach are in exteneded wings from the main building. These expensive rooms are just ok, nothing special. The first room they gave us smelled of something off, not sure what but it wasn't pleasant. When we asked for a change, there wasn't any problem but the manager said "we thought we had fixed that problem by tearing out the wall " and gave us another room down the hall. Why did they give us that room in the first place? Doesn't any one check on these things? The bathrooms are large with two sinks which I like. Walls between the rooms are thin, we could hear the phone ringing continuously in the next room. When someone is in the hall, you hear every word they say. Rooms on the ground floor walk on to a private small patio and then on to the grass and the beach, 30 yards away.If you want a beach front experience and easy access by walking to a variety of restaurants, shops and activities, stay in Waikiki. If isolation is your thing, stay out here.

Paradise? Oh yes! We stayed at The Kahala Hotel & Resort as part of my birthday and Wedding Anniversary celebration and as far as the Hotel and it's location it couldn't have been more perfect. The hotel is set in grounds which include a lagoon that are home to the hotel's 4 dolphins, that if you wish and can afford you can book to have the experience of swimming with. The hotel does sit on a sandy beach in a sheltered bay, which is safe and calm enough for swimming for all abilities.We had an ocean view room which was a very good size and had a very comfortable king size bed  sofa, chairs and a desk, a lovely bathroom, with bath, separate large shower and 2 sinks and 2 wardrobes. The location of the hotel suited us as it is set north of Waikiki itself so away from the hustle and bustle of the city. You do need transport, either hire car or taxis into town. Taxis on average cost around $20 each way, but avoided the issue of parking which apparently can be tricky.Definitely recommend the hotel's breakfast, overlooking the sea, inside or out, perfect. We had this included in our package which is definitely worth doing.The staff were all extremely helpful and very pleasent..All in all perfect!

We spent 2 nights at the Kahala with our 2 teen daughters (15 & 14). They were unimpressed with the pool (small) and the beach (no waves for body boarding and so-so snorkeling). The amenity and food prices were steep ($32 for breakfast buffet) and the beds in our room were very uncomfortable. I think it would be a great option if you have young kids but if you have teens, you might want to consider a hotel closer to Waikiki beach. We had a car so we could get around easily.

My family of 2 adults and 3 children have just returned from a fantastic holiday in Honolulu. The hotel although a little old is so well maintained. The rooms are large with lots of closet space and spotlessly clean. The buffet breakfast is outstanding. The pool and beach are great and closed to the public so you really feel you are in a private resort. We caught the shuttle every afternoon to either Waikiki or Ala Moana shopping centre and were always relieved to return to our quiet resort.

We spent 6 weeks in Oahu and I think we have visited or stayed in most places on the island. The Kahala hotel is really the outstanding hotel. In one word, it is" top-notch" and very luxurious. We stayed in the east wing of the hotel, with a fantastic view of the golf course and part view of the ocean. The Kahala is located in the best area of Honolulu, quiet and well taken care of , but also very close to the action of Waikiki. The hotel has a shuttle bus going to Waikiki regularly. The staff is great, food in the restaurants ( Hoku's and Plumeria ) is also the best you can get. We did not try the Tokyo Tokyo restaurant so I cannot comment. The Cabanas Seaside grill is o.k to have some fast food. The gym is very well equipped and my wife loved the fitness classes. It is difficult to imagine that the hotel was built in 1964. Lots of money must have been spent on keeping everything in this great condition.

We just returned from Oahu. We stayed 8 nights at The Kahala Hotel and Resort. Our family, from the moment we arrived at their large beautiful lobby was greeted by everyone with a warm smile and by name on many occassions. The rooms (Dolphin Lanai) were very large and clean with everything that was needed, including a large complimemtary tote bag, great for use at the pool. Our rooms were about 15 feet from the Dolphin Lagoon providing us a great opportunity to see and hear the dolphins swim and play day and night.The Buffet breakfast was beyond words, if you couldn't find something you liked to eat, I would be quuite suprised. Joy, the Food and Beverage Administrative Assistant greeted all guests with her warm smile and friendly words every day. She is a lovely person and always willing to share a recipe with you for your favorite morning dish. Several mornings, we were served by Corrine another friendly and pleasant individual, always remembering my skim milk for by coffee.The winds were a little stronger than we anticipated but we were at the pool and beach every day, again the staff was always pleasant, friendly and helpful with towels, drinks and a refreshing afternoon ice pop.Jade was also very helpful in making the dolphin trainer for a day program a memorable one for our granddaughter.The Dolphin quest was an amazing experience for our family as we watched our granddaughter interact with the dolphins. The Dolphin Quest team are a remarkable group of people dedicated to their profession and in sharing their enthusiam and knowledge with all the quests that they worked with in the program or those just stopping at the lagoons to watch the dolphins.We have mentioned some of the staff at the resort with whom we had the pleasure to meet, but our comments would apply to the entire staff as we had nothing but a pleasant experience with all.I can't say enough about this resort, you must see it and feel it in person.We dined at the following restaurants:The Royal Hawaiian Hotel-Luau- a beautiful history lesson to see, hear and taste the culture of the Island Alan Wong's- the Richard Hal's tomato salad a mustChef Morimoto-everything we had was fantasticOrchid's- food was delightful and the view from the restaurant was wonderfulHouse without a key-food was great and sunset view and music was enjoyablePlumeria at the Kahala-all lunches were good, don't miss the Kahala hamburgerHoku's at the Kahala- food was excellent, great service and wonderful viewsThe Veranda Tea at the Kahala was just lovelyWolfgang-WHAT A STEAK!!!! That says it allOh yesTeddy's Bigger Burgers- Waikiki- a fun burger place and also very good

A long story but was not happy with our rooms . Two double beds in one of our rooms and BOTH have mattresses with deep indentions on the inside sides. Literally you are on a downhill slide. Impossible for two people to sleep in. I complained to housekeeping to no avail. After my unhappy battle regarding the status of my rooms, I knew it was futile to pursue with management. You won't be treated as if you matter to them as a customer so don't bother complaining.Inconsistent room cleaning. Some days before noon other days not until 2. One night turn down service was at 9:30 another 5:30.I am checking out tomorrow and will be sure to tell the front desk staff but it won't matter to anyone.Maybe it's time for me to find another hotel for my annual business trip to Oahu.

This is a fabulous hotel is you want to be in Honolulu but don't want to be in the middle of Waikiki. There is a very nice rather quiet beach at the hotel with water safe for swimming. There is a clean & pretty pool with hot tubs. There is a very large pond on the grounds with dolphins swimming around. You can even pay to swim with the dolphins. My kids did the program where they got in the water with the dolphins and it was safe and the dolphins appeared to be very happy and healthy. There are several good restaurants on site, one restaurant is best for couples with the other is great for couples or families or large groups. Buffets are great, especially if you like sea food. Hotel is a few miles from Waikiki, so if you want to spend most of your time there you might want to stay there. But this hotel is in the perfect location if you want to explore the island but still be near great destinations. There are bikes for loan or a beach to walk on and the location is relaxing and laid-back.

If you want to be close to Waikiki but avoid its crowds and noise then the Kahala is the resort for you. Free frequent shuttles to Wikiki but I recommend renting a car for your stay since there is so much to see on Ohau. Parking is $24 day but you can save that much by eating some meals elsewhere, do sign up for the breakfast buffet which is one of the best I've come across. The $15 day wireless (slow) charge is a bad and the toilet paper cold be softer but those are very minor complaints. The staff is very friendly and attentive.

It is a mystery to be unveiled every time we stay, what will be on the menu in each elegant restaurant, what will be served in the tea room, what music will be playing, what the dolphins will be doing, what wine specials there are, what exciting venue awaits, which movie stars will we catch a glimpse of... The luxurious hawaiian weather and the natural beauty combines with the architecture and talented staff to create an oasis our whole family treasures... And Massimo Sport provides VIP thrilling personalized excursions we can't say enough good things about... Massimo Sport and Kahala partner to make a truly unforgettable, remarkable, wonderful vacation. Alooooha!!

This is a slightly belated review but my husband and I stayed here in August 2011 after getting married in Las Vegas. We felt that we should post a review as we always use trip advisor ourselves prior to going anywhere. We came to the states from the UK and to his was a wonderful place to stay.We've never been to Hawaii before but the reaction from other people on the island, was that the Kahala resort is the "Beverly Hills of Hawaii". After our stay of 10 days we can say we felt that the service was fantastic, the hotel is beautiful, impeccable standards and cleanliness and very welcoming, we got garlands on arrival and as a honeymoon present a bottle of sparkling wine in our room which was unexpected and a great start to a fantastic break.There are a variety of places to eat within the hotel all of which have excellent standards, one of the best was an afternoon tea with champagne in the veranda restaurant overlooking the dolphin lagoon.If partying is your style this would most probably not be the best option as Waikiki is 15 mins down the road by taxi or bus and has all the hustle and bustle you might like. We enjoyed the serenity, peaceful tranquillity, privacy and personal beach service at the Kahala however we made full use of the free shuttle bus which took us into Waikiki and back within specified times. We made full use of room service in our spacious room with huge bed, lovely bathroom, separate shower/dressing area, fridge, turn-down service with plenty of chilled bottled water.Although we didn't have a sea view, the balcony was well worth it, sitting watching the sun go down over ancient volcanic mountains with a cold beer in hand after a hard day sunbathing on the private beach was particularly enjoyable. We took a couple of excursions from the resort, you can book and pay in the hotel and get their friendly advice, and away you go for the day.It's a long way to go half way around the planet to stay somewhere for a week or so but this was definitely worth it, 5 star means 5 star at the kahala! Excellent.

When considering a Hawaiian vacation most have a preconceived idea of what it should be like. This impression has usually been formulated from motion pictures, TV and glossy brochures. The one resort where the promise is surpassed by the actuality is the beautiful Kahala hotel and resort. Having been fortunate enough to visit frequently I am happy to report it just does not, and probably could not get any better than it is. A magnificent location,serene, beautifully laid out and impeccably cared for, anything and everything you could possibly wish for in a perfect vacation is at your fingertips.Location, no matter how important, fades quickly if the service is not of the same standard. Have no fear, there is nowhere on the planet that you will be treated more graciously than here at the Kahala. From arrival until departure you are nurtured as if you were royalty. Not surprising really they just truly do not know any other way to treat their guests.On your visit you will be amazed at how important you are made to feel. When you return (and you will return) you will be further staggered by how many of the things you need, or prefer are remembered and prepared for upon your return visit,It is virtually impossible to select any one area of this wonderful place as special because every part that you visit will impress you. Check in is smooth and all that you have requested will be exactly as you wanted it. Room - large, clean comfortable and every possible amenity you will need, and some you wont. The Spa, a truly 'died and gone to heaven' experience. On arrival check with Angelie and if Saori is available allow her to provide a memorable and incredibly relaxing massage. The food of course is excellent with a choice of Hokus, the Plumeria (my personal favorite) where the food, especially the nightly chefs preparation equal any offering in a higher priced location. Snacks on the beach, tea in the veranda, anywhere you choose to eat you can be assured of attentive service. Were I to name all of the ladies and gentlemen who make the dining experiences at the Kahala special it would take up far too much space. After your first culinary visit you will understand exactly what I mean.When deciding on your vacation hotel by all means check out the other properties and then make the smart decision and head straight for the Kahala. It's one decision you will never have cause to regret.

This is a delayed review, since we stayed here as a family in October of 2010. We stayed in a room in the Dolphin Lagoon Wing and my kids loved waking up each morning to see the dolphins swimming in the water below our lanai. The room itself was spacious, even with 2 beds in the room. Service was great at the restaurant each morning for our delicious breakfast buffet and also at the pool where we spent lots of time just hanging out, swimming & drinking mai-tais & lava flows. The pool is small for a resort this size, but the beach is great for swimming and there was a neat inflated raft we swam out to with the kids every day. We used the activities desk to try out paddle boarding one day and it was really convenient (paddle boarding was fun, but challenging when you're going against the tide). One of the activities desk staff even took our girls out to the end of this jetty to "fish" while we were paddle boarding. I'm not sure if this is something they do for everyone, but very much appreciated by us.This is such a relaxed environment vs. Waikiki. We love the Halekulani on Waikiki beach, but that's not a family place, so this was a great place to relax with the kids. It was easy to hop in the rental car to hike to the top of Diamond Head or over to Hanauma Bay for snorkeling, too.

Kahala Resort truly transports you to the serene, luxurious tropical oasis that Oahu used to be. Just far enough away from Waikiki, it's is a perfect way to escape the hustle and bustle of the city, and find real relaxation. Their spa is one of the best, leaving you feeling pampered in the most tranquil setting.I love enjoying a cocktail at the Veranda while listening to jazz at sunset, then heading to Hokus for their award winning pacific rim cuisine.It is no wonder that celebrities and politicians always escape to this property when visiting Hawaii. The professionalism of the staff and tasteful discretion that they employ allow for a sense of privacy for those looking for it.

I have been to a couple of events at the Kahala Hotel in the past two months that have been over the top. They host a customer appreciation event for guests that feature declicious drinks, scrumptuous pupus and allow you to enjoy their incredible grounds. I was happy to skip the Super Bowl Tail Gate that day to attend the most recent event, which was themed for Valentine's Day. We were greeted with rose petals and lead to the Spa area where there were various stations set up. We learn how to make amazing cocktails from a master mixologist, learn foot and lomi lomi massaging techniques and the most fun was a lingerie station! The service was incredible, as usual! The whole staff is amazing, they make you feel welcomed and special.I, among many others continue to go back to the Kahala for the breathtaking ambiance, inviting culture and deliciouse cuisine. It really can't be beat!I can't wait to see what is coming up this year....

We stayed here for the majority of our 2 week long Hawaii honeymoon. And we plan to spend all our anniversaries there.PROS:-Private beach (away from all the chaos of Waikiki)-Staff (very helpful and friendly)-Rooms (roomy and clean)-Property (everything you could possibly need is there)-Shuttle to shopping centers (very convenient and punctual)CONS:-None.

Just left another hotel on the island after being thoroughly disappointed, and found the Kahala online. I called reservations explained my horrific experience, and was invited to come take a look at the Kahala. The reservationist made arrangements for the manager to meet us in the lobby. First, let me say the drive over from Waikiki, was so pleasant. Finally I felt like I was in Hawaii, and not Venice Beach, California. The closer we got to the hotel the better the surroundings. The area is like being in one of the better areas of Maui. The Kahala is a beachfront property located on a secluded corner of the island, that is only accessible to hotel guests. When we arrived the courteous manager personally escorted us to view 2 rooms they had in mind for my husband and I and our 2 teens. They were gorgeous, spacious (each over 500 sft.), and well appointed rooms with really nice views. We immediately checked in and headed to the pool and beach areas. Right outside the back of the lobby next to the pool there were, dolphins, turtles, fish, and a stingray. We arrived seeing the dolphins being fed and putting on a heck of a show. You can swim with the dolphins for a fee. The pool was decent, but who needs a pool when you have a private beautiful beach, with excellent attendant service to set up your complimentary lounge chairs and towels where ever you prefer. Each night we returned to our room after dinner, we would walk into a clean room with soft music playing, low lighting, the bed turned down, floor mats on both sides of the bed with a bottle of cold water on each nite stand. The bathroom was very nice, over sized and split, as in his and her sides with robes and slippers for your use. The towels and the high end toiletries were refreshed twice a day. The breakfast buffet was excellent with a variety of foods to please just about any nationality. The view from every area of the hotel was fantastic, from the lobby to the restaurant to your guestroom. Valet service was efficient with friendly knowledgeable staff. The fitness room was well appointed. Both women and men locker rooms had a dry sauna, steam room, spa, showers, and toiletries. There are fitness classes and personal trainers for a fee. If you are one to get excited about seeing celebrities or dignitaries, you may run into a few staying at the Kahala. If nothing else you will feel like one or the other with such great service and surroundings. Call reservations and ask for least expensive online rate, no need to spring for ocean view, any view is beautiful at the Kahala. I hope this review was helpful.

I held a meeting at this hotel in July 2011. The facilities were great. Private meeting space with windows in the foyer. The service as excellent. Great beach area, very private. The pool was nothing to write home about, but if you're in Hawaii you really should be on the beach. Definitely spring for an ocean view room. Great, large lanai's to watch the ocean. There is a free shuttle that runs to Waikiki and the mall, however you really should rent a car if you stay at the property. That's where it gets expensive. This is great if you're really looking to get away from the hustle and bustle of Waikiki, but it is a drive to most attractions.

Others have written wonderful things about the Kahala, and we found them to be true, and more! We stayed in an Ocean View Lanai room, on a corner of the building, and could look down on the driveway below, and beyond to the expanse of the ocean and the back side of Diamondhead. From inside the room, we could see the ocean. The dolphin lagoon is lovely, but don't expect a Sea World experience - if you're in one of the lagoon rooms, it's like the dolphins are staying in the room next door. The resort is in a quiet neighborhood, far from the bustle of Waikiki, and yet only minutes away. It's actually easier and faster to get to the airport from here than from the Waikiki hotels. The service here is exceptional (we'd equate it with the Four Seasons or Ritz-Carlton) and the rooms are extremely comfortable. We had breaksfast at Plumeria Beach House, and it was excellent, even by Hawaii standards. We also had afternoon tea at the Veranda, and it was a wonderful experience! You can make reservations at all of the restaurants on opentable.com.We don't regularly take trips of this magnitude, but when we do, we really want it to be wonderful, and to be worth the money we're spending. The Kahala Hotel and Resort exceeded our expectations - our thanks to their warm and friendly staff for making this such a special vacation.

We stayed one glorious night at the Kahala before a Hawaiian cruise. The lobby is amazing and peaceful. The private beach is fantastic. We booked a basic room and were delighted at the quality of furnishings and the size. Just lovely. We never left the property and ate at all of the restaurants, which I can recommend. Also, the drinks were a perfect while on a beach chair or at the bar looking over the ocean. Can't stress how much we loved this resort. Also, I splashed out for the private car booked with the resort from the airport and to the dock. Money well spent because both drivers actually gave us a tour while getting to our destinations. Oh, and did I mention the dolphin lagoon? Yep, right on the property. Very cool.

We stayed here for a week in February 2012 and absolutely loved it. The staff was friendly and helpful, from the moment we showed up, til the moment we left. The level of service was very high -- the rooms were cleaned each morning and the beds turned down each night. Anytime anyone serviced the room, they left fresh ice and a bottle of water.The amenities are great. There is a shuttle to Waikiki (which is a couple of miles away). Only downside was that it stopped service at 9 PM. There were also bikes available to ride (until sundown). The hotel has it's own beach, which is small but nice and had a long sandbar. The pool closes at night, but the hot tub is open 24 hrs. There are a few of restaurants, including Hokus, which is super nice. It also had a beach-side grill that was a little less pricey. They also have car rental on-site (although you'd probably do better to rent from the airport, depending on how many days you'd rent it for).We paid for the cheapest room (Mountain with no Lanai) and it was still an amazing, beautiful view. Even the bathroom was super nice (shower and large tub with his/her vanities and closets). Also, in addition to the dolphins, they had a couple of sea turtles. So cute!I'm very glad we stayed at the Kahala, and I would happily stay there again!
user_name:
Nora M
Mountain View, California, United States

review_body: My husband and I just returned from a 4 night stay at the Kahala. We were with a large group from his work but were on our own for the most part. We thoroughly enjoyed our stay. The staff was very helpful and friendly, the buffet breakfast was very tasty and at $32 a person, not outrageously priced. Most nice hotels in Hawaii charge that much and have for years. The shuttle service was efficient and free, a bonus since a cab ride into Waikiki runs about $20-25. Our room was very clean, spacious and comfortable, maid service twice daily. The beach in front of the hotel is very nice, the pool is small but many hotels in Waikiki have small pools as well. They must assume you're going to spend more time in the ocean. We really enjoyed our stay and without hesitation would return with our kids.

We stayed at the Kahala in September 2011. My husband, our baby boy (7 months) and I. It was worth every penny and even though it's expensive, it's also close to flawless. Of course, this all depends on your expectations and what you are looking for. We were trying to avoid the crowds at Waikiki, looking for a more secluded beach, a quiet but comfortable hotel with a choice of restaurants (so to avoid having to go to Waikiki), but close enough to the city centre to be able to go shopping a day or two.For this purpose, the Kahala is perfect. They have a free shuttle bus which we used for the Ala Moana shopping mall and Waikiki - for a walk down the busy streets. It doesn't run all the time and it pays off to sign up for it, but it's very handy and works well. Not sure it would work if you go out all night dancing, but then you can probably take a taxi. For us, it was perfect with our own beach which did not seem crowded or busy at all. With a baby we were at the pool quite early and never had any problems with sun chairs - even if we came late morning or early afternoon it was possible to get a chair - easily.The choice of restaurants is perfect. We had roomservice (nice and convenient with a baby) a few times as well as dinner at practically all the restaurants. They are pricey, but from a European's point of view, it's not pricey taking into consideration what you get. The sushi restaurant serves delicious sushi and japanese courses and the service and ambience was relaxed and personal. No problem at all with a baby sleeping in a stroller. We came in early and asked in advance if it was ok.Their upscale restaurant (forgot he name) was amazing. Again, expensive, but we live in Copenhagen, so not so bad in comparison. Even here we asked and got an ok to bring a sleeping baby in a stroller. The service was fantastic. They were very accomodating and nice to move us to one end of the restaurant, since a rather noisy party was right next to us to begin with. We always try to be not too much of a burden if we bring a baby and get in and leave as early as possible so as not to be of any inconvenience, but they did not make us feel uncomfortable at all. On the contrary. We had one of the best dinners of our holidays in Hawaii. In other words: we were absolutely fine with the location, quiet, family friendly (without being swarmed with noisy children) and beautiful! Forget about serene, beautiful sunsets if you're in Waikiki. Expect there to be a million others right next to you taking a picture. At Kahala, on the other hand, you'll feel that island feeling and remember why you chose Hawaii and not Miami (if you come for the same thing as we did).On premise, they have everything you could wish for. My husband even got a haircut and I did yoga close to beach front one morning. It's a small pavillon and only downside is that it's right next to the breakfast terrace and even though they have white curtains to shut off from all the people, it would have been nicer closer to the beach. The yoga instructor was good. I'm not very experienced so he put together a practice that was a perfect mix for all levels.Rooms are beautiful and with huge bathrooms. We could easily "rent" a microwave for a fee and we could borrow a baby crip for free. Extremely comfortable beds, spacious rooms (standard sizes and the suites are just two rooms put together) and we had a nice view to the golf course.The microwave ended up being superflouous since we could get oatmeal at the breakfast buffet for our son. The best breakfast ever! Made on the spot omelets, and an abundance of choice - even catering to the Japanese guests. Couldn't list it all even if I tried. Have to mentioned their buttermilk pancakes, though! Don't miss their breakfast if you're there. Maybe at least one morning. At the same restaurant we tried their seafood buffet one evening. Actually, an amazingly high quality of food considering the number of people there and thef act that it was a buffet. Fresh sea food, sushi, a million different stuff. Delicious.See our room tips, for more about the rooms.We did not try the dolphin experience, but (without being an expert) the dolphins seemed quite happy (!!) and the families trying the whole thing looked pleased and happy as well. With our son being so small the (relatively) high prices didn't seem to be worth it.The hotel was top of our list of places we saw in Hawaii, the service, the rooms, the location, the food, the pool (had a very small childrens' pool and the main pool was nice) and everything. Overall the amenities and activities there, including the pool, was great for us. For older kids, it was a great place, but maybe more for relaxing for some days in a quiet spot not in Waikiki. It's not really for adventures onsite - think it's a great spot for exploring Diamond Head, though, and easy going into Waikiki for shopping etc. The dolphin experience might be worth it all for families with older kids. Having mentioned all this about our baby and kids - don't worry, couples and friends (looking for a quiet spot) can have an amazing time here. I remember holidays without kids - and I would recommend it for that purpose anytime. Even if I ever had a chance to come back to Honolulu without kids, I would definitely stay here again.Just go there and splurge and enjoy - it's worth it. (went to Royal Hawaiian - which also seemed nice - and Halekulani - which are comparable in price - would go with Kahala anytime...)

According to dictionary.com, hospitality is the friendly treatment and reception of guests or strangers. The staff of the Kahala Hotel and Resort not only extended hospitality to my partner and I, but exceeded all expectations one can come to expect for a Leading Hotel of the World. In fact, I think we need to create a new word in the English language for their excellent and warm hospitality. After a horrendous stay at the Royal Hawaiian Hotel, we were hesitant about the remaining nights of our vacation. After calling American Express for a hotel recommendation and booking, we had a decision to make: the Kahala or Hilton Hawaiian Village. Thank God we chose the Kahala! Immediately upon our arrival to the Kahala we were greeted with a warm welcome by both the valet/bell stand staff as well as a guest servicerepresentative who presented us with a kukui shell lei and a cold towel. The thing my partner and I liked best about the greeting from the bell staff was when we inquired about valet or self parking, he said to go ahead and check in and whatever we decided was fine, he just wanted to spoil us! What a great first impression of a hotel!!! As they say, you never get a second chance at a first impression, and boy did they hit this DIRECTLY on the head. After valeting the car, wewere ushered to the reception desk and after a brief wait we had the privilege and honor to be checked in by Lynn. Of all the hotels I've stayed in( and I do stay in quite a bit of hotels for work... At least 150 nights on the road a year), I've never felt so welcomed at a hotel in my life! It felt like we were returning home and your closest family member was greeting after not seeing you for an extended amount of time. After briefing mentioning our terrible and short stay at the Royal Hawaiian, Lynn checked us in most efficiently and quickly. As she was finishing, she asked us to wait for just a moment. Can you believe she had the Front Office Manager, Tobias, escort us to our room!? What a nice touch! A lot of 5 star hotels will either check youin your actual room or have an agent escort you, but we've never had a manager. After showing us to our room, he gave us his card and personally thanked us for choosing the Kahala and informed us that if we needed anything, he was just a phone call away... What a great change after the Royal Hawaiian. The rooms are quite spacious, dressed in a simple, yet modern elegance. We were lucky enough to have a lanai, as not all rooms have one. Words to the wise, book an ocean view LANAI room or better for nice rooms with a lanai. The bathroomsare also quite large, they all have a separate bathtub and shower... double vanity... two closets... and shelves/drawers. One of our favorite things in the room was the bath robes... They are almost a knit material, which is quite different from your typical terry clothrobes found in most hotels. Recommendations for you stay, be sure to do the breakfast buffet. We definitely had our share plus another families' share! :D. And if you have lunch/dinner at the hotel or room service, be sure to have their fruit salad, which is served in a pineapple half and accompanied with sorbet... My personal favorite flavor of sorbet is their lilikoi, which is Hawaiian for passion fruit. YUM YUM! To summarize, the Kahala hotel is definitely heaven onOahu, if not heaven on Earth.. from the staff to the rooms to the hotel grounds (which are stunning and picturesque- nice for weddings), you can't go wrong staying here. Definitely don't waste your money at the Royal Hawaiian and Hilton Hawaiian Village. Are those hotelscentrally located in Waikiki, yes... but the reason you want to come to Hawaii is for relaxation and peace of mind. Oh, and did I mention they have dolphins and sea turtles at the Kahala?! You can do a group swimming session or individual session... All for the right price ofcourse :). Thank you Kahala, but more importantly thank you Lynn!
user_name:
AD361
New York City, New York

review_body: Let me start by saying that my husband posted a lengthy review of our recent stay (see "Disappointed with recent stay" on Feb 13, 2012 by ParadiseLost1978), to which the general manager responded to and asked him to contact her directly to handle our complaints. My husband wrote her back immediately and has yet to hear a response (almost a month later). Great management, huh? I grew up staying at the Kahala with my family and have such fond memories of this hotel, which is why my husband and I decided to stay here to celebrate our wedding anniversary and my good health after finishing chemotherapy. Sadly, this is not the same hotel it once was. It breaks my heart to write a bad review of this hotel...though if it leads some of you reading this to stay elsewhere and avoid a disappointing Hawaii trip (didn't even know that could be possible!), then it is well worth it. I'll refrain from commenting about the jack-hammering that ruined our stay since my husband's review (and many other reviews on here) give a great recap. What I will comment on is, that after multiple attempts to get more than a generic apology from management, we have heard nothing. If this was a 3.5 or maybe 4-star hotel, then this review would have a very different tone. But for a 5-star resort that charges what they charge, the resort and the management should be at a 5-star level. Construction noise aside (that was loud enough to be heard through earplugs while sitting on the far end of the beach, btw), here is an overview:Let's start with the good....The rooms are beautiful and luxurious. Even the cheapest room in the hotel is large and well decorated - really makes you feel like you are on vacation. Beds are very comfortable. The maid/room service/wait staff are very nice and attentive. If you have kids, the dolphins are amazing and will keep them entertained for hours. And if you're the type of parents that don't really want to parent when you are on vacation, you can let your kids run around the small-ish resort area (because that's what most of the parents there were doing). Tip: If you don't have kids or don't want to be bothered by other people's unattended kids, I suggest heading far to your left when you get out to the beach. Protected ocean is great for wading and swimming. There are no waves at all, so if you are not a strong swimmer you can safely swim here. Food out by the beach/pool is great - love the soba noodle salad! Had a great meal at Hoku's.The not so good...The pool is SMALL! If you are a pool person, stay elsewhere. It is tiny (think the size you would see in a backyard of a very nice home). Bathrooms by the pool are disgusting. By the end of the day it starts to feel like a Starbucks bathroom in NYC. I think it's from the tour buses of people that get dropped off at the hotel to hang out and watch the dolphins. Breakfast buffet is good, but not great. The fruit I bought in LA when we got home tasted better, and canned peaches at a breakfast buffet at a 5-star resort in Hawaii is unacceptable. And again with the tour-bus drop-off! With only 1 person making eggs, you could wait in line a very long time with the tourists to get your omelette. The host at the Plumeria will actually encourage you to eat breakfast before 8am to avoid this. The beach is not smoke-free and there were many hotel guests smoking. When the breeze picked up, it wasn't so bad, but if you prefer not to breathe in second-hand smoke, the newer resorts are much better about this issue. Thankfully, this was not a problem in our room or at any of the restaurants. If you are like us and grew up coming here in the 80's and 90's, pay attention to the recent reviews! It is not the same management and not the special hotel you may remember. :( Create new memories with your family elsewhere.

I stayed at this resort for one night. I could only afford a "Scenic View" room, even with the advanced purchase promotional discount. The room was still the same nice room as other rooms, with the only difference being the view. I was on a stopover between Sydney and the mainland US so I didn't really need a view for a one-night stay. That said, the view was actually nice - the mountainside behind the resort as well as a nice waterfall on the resort grounds. And, the location within the hotel was very quiet. I was in room 104. The room was very clean and nice and large - especially the bathroom. I had the best night's sleep in this hotel on my entire 11-day journey - the most comfortable bed, and I never had to use my earplugs.I arrived before the designated check-in time, around noon, and my room was available immediately, so I was thrilled with that. The desk staff and bell staff were very friendly and full of information even though I would only be there one day. The resort did not appear to be crowded, though I saw two wedding parties - one each on Thursday and Friday. I was able to find a good chair on the beach no problem, and there is staff in the pool/beach area to set you up with towels and covers for shade.I chose this hotel because it had a private beach area for hotel guests only as well as a shuttle to Waikiki if I wanted to eat in town instead of onsite. I wanted to be able to relax and enjoy the ocean/beach without the Waikiki crowds, and this place fit the bill. Waikiki is always so busy, and I am not a shopper, so I ended up staying put. There were plenty of nice areas on the property to relax. I did not try any of the shopping or the spa available onsite. I also did not try the activities offered, such as dolphin encounters or water sports, as they cost extra $$$.I wound up trying meals in the Veranda, Plumeria Beach House, and the casual beach-area restaurant and all were reasonably good. The Veranda only serves Pupus/Appetizers, but they are good-sized portions and very tasty - the best food out of the three places I tried, though they had a limited menu. The service at the beach-area restaurant was quite slow, and the food seemed to cater mostly to kids (hot dogs, nachos, burgers) but the fish sandwich I ordered was tasty, although pricey. And, I had an early lunch prior to check-out at the Plumeria Beach House that had a nice patio on the beach with great views. The food was fine, but not spectacular - again, pricey but typical for Hawaii. The fourth eatery is the upscale restaurant which I did not try. Overall, I would recommend this place for a more relaxed atmosphere compared to Waikiki. Personally, the view from my room is not very important to me so I wouldn't pay the charges for the upgrades since it is not a nominal fee change to go from the least expensive category up to an ocean front category. On a property like this, I tend to use my room for sleeping, showering, changing, and enjoy the ocean from the beach.

I stayed here twice and first time I booked Ocean Front View Room, because I would be there with my families who were not traveling around and wanted to see the great ocean in Hawaii. I stayed 4th floor in the center of the building but the view was dissappointing. There were a big parking lot in front of my room and half of the view from my room was occupied by the parking view! Then the next year I booked a partical ocean view, confirmed by the room description, which were, seemed to me, did not have much difference. Although I booked the room more than 6months before the arrival date, my room was disaster... Actually my room was located in the center of the building directly facing the mountain side! The first word my mother told me was, "where is the ocean!" Soon I called the front desk, assuming that they must have misunderstood my reservation, however, they told me that was a partical ocean view room! Yeah...., if I look back the ocean side from the balcony, I could see very small part of the ocean (but none from the room). In my perspective, it cannot be called as a partial ocean view room! Actually some other guests had same feelings and I happened to see several guests were claiming the front desk to change the room.However other services were excellent. The Hoku's dishes were awesome. The common facilities of the hotel was very gorgeous. If you do not care to pay how much money and stay more than suite room, you may be satisfied with the hotel.

Visited for a day to enjoy the calm beach and assess whether or not we wanted to stay there for a few days at the end of our trip. We ate and relaxed. Wonderful beach, overpriced resort to stay out in my honest opinion. Day trip this one and stay in Waikiki. Staff were okay, not overly friendly which made me decide real quick to stay elsewhere at the tail of our trip. Also, HORRIBLE construction going on with jackhammering that could be heard down the beach!

Yep! It's taken me this long to recover. Great video/audio on UTube of the construction work at The Kahala early last month. Mr Sweeney, Ms Grippo, did you know you had guests during early February? One would think not. We never knew about the construction when we booked our holiday. It affected our enjoyment almost every day of our stay and meant we could not take advantage of the pool or the beach and lagoon. Instead, we had to leave in order to maintain our sanity the noise was so loud. We would have had the opportunity to go elsewhere and enjoy our visit had we known about the construction and we are very disappointed to have had the experience we did. Imagine treating guests with such disdain! I do hope people who read Trip Advisor will take note: The Kahala is no longer the fine hotel it once was and management wants you to know that.

We travel a lot with our kids and my wife and I both agreed that this was probably the best hotel overall we have stayed at. Before I give my review of the hotel I just wanted to tell people who look at these reviews to take them all with a grain of salt. The week before we came we saw a few concerning reviews. I called the hotel before we arrived and mentioned these to them. Flora the manager who was maybe the nicest and most professional hotel manager I have ever spoke to allayed our fears and did all she could to make our stay perfect. I always read these reviews to see if it would be a good hotel for my family. I was just rereading a few of the negative reviews. One person's negative review was because they pronounced his name wrong, something that he said happens all the time anyway. When you are staying at a resort like this, you expect things to be expensive, so why complain about it. If your grey goose costs 11 dollars and that is a deal breaker for you, don't stay at a 5 star resort.
